$\mathbf E$ is the square matrix of order $m$ of the form:
:$E_{a b} = \delta_{a b} + \lambda \cdot \delta_{a i} \cdot \delta_{j b}$
where:
:$E_{a b}$ denotes the element of $\mathbf E$ whose indices are $\tuple {a, b}$
:$\delta_{a b}$ is the Kronecker delta:
::$\delta_{a b} = \begin {cases} 1 & : \text {if $a = b$} \\ 0 & : \text {if $a \ne b$} \end {cases}$

7c79c448-b2ca-43fb-a511-7094a0edfc74.text:
Consider the subset $S$ of the complex plane defined as:
:$S := \set {\dfrac i n : n \in \Z_{>0} }$
That is:
:$S := \set {i, \dfrac i 2, \dfrac i 3, \dfrac i 4, \ldots}$
where $i$ is the imaginary unit.
The set $S$ has exactly one limit point, and that is $z = 0$.

30e1353c-9018-4f0b-8080-b0a2030a3e08.text:
Let $\struct {\Q, \tau_d}$ be the rational number space under the Euclidean topology $\tau_d$.
Then $\struct {\Q, \tau_d}$ is $\sigma$-compact.

4c68939f-3eb8-4cd4-a683-f0350e212b9d.text:
Let $\alpha$, $\beta$ and $\gamma$ be cuts.
Let the operation of $\alpha + \beta$ be the sum of $\alpha$ and $\beta$.
Let $\beta < \gamma$ denotes the strict ordering on cuts defined as:
:$\beta < \gamma \iff \exists p \in \Q: p \in \beta, p \notin \gamma$
Then:
:$\beta < \gamma \implies \alpha + \beta < \alpha + \gamma$

aa46d19a-2c0c-447d-853f-38b25553ccf4.text:
Let $\struct {X, \circ}$ be a $B$-algebra. 
Then:
:$\forall x \in X: 0 \circ \paren {0 \circ x} = x$

2f3fd4be-0230-40d4-a2fd-49aa2cb06c7d.text:
Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a topological space.
Let $A$ be a subset of $S$.
Then:
:$A^0 \subseteq A'$
where
:$A^0$ denotes the set of condensation points of $A$
:$A'$ denotes the derivative of $A$

86ae9ab6-25bc-44f7-a96f-024d6c426c4f.text:
Let $S$ be the set of odd integers:
:$S = \set {x \in \Z: \exists n \in \Z: x = 2 n + 1}$
Let $\struct {S, +}$ denote the algebraic structure formed by $S$ under the operation of addition.
Then $\struct {S, +}$ is not a group.

968d9896-8716-48a5-83b6-87262327f0bb.text:
Consider the folium of Descartes $F$, given in parametric form as:
:$\begin {cases} x = \dfrac {3 a t} {1 + t^3} \\ y = \dfrac {3 a t^2} {1 + t^3} \end {cases}$
The area $\AA$ of the loop of $F$ is given as:
:$\AA = \dfrac {3 a^2} 2$

5e52342f-359f-4648-81f8-0936c354788e.text:
Let $\struct {G, \oplus}$ and $\struct {H, \odot}$ be groups.
Let $\phi: \struct {G, \oplus} \to \struct {H, \odot}$ be a group epimorphism.
Let $e_G$ and $e_H$ be the identities of $G$ and $H$ respectively.
Let $K = \map \ker \phi$ be the kernel of $\phi$.
There is one and only one group isomorphism $\psi: G / K \to H$ satisfying:
:$\psi \circ q_K = \phi$
where $q_K$ is the quotient epimorphism from $G$ to $G / K$.

921b3d20-0818-4f5e-a80b-5bfe886b028a.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $H \subseteq A$.
Let $d_H: H \times H \to \R$ be the restriction $d \restriction_{H \times H}$ of $d$ to $H$.
Let $\struct {H, d_H}$ be a metric subspace of $\struct {A, d}$.
Then $d_H$ is a metric on $H$.

8f24fa94-31cd-444d-8487-ac5f47dd99b4.text:
Let $f: X \to X$ be a function, where $X$ is either $\R$ or $\C$.
Let $L \in X_{\ne 0}$ be an anti-periodic element of $f$.
Then $2L$ is a periodic element of $f$.
In other words, every anti-periodic function is also periodic.

ad68b814-a26c-47a3-b5c2-77dace7c521e.text:
Let $\Sigma$ be a $\sigma$-algebra over a set $X$.
Let $f: \Sigma \to \overline \R_{\ge 0}$ be an additive and countably subadditive function, where $\overline \R_{\ge 0}$ denotes the set of positive extended real numbers.
Then $f$ is countably additive.

16be164b-daa9-4f1c-a7b6-535137deb5e0.text:
Let $T_1 = \struct {S_1, \tau_1}$, $T_2 = \struct {S_2, \tau_2}$ be topological spaces.
Let $f: S_1 \to S_2$ be a homeomorphism between $T_1$ and $T_2$.
Let $S$ be a subset of $S_1$.
Let $f {\restriction_{S \times f \sqbrk S} } : S \to f \sqbrk S$ be the restriction of $f$ to $S \times f \sqbrk S$.
Let $S$ and $f \sqbrk S$ bear their respective subspace topologies.
Then $f {\restriction_{S \times f \sqbrk S} }$ is a homeomorphism.

0650b220-b30b-4096-a8eb-2ebd820fa49b.text:
Let $\N_{>0}$ be the set of natural numbers without zero, i.e. $\N_{>0} = \N \setminus \set 0$.
The structure $\struct{\N_{>0}, \times}$ forms a commutative monoid.

673cc4eb-7c56-49f4-a01a-61161bd6b89c.text:
:$\sin^3 x = \dfrac {3 \sin x - \sin 3 x} 4$
where $\sin$ denotes sine.

276eb39a-53ad-48e7-a70e-9ca28822c42f.text:
Let $A = \struct {A_F, \oplus}$ be a $*$-algebra.
Let $A' = \struct {A_F, \oplus'}$ be constructed from $A$ using the Cayley-Dickson construction.
Then:
: $A'$ is an associative algebra
{{iff}}:
: $A$ is both a commutative algebra and an associative algebra.

72ede72c-d22f-4fc2-b1a7-c519b609a70f.text:
Let $\struct {\R, d}$ denote the real number line $\R$ with the usual (Euclidean) metric $d$.
Let $x \in \R$ be a point in $\R$.
Let $\map {B_\epsilon} x$ be the open $\epsilon$-ball at $x$.
Then $\map {B_\epsilon} x$ is the open interval $\openint {x - \epsilon} {x + \epsilon}$.

2f8aea29-e0b9-4a50-8582-002a87eca075.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \preceq}\right), R = \left({T, \precsim}\right)$ be ordered sets.
Ley $g:S \to T, d:T \to S$ be mappings such that
:$\left({g, d}\right)$ is Galois connection
and
:$g$ is a surjection/
Let $N = \left({d\left[{T}\right], \preceq'}\right)$ be an ordered subset of $L$.
Then $R$ and $N$ are order isomorphic.

3c0952f6-f590-4350-879f-85eba5c4a3c9.text:
Let $M$ be a class which is minimally inductive under a progressing mapping $g$.
Then every non-empty bounded subset of $M$ has a greatest element.

171fdb48-539b-4bf6-8271-e71e00ce9c6d.text:
Let $\sequence {a_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ be a sequence of natural numbers.
Then the following are equivalent:
$(1): \quad \ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n$ converges
$(2): \quad \exists N \in \N: \forall n \ge N: a_n = 0$
That is, $\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n$ converges {{iff}} only finitely many of the $a_n$ are non-zero.

ee665948-59b9-4370-b3fb-11555a5a0cfa.text:
:$\ds \int_0^{2 \pi} \frac {\d x} {1 - 2 a \cos x + a^2} = \frac {2 \pi} {1 - a^2}$
where $a$ is a real number with $0 < a < 1$.

4e6b3ab5-6482-4efc-b98a-de8f04cfbbcd.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \times}$ be a Euclidean domain whose unity is $1$.
Let $p$ be an irreducible element of $D$.
Let $n \in D$ such that:
:$\ds n = \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^r a_i$
where $a_i \in D$ for all $i: 1 \le i \le r$.
If $p$ divides $n$, then $p$ divides $a_i$ for some $i$.
That is:
:$p \divides a_1 a_2 \ldots a_n \implies p \divides a_1 \lor p \divides a_2 \lor \cdots \lor p \divides a_n$

f81825e6-cad3-4a4d-a673-43dfb8c2f8a7.text: The set of real numbers $\R$ forms a field under addition and multiplication: $\struct {\R, +, \times}$.

8e139ef2-a733-4406-a3f7-a7b0dac7e62b.text:
Let $A \subseteq B$ be an extension of commutative rings with unity.
Let $C$ be the integral closure of $A$ in $B$.
Then $C$ is integrally closed.

b66c18bb-96e0-4a3f-88e6-92f04fe1f78d.text:
Let $T = \struct {\set {0, 1}, \tau_0}$ be a Sierpiński space.
Then $T$ is irreducible.

11e0b80a-f1c9-4aea-ac18-2cce929eb07c.text:
For every pair of integers $a, b$ where $a \ge 0$ and $b > 0$, there exist integers $q, r$ such that $a = q b + r$ and $0 \le r < b$:
:$\forall a, b \in \Z, a \ge 0, b > 0: \exists q, r \in \Z: a = q b + r, 0 \le r < b$

17a06018-e141-4c7e-9ecb-e97cfb8faae6.text:
Let $m, n \in \Z$ such that $n > 0$.
Let $x \in \R$.
Then:
:$\ceiling {\dfrac {x + m} n} = \ceiling {\dfrac {\ceiling x + m} n}$
where $\ceiling x$ denotes the ceiling of $x$.

34cb6701-514c-4f76-8266-6d42f2677187.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set which has a smallest element.
Let $m$ be the smallest element of $\struct {S, \preceq}$.
Then $m$ is a minimal element.

4080e54b-f8a3-42e9-aea3-727401e99eda.text:
:$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {\cosh x} = \sinh x$
where $\cosh$ is the hyperbolic cosine and $\sinh$ is the hyperbolic sine.

305cc965-0dd9-424d-8ee8-1634fd5b93e5.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $H \subseteq A$ be an arbitrary subset of $A$.
Let $x \in A$ be a limit point of $H$.
Let $\map d {x, H}$ denote the distance between $x$ and $H$:
:$\ds \map d {x, H} = \inf_{y \mathop \in H} \paren {\map d {x, y} }$
Then:
:$\map d {x, H} = 0$

10f97afa-1ca9-4929-ab5a-397e750c93df.text:
Let $P$ be the perfect number $2^{n - 1} \paren {2^n - 1}$.
Then:
:$\ds \prod_{d \mathop \divides P} d = P^n$

61016808-2500-4a48-b452-9c80c9183f69.text:
Let $f: D \to \C$ be a complex function, where $D \subseteq \C$ is an open set.
Suppose that $f$ is complex-differentiable at $z \in D$.
Then $f$ is continuous at $z$.

4177f777-28bd-4ead-b181-7ff97c1683fc.text:
Let $a \in \R_{\ne 0}$.
Let $b = 0$.
Then:
:$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {a x^2 + b x + c} = \begin {cases}
\dfrac 1 {\sqrt {a c} } \map \arctan {x \sqrt {\dfrac a c} } + C & : a c > 0 \\
\dfrac 1 {2 \sqrt {-a c} } \ln \size {\dfrac {a x - \sqrt {-a c} } {a x + \sqrt {-a c} } } + C & : a c < 0 \\
\dfrac {-1} {a x} + C & : c = 0
\end {cases}$

b7e6b7e1-bfe1-4bf0-a85c-04d56f701c35.text:
Let $T_1$ and $T_2$ be topological spaces.
Let $S_1 \subseteq T_1$ be connected.
Let $f: T_1 \to T_2$ be a continuous mapping.
Then the image $f \sqbrk {S_1}$ is connected.

f361db0a-f8cd-4a3f-b98f-325d1a1ed7f5.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a Fortissimo space.
Then $T$ is not a $\sigma$-compact space.

85f6ecf0-bdb8-4617-a818-a2da185673a7.text:
Let $r \in \Q$ be a rational number.
Then $r$ is an algebraic number of degree $1$.

1ae9fa1c-88cf-46c4-a29f-869f4b2ee559.text: A ring of sets $\struct {\RR, *, \cap}$ is a commutative ring whose zero is $\O$.

7f7b1dc0-829b-43c7-bd35-ff9e1d3b7315.text:
:$\ds \int \map \Si x \rd x = x \map \Si x + \cos x + C$
where $\Si$ denotes the sine integral function.

703ebce8-94eb-467f-9de3-4710956580b9.text:
Let $n \in \Z$ such that $n$ is not a square.
Then the continued fraction expansion of $\sqrt n$ is of the form:
:$\sqbrk {a_1 \sequence {b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_{m - 1}, b_m, b_{m - 1}, \ldots, b_2, b_1, 2 a_1} }$
or
:$\sqbrk {a_1 \sequence {b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_{m - 1}, b_m, b_m, b_{m - 1}, \ldots, b_2, b_1, 2 a_1} }$
where $m \in \Z: m \ge 0$.
That is, it has the form as follows:
:It is periodic
:It starts with an integer $a_1$
:Its cycle starts with a palindromic section, either:
:::$b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_{m - 1}, b_m, b_{m - 1}, \ldots, b_2, b_1$
::or:
:::$b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_{m - 1}, b_m, b_m, b_{m - 1}, \ldots, b_2, b_1$
::which may be of length zero
:Its cycle ends with twice the first partial quotient.

2f4d4bd2-0e06-4216-9ec1-5f2a34caa275.text:
Let $n, k \in \Z_{\ge 0}$ such that $k > n$.
Let $\ds {n \brace k}$ denote a Stirling number of the second kind.
Then:
:$\ds {n \brace k} = 0$

04faf09d-c04e-4e5a-a813-aa5921cfabac.text:
Let $R$ be a ring with unity.
Let $J$ be an ideal of $R$.
If the quotient ring $R / J$ is a division ring then $J$ is a maximal left ideal.

a1a0ab16-bf69-46b0-8b45-7f8829c37a34.text:
Let $a, b, m \in \Z$.
Let $a \equiv b \pmod m$ denote that $a$ is congruent to $b$ modulo $m$.
Then $\forall n \in \Z, n \ne 0$:
: $a \equiv b \pmod m \iff a n \equiv b n \pmod {m n}$

d9be1576-6f75-4752-af6b-ef46109d5140.text: :$\ds \int \arcsin x \rd x = x \arcsin x + \sqrt {1 - x^2} + C$

7f7fb875-6b02-443e-9844-f282a07e5568.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq_1}$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $\struct {T, \preceq_2}$ be an ordered set.
Let $\phi: S \to T$ be a strictly increasing mapping.
Then $\phi$ is an order embedding.

9fbb168d-76ab-470c-ab58-998e1c7eafd0.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a perfectly normal space.
Then $T$ is also a completely normal space.

9dac77da-a3c6-45f9-83d7-59f2786b9ff6.text:
:$\ds e = \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \dfrac n {\sqrt [n] {n!} }$
where:
:$e$ denotes Euler's number
:$n!$ denotes $n$ factorial.

d0d6e78b-69f9-4a28-a8a0-83e5905bf317.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number such that $\size x > 1$.
Let $\arcsec x$ be the arcsecant of $x$.
Then:
:$\dfrac {\map \d {\arcsec x} } {\d x} = \dfrac 1 {\size x \sqrt {x^2 - 1} } = \begin {cases} \dfrac {+1} {x \sqrt {x^2 - 1} } & : 0 < \arcsec x < \dfrac \pi 2 \ (\text {that is: $x > 1$}) \\
\dfrac {-1} {x \sqrt {x^2 - 1} } & : \dfrac \pi 2 < \arcsec x < \pi \ (\text {that is: $x < -1$})  \\
\end{cases}$

f4f5d8c5-994a-4200-bc96-770b19f78f9e.text:
Let $x$ and $y$ be ordinals.
Then:
:$x^y \in \On$
That is, ordinal exponentiation is closed.

79376a20-1acc-4724-9056-612ff75ef206.text:
Let $\OO^n$, $\CC^n$ and $\KK^n$ be the collections of open, closed and compact subsets of the Euclidean space $\struct {\R^n, \tau}$, respectively.
Let $\JJ_{ho}^n$ be the collection of half-open rectangles in $\R^n$.
Let $\JJ^n_{ho, \text {rat} }$ be the collection of half-open rectangles in $\R^n$ with rational endpoints.
Then the Borel $\sigma$-algebra $\map \BB {\R^n}$ satisfies:
:$\map \BB {\R^n} = \map \sigma {\OO^n} = \map \sigma {\CC^n} = \map \sigma {\KK^n} = \map \sigma {\JJ_{ho}^n} = \map \sigma {\JJ^n_{ho, \text {rat} } }$
where $\sigma$ denotes generated $\sigma$-algebra.

fd322209-2bc2-44d4-99d8-a52e8015755b.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a semigroup.
Let $\sigma: S \to S$ be a permutation on $S$.
Let $\struct {S, \circ_\sigma}$ be the structure induced by $\sigma$ on $\circ$:
:$\forall x, y \in S: x \circ_\sigma y := \map \sigma {x \circ y}$
Then $\struct {S, \circ_\sigma}$ is not necessarily itself a semigroup.

bf32e9cc-12c5-4514-83f0-9f4700a13f19.text:
Let $D$ be an open subset of the set of complex numbers $\C$.
Let $f, g: D \to \C$ be complex-differentiable functions on $D$
Then $f + g$ is complex-differentiable in $D$, and its derivative $\paren {f + g}'$ is defined by:
:$\map {\paren {f + g}'} z = \map {f'} z + \map {g'} z$
for all $z \in D$.

6259fe7e-eb76-4973-93dd-ab17f1d6697e.text:
Let $a \in \R^d$ be a vector in Euclidean space.
Let $\delta_a \in \map {\DD'} {\R^d}$ be the Dirac delta distribution.
Let $\alpha \in \map {\CC^\infty} {\R^d}$ be a smooth real function.
Then in the distributional sense we have that:
:$\alpha \delta_a = \map \alpha a \delta_a$

c32ba24b-3377-4527-8d1c-9d247a1a6541.text:
:$\ds \int_0^\infty \frac {\sin m x} {x \paren {x^2 + a^2} } \rd x = \frac \pi {2 a^2} \paren {1 - e^{-m a} }$
where:
:$a$ is a positive real number
:$m$ is a non-negative real number.

e8df8f30-944a-4ab5-81fd-39b504f36e11.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\complement_S: \powerset S \to \powerset S$ denote the relative complement mapping on the power set of $S$.
Then $\complement_S$ is a bijection.
Thus each $T \subseteq S$ is in one-to-one correspondence with its relative complement.

4884da8e-df85-4efe-9781-1b4dcdf89c43.text:
Let $r \in \R_{> 0}$ be a positive real number.
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer.
Let $r^n$ be defined as $r$ to the power of $n$.
Then:
:$r^{-n} = \dfrac 1 {r^n}$

dc00bd0d-5f61-49c5-b34c-ff746f15375e.text:
Let $x \in \R_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive real number.
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Then:
:$\sqrt [n] {1 + x} \le 1 + \dfrac x n$

5d4996ee-f656-4826-a66b-97827c744210.text:
Let $A$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $S \subseteq A$ be a multiplicatively closed subset with $0 \notin S$.
Let $\sim$ be the relation defined on the Cartesian product $A \times S$ by:
:$\tuple {a, s} \sim \tuple {b, t} \iff \exists u \in S: a t u = b s u$
Let $A_S$ denote the quotient set $\paren {A \times S} / \sim$.
Let $\dfrac a s$ denote the equivalence class of $\tuple {a, s}$ in $\paren {A \times S} / \sim$.
Let $B$ be a ring.
Let $g: A \to B$ be a mapping such that:
:$g \sqbrk S \subseteq B^\times$
where $B^\times$ denotes the set of units of $B$.
The map $\map h {\dfrac a s} = \map g a \map g s^{-1}$ is a well defined ring homomorphism $A_S \to B$.

b21f50b9-288c-4e89-8dc6-5602d1f1ed08.text:
Let $\struct {A_R, \oplus}$ be an associative algebra over the ring $A_R$.
Then:
:$\struct {A_R, \oplus}$ has a unique multiplicative inverse for every non-zero $a \in A_R$
{{iff}}:
:$\struct {A_R, \oplus}$ is a unitary division algebra.

dd241b90-c925-40ca-8b66-ec42abc63195.text:
Let $\family {S_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of sets.
Let $\struct {P, \family {\phi_i} _{i \mathop \in I} }$ be a product of $S$ and $T$.
Then for all $i \in I$, $\phi_i$ is a surjection.

d03a31cc-1948-444e-9a89-edf4ca67487b.text:
Let $\mathbf u, \mathbf v, \mathbf w$ be vectors in the vector space $\R^n$.
Then:
:$\paren {\mathbf u + \mathbf v} \cdot \mathbf w = \mathbf u \cdot \mathbf w + \mathbf v \cdot \mathbf w$

f7aba78d-16ec-4749-aec3-4fd9a06220ba.text:
Let $\theta$ be an angle such that $\sin \theta \ne 0$.
Then:
:$\cot \theta = \dfrac {\cos \theta} {\sin \theta}$
where $\cot$, $\sin$ and $\cos$ mean cotangent, sine and cosine respectively.

300c01b6-7d94-47c0-8abf-46009b386cac.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=VIII|prop=11|body=Between two square numbers there is one mean proportional number, and the square has to the square the ratio duplicate of that which the side has to the side.}}

bdabc91b-ca12-489b-9a34-3d09fd135b8b.text:
Let $T_A = \struct {S_A, \tau_A}$ and $T_B = \struct {S_B, \tau_B}$ be topological spaces.
Let $\phi: T_A \to T_B$ be a homeomorphism.
If $T_A$ is a $T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space, then so is $T_B$.

e5cb761e-3698-4196-846f-21404aa582e7.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x^2 \paren {x^2 + a^2} } = -\frac 1 {a^2 x} - \frac 1 {a^3} \arctan \frac x a + C$

b5b19a38-769c-4a10-9fd0-a85c67469b05.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{\ne 0}$ be a non-zero integer.
Then $n$ has a finite number of divisors.

98bc2ad0-6258-495f-b350-60f765cc5d77.text:
:$\ds \prod_{n \mathop \ge 1} \dfrac {\paren {n + \alpha_1} \cdots \paren {n + \alpha_k} } {\paren {n + \beta_1} \cdots \paren {n + \beta_k} } = \dfrac {\map \Gamma {1 + \beta_1} \cdots \map \Gamma {1 + \beta_k} } {\map \Gamma {1 + \alpha_1} \cdots \map \Gamma {1 + \alpha_k} }$
where:
:$\alpha_1 + \cdots + \alpha_k = \beta_1 + \cdots + \beta_k$
:none of the $\beta$s is a negative integer.

113b4d61-c742-46f1-93ba-4dfb355cb824.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau}$ be a regular space.
Then $\struct {S, \tau}$ is also a semiregular space.

1d4f6836-0e8b-4f9f-8511-8f1d33b6dd93.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a semilattices.
Let $\preceq$ be the ordering on $S$ defined by:
:$a \preceq b \iff \paren {a \circ b} = b$
Let $T$ be a subset of $S$.
Let the ordered subset $\struct{T, \preceq \restriction_T}$ be a join semilattice.
Let $\vee$ be the binary operation on $S$ defined by:
:for all $a, b \in S$, $a \vee b$ is the join of $a$ and $b$ with respect to $\preceq$.
Then:
:$\struct{T, \vee}$ may not be a subsemilattice of $\struct {S, \circ}$.

9209fa25-d3fc-43ab-8954-3b23e5de4c97.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is twice differentiable on the open interval $\openint a b$.
Then $f$ is strictly convex on $\openint a b$ {{iff}} its second derivative $f'' > 0$ on $\openint a b$.

ce6dca9c-3ef7-4663-ac78-44db4ac135d1.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\csc a x} = \frac {-\cos a x} a + C$

a0c911f7-1986-4611-8fbd-cd240d77ac53.text:
Let $S$ be a set which is well-ordered by $\preccurlyeq$.
Let $\preccurlyeq_l$ be the lexicographic order on the set $T$ of all ordered tuples of $S$.
Then:
:$(1): \quad$ For a given $n \in \N: n > 0$, $\preccurlyeq_l$ is a well-ordering on the set $T_n$ of all ordered $n$-tuples of $S$;
:$(2): \quad \preccurlyeq_l$ is '''not''' a well-ordering on the set $T$ of ''all'' ordered tuples of $S$.

7145dae6-1c89-45e9-b1f2-925f5a4eb8d3.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=78|body=If from a straight line there be subtracted a straight line which is incommensurable in square with the whole and which with the whole makes the sum of the squares on them medial, twice the rectangle contained by them medial, and further the squares on them incommensurable with twice the rectangle contained by them, the remainder is irrational; and let it be called '''''that which produces with a medial area a medial whole'''''.}}

ed450f86-bde5-429b-b64a-24f4d32b8c7b.text:
Let $\OO^n$ be the collection of open subsets of the Euclidean space $\struct {\R^n, \tau}$.
Let $\JJ_{ho}^n$ be the collection of half-open rectangles in $\R^n$.
Then:
:$\map \sigma {\OO^n} = \map \sigma {\JJ_{ho}^n}$
where $\sigma$ denotes generated $\sigma$-algebra.

65f0462a-8a97-4e9f-9907-3e06ec77ede8.text:
Let $m, n$ be distinct finite ordinals.
Then:
:$m \in n \iff m \subseteq n$

2681422b-c79b-4902-aec5-f259e4553788.text:
Let $1$ be temporarily considered to be a prime number.
Under that consideration, the largest right-truncatable prime numbers are:
:$1 \, 979 \, 339 \, 333$
:$1 \, 979 \, 339 \, 339$

8ddd843a-5056-4f36-85e3-cb0b62321ae0.text:
Let $X$ be a non-empty set.
Let $\LL$ be the set of topologies on $X$.
Then $\struct {\LL, \subseteq}$ is a complete lattice.

c9462448-86e2-4186-b0fc-322831f138f7.text:
The usual ordering on the real numbers is a transitive relation.
Let $a, b, c \in \R$ such that $a > b$ and $b > c$.
Then:
:$a > c$

6d26dba2-b045-4061-bd38-636d39d3e87b.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $a \in S$ and $T \subseteq S$.
The following are dual statements:
:$a$ is a supremum for $T$
:$a$ is an infimum for $T$

d8745706-c4a4-434a-8b38-f2de68c316fc.text:
Let $C$ be a circle of radius $a$ whose center is at the origin of a cartesian plane.
The involute $V$ of $C$ can be described by the parametric equation:
:$\begin {cases} x = a \paren {\cos \theta + \theta \sin \theta} \\ y = a \paren {\sin \theta - \theta \cos \theta} \end {cases}$

ed6233fd-a731-4520-b882-ed73b785d00b.text:
Let $\mathbf a$ be a cardinal.
Then:
: $\mathbf 0 \mathbf a = \mathbf 0$
where $\mathbf 0 \mathbf a$ denotes the product of the (cardinal) zero and $\mathbf a$.
That is, $\mathbf 0$ is the zero element of the product operation on cardinals.

22c96ec9-fd27-4657-89b7-e577c92685ac.text:
Let $\struct {R, \norm {\,\cdot\,}}$ be a normed division ring.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a sequence in $R$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be convergent in the norm $\norm {\,\cdot\,}$ to the following limit:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n = l$
Then $\sequence {x_n}$ is bounded.

1d230d3d-9cf4-48de-9b18-7e636797aea8.text:
Let $z \in \C$ be a complex number.
Let $\overline z$ denote the complex conjugate of $z$.
Then:
: $\overline {z^2} = \left({\overline z}\right)^2$

a4c45186-5595-4daf-93a9-e2fe97082613.text:
The roots of the polynomial:
:$z^4 + 81$
are:
:$\set {3 \cis 45 \degrees, 3 \cis 135 \degrees, 3 \cis 225 \degrees, 3 \cis 315 \degrees}$

7768b1fc-b840-49e0-b620-679ef1236495.text:
Let $\N_{> 0}$ be the $1$-based natural numbers.
Let $<$ be the strict ordering on $\N_{>0}$.
Then $<$ is a transitive relation.

98227ddf-5c0b-4e37-9d3d-eed3dc5b0ceb.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a bounded below algebraic lattice.
Let $P = \struct {T, \precsim}$ be a continuous lattice subframe of $L$.
Then $P$ is algebraic lattice.

98ff4d18-f738-442b-be65-9eaff10eeede.text:
Let $L / K$ be a finite field extension.
Then $L / K$ is algebraic.

4b1f5bc7-909d-4d17-9ae5-165b9d0af669.text:
:$\cosh^3 x = \dfrac {\cosh 3 x + 3 \cosh x} 4$
where $\cosh$ denotes hyperbolic cosine.

fda5c08c-68d8-41ec-917f-241a81589170.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Let $\RR$ be a relation on $G$.
Let $\RR$ be compatible with $\circ$.
Let $\QQ = \complement_{G \times G} \RR$, so that:
:$\forall a, b \in G: a \mathrel \QQ b \iff \neg \paren {a \mathrel \RR b}$
Then $\QQ$ is a relation compatible with $\circ$.

088161fd-558b-4917-a936-a158e0a85359.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a scattered topological space.
Then $T$ is also a $T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space.

99d00e93-6de0-46a9-9ab9-91dcc1eab11c.text:
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\family {A_\alpha}_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be a indexed family of subsets of a set $S$.
Let $B \subseteq S$.
Then:
:$\ds \map {\bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in I} } {A_\alpha \cap B} = \paren {\bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in I} A_\alpha} \cap B$
where $\ds \bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in I} A_\alpha$ denotes the union of $\family {A_\alpha}_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$.

e27de8da-7ed2-420f-8fb8-a81ddfef6cc8.text:
Let $K / F$ be a finite field extension of degree $2^m$.
Let $\alpha \in K$ be algebraic over $F$ with degree $3$.
Then $\alpha \notin K$.

d21a5bde-26f8-454f-a97e-06bd26ca51ef.text:
Let $V$ denote the universal class.
Then $V$ is a proper class.

9ffd30d7-7d64-4440-91d6-4bd37c5c5fff.text:
Let $\struct {R_1, +_1, \circ_1}$ and $\struct {R_2, +_2, \circ_2}$ be rings.
The image of a ring homomorphism $\phi: R_1 \to R_2$ is a subring of $R_2$.

b4b4afd8-6d35-4871-96b1-f0ca01117a3d.text:
Let $I$ be an indexing set with infinite cardinality.
Let $\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be a family of topological spaces indexed by $I$.
Let $\ds \struct {S, \tau} = \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be the product space of $\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$.
Let each of $\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be weakly locally compact-compact.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $\struct {S, \tau}$ is also weakly locally compact.

8a50eb3c-8797-4928-8905-948648027fd0.text:
Let $a, b \in \R$ such that $a \ne b$.
Then
:$-\map \sgn {\dfrac {b - a} {b + a} } = \map \sgn {a^2 - b^2} = -\map \sgn {\dfrac {b + a} {b - a} }$
where $\sgn$ denotes the signum of a real number.

87c2c75a-95e3-4567-a86e-e906f274c9ff.text:
Let $S$ be the subset of the set of real numbers $\R$ defined as:
:$S = \set {\dfrac {n - 1} n: n \in \Z_{>0} }$
$S$ is bounded above with supremum $1$.
$S$ has no greatest element.

bfdf75d1-a7b6-4ecb-8bf1-411e6a22c99b.text:
Let $\map P n$ be a propositional function depending on $n \in \N$.
If:
:$(1): \quad \map P n$ is true for all $n \le d$ for some $d \in \N$
:$(2): \quad \forall m \in \N: \paren {\forall k \in \N, m \le k < m + d: \map P k} \implies \map P {m + d}$
then $\map P n$ is true for all $n \in \N$.

63867c3c-c840-46fe-afd8-65bb463bc003.text:
Let $S$ be the set of vectors in $3$ dimensional Euclidean space.
Let $\times$ denote the vector cross product on $S$.
Then $\struct {S, \times}$ is a Lie algebra.

2e61cb5c-b138-427d-a8e5-898c3bbf5cc1.text:
Let $x$ and $y$ be ordinals.
Let $x > 1$ and $y > 0$.
Then there exist unique finite sequences of ordinals:
:$\sequence {a_i}, \sequence {b_i}$
both of unique length $n$ such that:
:$(1): \quad \sequence {a_i}$ is a strictly decreasing sequence for $1 \le i \le n$
:$(2): \quad 0 < b_i < x$ for all $1 \le i \le n$
:$(3): \quad \ds y = \sum_{i \mathop = 1}^n x^{a_i} b_i$

e4777835-0ff0-4ba5-b556-42394fc8403d.text:
Let $\sequence {b_n}$ be a sequence in $\R$.
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ be a sequence whose terms are defined as:
:$a_k = b_k - b_{k - 1}$
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{k \mathop = m}^n a_k = b_n - b_{m - 1}$

a5dc219b-96d1-4438-9bdf-8bed7378eb95.text:
Let $\RR$ be a congruence relation on a group $\struct {G, \circ}$.
Then the quotient structure $\struct {G / \RR, \circ_\RR}$ is a group.

51f0c9ca-82f2-4812-96d7-ad30de5f3364.text:
Let $\mu_c: \R \to \R$ be the Heaviside step function:
:$\map {\mu_c} x = \begin {cases}
0 & : x < c \\
1 & : x > c \\
\text {arbitrary} & : x = c
\end {cases}$
Then $\mu_c$ is continuous at every point of $\R$ except at $c$.

3feb85a4-9866-4eff-8d43-d85c9d2f9382.text:
Let $\struct {S, \RR}$ be a relational structure such that $\RR$ is a preordering.
Let $\sim$ be the relation induced by $\RR$:
:$x \sim y$ {{iff}} $x \precsim y$ and $y \precsim x$.
Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.

a48bd557-daf7-4847-b050-be8ede62ec73.text:
Let $G$ be a group, and let $H$ be a normal subgroup of $G$.
Let $G / H$ be the quotient group of $G$ by $H$.
The order of $a H \in G / H$ divides the order of $a \in G$.

2ed180a2-c314-4624-b248-7f22fe9e7839.text:
Let $\cos$ be the cosine function.
Then:
:$\cos x$ is absolutely convergent for all $x \in \R$.

a12858c6-8e2c-48c1-9c09-6f76f97dc77f.text:
Let $\struct {U_\C, \times}$ be the group of Gaussian integer units under complex multiplication.
Let $\struct {\Z'_5, \times_5}$ be the multiplicative group of reduced residues modulo $5$.
Then $\struct {U_\C, \times}$ and $\struct {\Z'_5, \times_5}$ are isomorphic algebraic structures.

ea150a82-db82-4117-976a-2f3d28be9955.text:
Let $S$ be a set and let $\PP$ be a partition on $S$ which is not the (trivial) partition of singletons.
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the partition space whose basis is $\PP$.
Then $T$ is not a $T_2$ (Hausdorff) space.

5d8f699e-5e54-4303-b870-f1a966db1e45.text:
Let $G$ be a cyclic group with generator $g$.
Let $H$ be a group.
Let $\phi: G \to H$ be a (group) homomorphism.
Let $\Img G$ denote the homomorphic image of $G$ under $\phi$.
Then $\Img G$ is a cyclic group with generator $\map \phi g$.
That is:
:$\phi \sqbrk {\gen g} = \gen {\map \phi g}$

67334e8b-4c2b-4fea-b5cc-d52bf9668d0a.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \set {\O, S} }$ be an indiscrete topological space.
Let $H \subseteq S$.
Then:
:$\map \partial {\partial H} = \O$
where $\partial H$ denotes the boundary of $H$.

9382776e-a1dd-4d87-96e5-b0e1cff2f7d6.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times S$ be a transitive relation on $S$.
Let $T \subseteq S$ be a subset of $S$.
Let $\RR {\restriction_T} \subseteq T \times T$ be the restriction of $\RR$ to $T$.
Then $\RR {\restriction_T}$ is a transitive relation on $T$.

dcb8dc1e-04d1-47e0-9a9f-bb0584d51ebf.text:
Let $N$ be a class which is closed under a progressing mapping $g$.
Let $b$ be an element of $N$ such that $N$ is minimally closed under $g$ with respect to $b$.
$g$ has no fixed point, unless possibly the greatest element, if there is one.

60465cb2-3fc8-4dcc-b9f1-f6184058d63f.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Then:
:$\struct {G, \circ} \le \struct {G, \circ}$
That is, a group is always a subgroup of itself.

51722f32-eced-4e89-ac81-674e8a124ce0.text:
Let $\struct {T, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $H \subseteq T$ be a subset of $T$.
Let $\map \cl H$ denote the closure of $H$.
Let $x \in \map \cl H$ be an isolated point of $\map \cl H$.
Then $x$ is also an isolated point of $H$.

5a6283d4-e38b-4348-8dd7-ea3221027eb8.text:
Let $F$ be a mapping.
Let $A$ be a small class.
Then the restriction $F {\restriction_A}$ is a small class.

ee577c0b-74bd-4060-a8d5-d73682fc49f7.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a totally bounded metric space.
Then $M$ is bounded.

5b1b0ce1-25d1-4c16-87e2-c3913ee8bdc0.text:
Let $F_n$ be the $n$th Fibonacci number.
Then:
:$F_{n + i} F_{n + j} - F_n F_{n + i + j} = \paren {-1}^n F_i F_j$

f6ee0ff2-37bc-4228-b089-9f3c452021ef.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be a periodic real function whose period is $2 \pi$.
Let $\SS$ denote the unit circle whose center is at the origin of the Cartesian plane $\R^2$.
Let $p: \R \to \SS$ be the mapping defined as:
:$\forall x \in \R: \map p x = \tuple {\cos x, \sin x}$
Let $f': \SS \to \R$ be the well-defined real-valued function such that:
:$f = f' \circ p$
where $f' \circ p$ denotes the composition of $f'$ with $p$.
Then $f$ is continuous {{iff}} $f'$ is continuous.

4c2540b9-74a2-4432-8298-47b0520a211a.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=XI|prop=2|body=If two straight lines cut one another, they are in one plane, and every triangle is in one plane.}}

7b80acb5-67a5-470b-a785-60c158bd8c77.text: The finite chain and union of compositions definitions of '''transitive closure''' are equivalent.

78c4849d-cda1-4bb2-8651-4c19586303e3.text:
Let $x \in \R$.
Let $\arctan x$ be the arctangent of $x$.
Then:
:$\dfrac {\map \d {\arctan x} } {\d x} = \dfrac 1 {1 + x^2}$

1fa35daa-b966-492d-8eb1-921890a15b75.text: :$\ds \int x \arccot \frac x a \rd x = \frac {x^2 + a^2} 2 \arccot \frac x a + \frac {a x} 2 + C$

4aa57c84-7ae3-424d-ae8e-33095d82fac1.text:
Let $R$ be a division ring.
Let $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_1: R 	o \R_{\ge 0}$ and $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_2: R 	o \R_{\ge 0}$ be norms on $R$.
Let $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_1$ and $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_2$ satisfy:
:for all sequences $\sequence {x_n}$ in $R:\sequence {x_n}$ is a null sequence in $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_1  \iff \sequence {x_n}$ is a null sequence in $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_2$ 
Then $ orall x \in R$:
:$
orm x_1 < 1 \iff 
orm x_2 < 1$

9819c2a8-89d1-44e1-b458-57ee8e4cc307.text:
Let $\struct {G_1, \circ_1}$ and $\struct {G_2, \circ_2}$ be groups with identity elements $e_1$ and $e_2$ respectively.
Let $\struct {G_1 \times G_2, \circ}$ be the group direct product of $\struct {G_1, \circ_1}$ and $\struct {G_2, \circ_2}$
Let:
:$\pr_1: \struct {G_1 \times G_2, \circ} \to \struct {G_1, \circ_1}$ be the first projection from $\struct {G_1 \times G_2, \circ}$ to $\struct {G_1, \circ_1}$
:$\pr_2: \struct {G_1 \times G_2, \circ} \to \struct {G_2, \circ_2}$ be the second projection from $\struct {G_1 \times G_2, \circ}$ to $\struct {G_2, \circ_2}$.
Let:
:$\inj_1: \struct {G_1, \circ_1} \to \struct {G_1 \times G_2, \circ}$ be the canonical injection from $\struct {G_1, \circ_1}$ to $\struct {G_1 \times G_2, \circ}$
:$\inj_2: \struct {G_2, \circ_2} \to \struct {G_1 \times G_2, \circ}$ be the canonical injection from $\struct {G_2, \circ_2}$ to $\struct {G_1 \times G_2, \circ}$.
Then:
:$(1): \quad \Img {\inj_1} = \map \ker {\pr_2}$
:$(2): \quad \Img {\inj_2} = \map \ker {\pr_1}$
That is:
:the image of the (first) canonical injection is the kernel of the second projection
:the image of the (second) canonical injection is the kernel of the first projection.

fdbfe68d-3c48-473d-b6c6-7ea2a8530530.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}$ be metric spaces.
Let $f: A_1 \to A_2$ be a mapping from $A_1$ to $A_2$.
Let $a \in A_1$ be a point in $A_1$.
Let $\BB_{\map f a}$ be a basis for the neighborhood system at $\map f a$.
$f$ is continuous at $a$ with respect to the metrics $d_1$ and $d_2$ {{iff}}:
:for each neighborhood $N$ in $\BB_{\map f a}$, $f^{-1} \sqbrk N$ is a neighborhood of $a$.

fefa9b83-cf7d-4713-be90-ad810c2b1839.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book = VIII|prop = 4|body = Given as many ratios as we please in least numbers, to find numbers in continued proportion which are the least in the given ratios.}}

03857199-6517-436e-880c-373a38f4a5d0.text:
The ring of Gaussian integers:
:$\struct {\Z \sqbrk i, +, \times}$
forms a principal ideal domain.

6a07cb76-4e61-43ec-9d92-4757b4b1ae1a.text:
Let $f$ be a real function defined on a closed interval $\closedint a b$, $a < b$. 
Let $f$ be a piecewise continuous function with improper integrals.
Then $f$ may not be piecewise continuous and bounded on $\closedint a b$.

9300c80b-e356-4178-8744-e83a5c95cd84.text:
Let $\mathbb F$ be one of the standard number sets: $\N, \Z, \Q, \R$ and $\C$.
Then:
:$\forall x, y, z \in \mathbb F: x \times \paren {y \times z} = \paren {x \times y} \times z$
That is, the operation of multiplication on the standard number sets is associative.

a8da7c1e-2689-43b2-939b-cb19c1ef6dbf.text:
Let $H$ be the Heaviside step function.
Let $\omega \in \R : \omega \ne 0$.
Let $\ds \map f x = \map H x \frac {\map \sin {\omega x}} \omega$.
Let $T_f$ be the distribution associated with $f$.
Then, in the distributional sense, $T_f$ is the fundamental solution of
:$\paren {\dfrac {\d^2}{\d x^2} + \omega^2} T_f = \delta$

20adda32-abb3-4ff3-a6e5-9db483d3cf72.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $\tilde M = \struct {\tilde A, \tilde d}$ be a completion of $\struct {A, d}$.
Then:
:$\tilde M = \struct {\tilde A, \tilde d}$ is unique up to isometry.
That is, if $\struct {\hat A, \hat d}$ is another completion of $\struct {A, d}$, then there is a bijection $\tau: \tilde A \leftrightarrow \hat A$ such that:
:$(1): \quad \tau$ restricts to the identity on $x$:
:::: $\forall x \in A : \map \tau x = x$
:$(2): \quad \tau$ preserves metrics:
:::: $\forall x_1, x_2 \in A : \map {\hat d} {\map \tau {x_1}, \map \tau {x_2} } = \map {\tilde d} {x_1, x_2}$

4e6043c7-399d-405e-9ac5-b9e784bdcba4.text:
:$\ds \int e^x \rd x = e^x + C$
where $C$ is an arbitrary constant.

9ecd79f2-ef9c-4b0d-a16d-bba00c653067.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number such that $x \ge 0$.
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer such that $n < 0$.
Then there always exists a unique $y \in \R: \paren {y \ge 0} \land \paren {y^n = x}$.

2384b41e-1b8d-456c-85de-f755b1396953.text:
The set difference between a set and the empty set is the set itself:
:$S \setminus \O = S$

b7dea061-1ae3-42e9-9598-bbbe1752b6d5.text:
Let $\norm {\,\cdot\,}_p$ be the $p$-adic norm on the rationals $\Q$ for some prime number $p$.
Let $x \in \Q$ such that $\norm x_p \le 1$.
Then for all $i \in \N$ there exists $\alpha \in \Z$ such that:
:$\norm {x - \alpha}_p \le p^{-i}$

bb6174ec-7456-482e-afeb-de19e4b20ed9.text:
The volume $V$ of a sphere of radius $r$ is given by:
:$V = \dfrac {4 \pi r^3} 3$

a5011277-b98b-48d2-b923-f4f010bda77c.text: A normal $\NN$ to a circle $\CC$ passes through the center of $\CC$.

e3433ef3-a52b-461f-9fd6-24b8b65f3f67.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be a principal ideal domain.
Let $S = \set {a_1, a_2, \dotsc, a_n}$ be a set of non-zero elements of $D$.
Let $y$ be a greatest common divisor of $S$.
Then $y$ is expressible in the form:
:$y = d_1 a_1 + d_2 a_2 + \dotsb + d_n a_n$
where $d_1, d_2, \dotsc, d_n \in D$.

fbda46d8-5b9b-488f-b051-61ccfba196c5.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a semigroup.
Let $x, y, z \in S$.
Let $x$ commute with both $y$ and $z$.
Then $x$ commutes with $y \circ z$.
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a semigroup.
Let $\sequence {a_k}_{1 \mathop \le k \mathop \le n}$ be a sequence of terms of $S$.
Let $b \in S$ such that $b$ commutes with $a_k$ for each $k \in \closedint 1 n$.
Then $b$ commutes with $a_1 \circ \cdots \circ a_n$.

f94f4ed9-43da-40f4-824e-6e77c1c2fc4e.text:
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer such that $n \ge 48$.
Then there exists a prime number $p$ such that $n < p < \dfrac {9 n} 8$.

168b182f-6178-421e-9fe6-5954a136828a.text:
Let $\left({S, \vee_1, \wedge_1, \preceq_1}\right)$ and $\left({T, \vee_2, \wedge_2, \preceq_2}\right)$ be complete lattices.
Let $f: S \to T$ be an increasing mapping.
Let $\left({D, \precsim}\right)$ be a directed set.
Let $N: D \to S$ be a Moore-Smith sequence in $S$.
Let $j \in D$.
Then $f\left({\inf\left({N\left[{\precsim \left({j}\right)}\right]}\right)}\right) \preceq_2 \inf \left({\left({f \circ N}\right)\left[{\precsim \left({j}\right)}\right]}\right)$

288ce337-95cc-45d8-8177-7ea983f2c559.text:
Let $\tuple {m_1, m_2}$ be a Thabit pair such that $m_1 < m_2$.
Then $m_1$ is a tetrahedral number.

b27dfd5e-32cc-4e2c-8874-14dc8e9981a9.text:
Let $T$ be a topological space.
Let $\mathbb H$ be a set of subsets of $T$.
That is, let $\mathbb H \subseteq \powerset T$ where $\powerset T$ is the power set of $T$.
Then:
:$\ds \bigcup_{H \mathop \in \mathbb H} H^e \subseteq \paren {\bigcap_{H \mathop \in \mathbb H} H}^e$
where $H^e$ denotes the exterior of $H$.

0a5e3b2f-90c6-4662-8773-0a47d0246b11.text:
Let $\mathbf a$ and $\mathbf b$ be cardinals.
Then:
: $\mathbf a \le \mathbf b \iff \exists \mathbf c: \mathbf a + \mathbf c = \mathbf b$
where $\mathbf c$ is also a cardinal.

197733cb-98d5-4b6d-bc3b-175a29766e8c.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a bounded below up-complete lattice.
Let $\map {\mathit {Ids} } L$ be the set of all ideals in $L$.
Let $P = \struct {\map {\mathit {Ids} } L, \precsim}$ be an ordered set where $\mathord \precsim = \subseteq \restriction_{\map {\mathit {Ids} } L \times \map {\mathit {Ids} } L}$
Let $f: \map {\mathit {Ids} } L \to S$ be a mapping such that
:$\forall I \in \map {\mathit {Ids} } L: f \sqbrk I = \sup I$
Let $f$ be an upper adjoint of a Galois connection.
Then $L$ is continuous.

01d5fb8d-d999-4aa3-ac71-c9da21ea04c7.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Then the set $\Inn G$ of all inner automorphisms of $G$ forms a normal subgroup of the automorphism group $\Aut G$ of $G$:
:$\Inn G \le \Aut G$

42e569f2-6221-48f4-adba-00ca9bd7d42a.text:
Let $z_1 := r_1 e^{i \theta_1}, z_2 := r_2 e^{i \theta_2} \in \C$ be complex numbers expressed in exponential form.
Then:
:$z_1 \times z_2 = r_1 r_2 \map \sin {\theta_2 - \theta_1}$
where $z_1 \times z_2$ denotes the dot product of $z_1$ and $z_2$.

2bf7347f-5b7a-444b-8153-19945740e095.text:
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times T$ be a relation which is many-to-one.
Then the composites (both ways) of $\RR$ and its inverse $\RR^{-1}$, that is, both $\RR^{-1} \circ \RR$ and $\RR \circ \RR^{-1}$, are transitive.

8b92f70d-0def-4efd-ad43-e4f83e34a816.text:
Let $n$ be an ordinal.
Let $m \in n$.
Then $m$ is also an ordinal.

0433e547-68a8-4240-974b-892d31e86742.text:
Let $V$ be a vector space over a field $F$.
Let $\BB$ be a generator for $V$ containing $m$ elements.
Then:
:$\map {\dim_F} V \le m$
where $\map {\dim_F} V$ is the dimension of $V$.

d5f46ad5-7050-44f4-87cf-17be80cd931e.text:
:$\cos i = \dfrac e 2 + \dfrac 1 {2 e}$
where $\cos$ denotes the complex cosine function and $i$ is the imaginary unit.

78c54a9f-d40d-42f4-a183-bb6bd548bb55.text:
Let $\mathbf A$ and $\mathbf B$ be square matrices of order $n$.
Let $\mathbf A \mathbf B$ be the (conventional) matrix product of $\mathbf A$ and $\mathbf B$.
Then:
:$\ds \map \tr {\mathbf A \mathbf B} = \sum_{i \mathop = 1}^n \sum_{j \mathop = 1}^n a_{i j} b_{j i}$
where $\map \tr {\mathbf A \mathbf B}$ denotes the trace of $\mathbf A \mathbf B$.
Using the Einstein summation convention, this can be expressed as:
:$\map \tr {\mathbf A \mathbf B} = a_{i j} b_{j i}$

b1fa1947-6bef-47f1-91a5-05d38d302726.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $U$ be an upper bound for $S$.
Let $\left({T, \preceq}\right)$ be a subset of $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$.
Then $U$ is an upper bound for $T$.

636ee4d4-5196-4871-8c0a-8461bc4e314a.text:
Let $K$ be a ring. 
Let $A$ be a symmetric matrix over $K$.
Let $\lambda_1, \lambda_2$ be distinct eigenvalues of $A$.
Let $\mathbf v_1, \mathbf v_2$ be eigenvectors of $A$ corresponding to the eigenvalues $\lambda_1$ and $\lambda_2$ respectively.
Let $\innerprod \cdot \cdot$ be the dot product on $K$. 
{{explain|The existing definitions of dot product are not presented in terms of the inner product. Recommend either using the conventional definitions of dot product, or explicitly linking to the result which explains this. Perhaps preferable to bypass the inner product notation altogether, as it is often the case that linear algebra at this level is covered before inner product spaces are encountered at all. This would ensure accessibility to those at that more basic level.}}
Then $\mathbf v_1$ and $\mathbf v_2$ are orthogonal with respect to $\innerprod \cdot \cdot$.

8dd6adc5-0aa4-47a4-8b26-ba51dbe81828.text:
Let $u$ be a differentiable real function of $x$.
Then:
:$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {\tanh u} = \sech^2 u \dfrac {\d u} {\d x}$
where $\tanh$ is the hyperbolic tangent and $\sech$ is the hyperbolic secant.

a85abf58-13d4-4137-8960-02ca691565cc.text: :$\forall x, w \in \R, y, z \in \R_{\ne 0}: \dfrac x y \times \dfrac w z = \dfrac {x \times w} {y \times z}$

8c5edbba-ea07-43e3-abf6-2a728cf3f3e6.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let each filter on $S$ have a limit point in $S$.
Then each ultrafilter on $S$ converges to a point in $S$.

ec2d28ec-df98-46a9-9d79-05f7d0d5b9ac.text:
Let $n \in \N$ be a natural number such that $n \ge 2$.
Let $\N_n$ be defined as:
:$\N_n := \set {1, 2, \dotsc, n}$
Let $A_n = \set {a_1, a_2, \dotsc, a_n} \subseteq \Z$ be a set of $n$ integers.
From Expression for Integers as Powers of Same Primes, let:
:$\ds \forall i \in \N_n: a_i = \prod_{p_j \mathop \in T} {p_j}^{e_{i j} }$
where:
:$T = \set {p_j: j \in \N_r}$
such that:
:$\forall j \in \N_{r - 1}: p_j < p_{j - 1}$
:$\forall j \in \N_r: \exists i \in \N_n: p_j \divides a_i$
where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.
Then:
:$\ds \map \lcm {A_n} = \prod_{j \mathop \in \N_r} {p_j}^{\max \set {e_{i j}: \, i \in \N_n} }$
where $\map \lcm {A_n}$ denotes the greatest common divisor of $a_1, a_2, \dotsc, a_n$.

70bec157-283a-4e98-b72e-e36479141b50.text:
Let $p$ be an odd prime.
Let $a \in \Z$.
Let $\paren {\dfrac a p}$ be the Legendre symbol::
:$\paren {\dfrac a p} := a^{\paren {\frac {p - 1} 2} } \pmod p$

7aae51d9-1446-4807-8eba-8f3182ae2928.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \times}$ be a ring.
Let $\map {\mathrm {Ann} } R$ be the annihilator of $R$.
Then $0 \in \map {\mathrm {Ann} } R$.

42a2d8b7-5fde-49f3-b3f9-c2cd496875fd.text: The set of integers under multiplication $\struct {\Z, \times}$ is a monoid.

7ee841ed-8e6b-4047-9082-5db7a55f9209.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is defined on a real interval $I$.
{{TFAE|def = Convex Real Function}}

6234f88d-6075-40ec-9bb6-7db34b00fe57.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be an integral domain whose zero is $0_D$.
Let $\struct {D \sqbrk X, \oplus, \odot}$ be the ring of polynomial forms over $D$ in the indeterminate $X$.
Then $\struct {D \sqbrk X, \oplus, \odot}$ is an integral domain.

f5720052-5dbd-4088-b495-a4a35f74d275.text:
Let $\sequence {r_k}_{0 \mathop \le k \mathop \le n}$ be a strictly increasing finite sequence of natural numbers.
Let:
:$\forall k \in \closedint 1 n: A_k := \closedint {r_{k - 1} + 1} {r_k}$
Then:
:$\set {A_k: k \in \closedint 1 n}$ is a partition of $\closedint {r_0 + 1} {r_n}$.

c3f9ff1f-9384-4c2f-b0d0-71f440093f5e.text:
Let $T_1$ be a compact space.
Let $T_2$ be a Hausdorff space.
Let $f: T_1 \to T_2$ be a continuous injection.
Then $f$ determines a homeomorphism from $T_1$ to $f \sqbrk {T_1}$.
That is, $f$ is an embedding of $T_1$ into $T_2$.

ec739c0b-d535-4c77-b34e-a283e6f5ca4f.text:
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{j \mathop = 0}^n j \binom n j = n 2^{n - 1}$
where $\dbinom n k$ denotes a binomial coefficient.
That is:
:$1 \dbinom n 1 + 2 \dbinom n 2 + 3 \dbinom n 3 + \dotsb + n \dbinom n n = n 2^{n - 1}$

8eeae475-29b0-47ab-b430-0f15fce01bd8.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a semigroup.
Let $e_R \in S$  be a right identity of $S$.
Let $a \in S$ such that:
:$\exists b \in S: a \circ b = e_R$
Then $a$ is right cancellable in $\struct {S, \circ}$.

e6e18325-78c3-43ce-87d3-80545226291e.text:
Let $S$ be a set on which $\tau_1$ and $\tau_2$ are topologies such that:
:$\tau_1 \subseteq \tau_2$
that is, such that $\tau_2$ is an expansion of $\tau_1$.
Let $I_X: \struct {S, \tau_1} \to \struct {S, \tau_2}$ be the identity mapping from $\struct {S, \tau_1}$ to $\struct {S, \tau_2}$.
Then $I_S$ is closed.

ef61fc7d-32e4-422a-92f0-255384c0b997.text: The set of non-zero complex numbers is closed under multiplication.

5198428c-463c-47bc-b113-7411cf152c61.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $\R$ denote the real numbers.
Let $f: M \to \R$ and $g: M \to \R$ be real-valued functions from $M$ to $\R$ which are continuous on $M$.
Then:
:$f g$ is ‎continuous on $M$.

34e355cd-5529-4c83-9c68-00cd376905ea.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\mathbb T$ be the set of all topologies on $S$.
Let $\le$ be the relation on $\mathbb T$ defined as:
:$\forall \tau_1, \tau_2 \in \mathbb T: \tau_1 \le \tau_2$ {{iff}} $\tau_1$ is coarser than $\tau_2$.
Then $\le$ is a partial ordering on $\mathbb T$.

e7bd0622-21d4-49f1-bfe2-4658900ad887.text:
Let $\left({S, \vee, \preceq}\right)$ be a bounded below join semilattice.
Then
:$\preceq$ is auxiliary relation.

08db8f0c-d150-407e-81c2-227a3185341b.text:
Let $\struct {B, \vee, \wedge, \neg, \bot, \top}$ be a Boolean algebra.
Let $J \subseteq B$ have the finite join property.
Let $z \in B$.
Then either $J \vee z$ or $J \vee \neg z$ also has the finite join property.

b23177ab-ce7f-40b2-8e95-ff57f4ead528.text:
Let $T_A = \struct {A, \tau_A}$ and $T_B = \struct {B, \tau_B}$ be topological spaces.
Let $\phi: T_A \to T_B$ be a continuous mapping.
If $T_A$ is a first-countable space, then it does not necessarily follow that $T_B$ is also first-countable.

84942f44-cec6-4be2-a4c1-aa89b1c6f4c0.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $R = \struct {T, \preceq'}$ be an ordered subset of $L$.
Let $X \subseteq T$ such that
:$X$ admits an infimum in $L$.
Then $\inf_L X \in T$ {{iff}}
:$X$ admits an infimum in $R$ and $\inf_R X = \inf_L X$

3957033c-ade5-4ca4-9879-b4c277c3b082.text: :$g h = e \implies h = g^{-1}$ and $g = h^{-1}$

393aaeca-2d82-4181-ac7a-ea3ff494fc7f.text:
Let $a, b$ be real numbers with $a < b$.
Let $f : \closedint a b \to \R$ be a function of bounded variation.
Let $V_f$ be the total variation of $f$ on $\closedint a b$.
Then: 
:$V_f \ge 0$
with equality {{iff}} $f$ is constant.

24adc293-48e0-43d2-8c9c-ce82c1f43dfe.text:
Let $I$ be a finite set.
The number of characteristic functions on $I$ is:
:$2^{\card I}$ 
where $\card I$ denotes the cardinality of $I$.

36f95c5b-5cb3-4534-833f-0e26f9fe9290.text:
Let $f$ be a real function defined on an interval $I$.
Let $a$ be a point in $I$ where $f$ is left-hand differentiable.
Then $f$ is left-continuous at $a$.

a9133ade-677a-45ca-b631-c7cf7204a17d.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_{a, b} }$ be a modified Fort space.
Let $A \subseteq S$ be both closed and open in $T$.
If $a \in A$, then $b \in A$ as well.
That is, any clopen set of $T$ must contain '''both''' or '''neither''' of $a$ and $b$.

93774c24-0236-407a-a796-550e663f848b.text:
Let $x$ be a irrational number. 
Let $y$ be a non-zero rational number.
Then: 
:$\dfrac x y$
is irrational.

3db28cdf-5697-4433-b68b-6dfd8aa7417a.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be a real function.
Let $f$ be differentiable on all of $\R$.
Then if $f$ is periodic with period $L$, then its derivative is also periodic with period $L$.

9c27a1dc-f54e-4574-a562-20be636ca10b.text:
Let $\Gamma$ denote the gamma function.
Then:
:$\forall z \notin \Z: \paren {-z}! \, \map \Gamma z = \dfrac \pi {\map \sin {\pi z} }$

70e85284-f91f-4eff-9636-bd6d5485b59f.text:
The positive square root function:
:$t \mapsto \sqrt t$
is of exponential order $\epsilon$ for any  $\epsilon > 0$ arbitrarily small in magnitude.

2be017ab-a148-4c79-a1a2-f8c22d64fe8f.text:
Let $x$, $y$, and $z$ be ordinals.
Then:
:$\paren {x^y}^z = x^{y \mathop \times z}$

9bfa4a14-b1b9-48d5-aa98-0bbc8f9f4386.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a meet semilattice.
Let $f: S \times S \to S$ be a mapping such that:
:$\forall s, t \in S: \map f {s, t} = s \wedge t$
Then:
:$f$ is increasing as a mapping from the simple order product $\struct {S \times S, \precsim}$ of $\struct {S, \preceq}$ and $\struct {S, \preceq}$ into $\struct {S, \preceq}$.

f236278b-0cc3-4c6b-97aa-65c4874f8a25.text:
Let $a, b, c, d \in \R$ such that $a > b$ and $c > d$.
Let $b > 0$ and $d > 0$.
Then $a c > b d$.
If $b < 0$ or $d < 0$ the inequality does not hold.

c7867662-07a6-46e8-a16d-29bd1b233734.text: :$\ds \int \frac {x^2 \rd x} {\sqrt {x^2 + a^2} } = \frac {x \sqrt {x^2 + a^2} } 2 - \frac {a^2} 2 \sinh^{-1} \frac x a + C$

c65103f5-e85f-47fc-865b-145538b9ae91.text:
Let $L / K$ be a normal extension.
Let $\Gal {L / K}$ be the Galois group of $L / K$.
Then $\Gal {L / K}$ forms a group under the operation of composition of mappings.

0d3f926a-98be-45f9-bcd7-1125c59c67a4.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring which is not null.
Let $0$ be the ring zero of $R$.
Then $0$ is not a cancellable element for the ring product $\circ$.

c18f9e5f-09f7-4a5a-adea-0d07cc10c8e0.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\paren {a x + b} \paren {p x + q} } = \frac 1 {b p - a q} \ln \size {\frac {p x + q} {a x + b} } + C$

e5493568-6d85-4955-8aa7-4b168f6c3a35.text:
Let $x$ and $y$ be ordinals.
Then:
:$x \in \aleph_y \iff \left|{ x }\right| \in \aleph_y$ where $\aleph$ denotes the aleph mapping.

413eeb54-9c3f-4d67-b506-0b3b27d894e6.text:
Let $x \in \R$.
Let $\arccot x$ be the arccotangent of $x$.
Then:
:$\dfrac {\map \d {\arccot x} } {\d x} = \dfrac {-1} {1 + x^2}$

2887d273-19aa-4941-93a5-8a2900f1fe4f.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $T^*_p = \struct {S^*_p, \tau^*_p}$ be the closed extension space of $T$.
Then $T^*_p$ is a $T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space {{iff}} $T$ is.

8c8a56e0-719f-4927-89bc-609534070c79.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma}$ be a measurable space.
Then the null measure $\mu$ on $\struct {X, \Sigma}$ is a measure.

5c2001f4-df18-4292-8e77-960031f3f1dc.text:
{{refactor|three theorems: $\laptrans {e^{a t} }$ for $a \in \R$; $\laptrans {e^{i b t} }$ for $b \in \R$; $\laptrans {e^{\psi t} }$ for $\psi \in \C$
In progress: this page has been renamed, and a master page created. The pages for the second two instances need to be written. In due course, unless someone gets there before me.}} Let $\laptrans f$ denote the Laplace transform of a function $f$. Let $e^x$ be the real exponential. Then: :$\map {\laptrans {e^{a t} } } s = \dfrac 1 {s - a}$ where $a \in \R$ is constant, and $\map \Re s > \map \Re a$.

9b327f16-ebc2-417e-8d10-328d6f939e57.text:
Let $\left({S, *}\right)$ be a $B$-algebra.
Let $\left({S, \circ}\right)$ be the group described on $B$-Algebra Induces Group.
Let $\left({S, *'}\right)$ be the $B$-algebra described on Group Induces $B$-Algebra.
Then $\left({S, *'}\right) = \left({S, *}\right)$.

0d717e33-75f5-4d0c-8ce4-e938b69395dc.text:
Let $A \subseteq \R$ be the set of all points on $\R$ defined as:
:$A := \set 0 \cup \set {\dfrac 1 n : n \in \Z_{>0} }$
Let $\struct {A, \tau_d}$ be the integer reciprocal space with zero under the usual (Euclidean) topology.
Then $A$ is totally separated.

23e4cb93-9bd8-44c3-995a-0679735ba1d3.text:
Let $a, b \in \Z$ such that not both of $a$ and $b$ are zero.
Let $c$ be any common divisor of $a$ and $b$.
That is, let $c \in \Z: c \divides a, c \divides b$.
Then:
:$c \divides \gcd \set {a, b}$
where $\gcd \set {a, b}$ is the greatest common divisor of $a$ and $b$.

6f66e1be-ebdb-46dc-893c-bee39f85b6c2.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be an integral domain whose zero is $0_D$ and whose unity is $1_D$.
Let $\sim$ be the relation defined on $D$ as:
:$\forall x, y \in D: x \sim y$ {{iff}} $x$ is an associate of $y$
Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.

14f94077-6d63-4d06-82c9-52cccb949940.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a countable complement topology on an uncountable set $S$.
Then $T$ is an irreducible space.

ca4bae86-c914-40c3-bd41-7e9367477510.text:
Let $G$ be an abelian group whose identity element is $e$.
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer .
Let $G_n$ be the subset of $G$ defined as:
:$G_n = \set {x \in G: \order x \divides n}$
where:
:$\order x$ denotes the order of $x$
:$\divides$ denotes divisibility.
Then $G_n$ is a subgroup of $G$.

743ffae3-fde7-4cbe-a9ba-a733c9993ccb.text:
Let $m \in \Z: m \ge 2$.
Let $\struct {\Z_m, +, \times}$‎ be the ring of integers modulo $m$.
Then $\struct {\Z_m, +, \times}$ cannot be an ordered integral domain.

fd0274ca-9738-4380-86d5-ce7a0a29ee4d.text:
There exist exactly five platonic solids:
:$\paren 1: \quad$ the regular tetrahedron
:$\paren 2: \quad$ the cube
:$\paren 3: \quad$ the regular octahedron
:$\paren 4: \quad$ the regular dodecahedron
:$\paren 5: \quad$ the regular icosahedron.
{{EuclidPropStatement|book=XIII|prop=18|qual=Endnote|body=I say next that no other figure, besides the said five figures, can be constructed which is contained by equilateral and equiangular figures equal to one another.}}

c55b3dc3-b3b6-49d9-92bf-d4d5bb29dfb5.text:
Let $\R_{>0}$ be the set of strictly positive real numbers.
For all $x \in \R_{>0}$, let $A_x$ be the open real interval $\openint 0 x$.
Then:
:$\ds \bigcup_{x \mathop \in \R_{>0} } A_x = \R_{>0}$

7506e8c3-25d1-4eef-91fc-d8714e35f027.text:
Let $z_1, z_2 \in \C$ be complex numbers.
Let $\overline z$ denote the complex conjugate of the complex number $z$.
Then:
:$\overline {z_1 - z_2} = \overline {z_1} - \overline {z_2}$

ebe8c186-adf6-4524-a358-5dfdb5e2d63e.text:
Let $\dbinom r k$ denote a binomial coefficient.
Then:
:$\dbinom r k = \dfrac 1 {\paren {r + 1} \map B {k + 1, r - k + 1} }$

c0dcb96f-c7d6-4bb4-a14a-2f6e70192535.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $V$ be a closed set of $T$.
Then $V$ is an $F_\sigma$ set of $T$.

5adbd059-f084-43fb-98a8-80dcbba69eb6.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a non-null ring with no (proper) zero divisors.
Let $x \in R$.
Then:
:$x \circ x = x \iff x \in \set {0_R, 1_R}$
That is, the only elements of $\struct {R, \circ}$ that are idempotent are zero and unity.

6d452057-b30c-4d8c-9e1f-8612302c4118.text:
Let $J$ be an ideal of a ring $R$.
Let $\mathbb L_J$ be the set of all ideals of $R$ which contain $J$.
Let the ordered set $\struct {\map {\mathbb L} {R / J}, \subseteq}$ be the set of all ideals of $R / J$.
Let the mapping $\Phi_J: \struct {\mathbb L_J, \subseteq} \to \struct {\map {\mathbb L} {R / J}, \subseteq}$ be defined as:
:$\forall a \in \mathbb L_J: \map {\Phi_J} a = \map {q_J} a$
where $q_J: a \to a / J$ is the quotient epimorphism from $a$ to $a / J$ from the definition of quotient ring.
Then $\Phi_J$ is an isomorphism.

4699e06a-11f1-44f2-803b-468079d2ce5d.text: :$\ds \int \frac {x \rd x} {\paren {a x + b}^2} = \frac b {a^2 \paren {a x + b} } + \frac 1 {a^2} \ln \size {a x + b} + C$

86e0e591-93a5-43bc-98e1-98e82813a5bc.text: The Hausdorff Maximal Principle implies Zorn's Lemma.

54b5c9f6-bced-4fe9-9a1b-0fd8ac9c80db.text:
Let $\R$ be the real number line considered as an Euclidean space.
Let $\hointr a b \subset \R$ be a half-open interval of $\R$.
Then $\hointr a b$ is not an open set of $\R$.
Similarly, the half-open interval $\hointl a b \subset \R$ is not an open set of $\R$.

b88e2ed8-3354-4a4d-b3e9-b39abb36347d.text:
Let $\struct {S, +, \circ, \preceq}$ be an ordered ring.
Then the identity mapping $I_S: S \to S$ is an ordered ring automorphism.

96560deb-3e81-4d23-b4b3-44b79ac62ddc.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\powerset S$ be the power set of $S$.
Let $\cl: \powerset S \to \powerset S$ be a closure operator.
Let $T \subseteq S$.
Then $\map \cl T$ is a closed set with respect to $\cl$.

ccfc69aa-2e94-4c7f-b769-88756d345c9c.text:
Let $p$ be any prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $x \in \Q_p$.
Then for any sequence $\sequence{y_n}$ of the rational numbers $\Q$:
:$\sequence{y_n}$ is a representative of the $p$-adic number $x$ {{iff}} $\sequence{y_n}$ is a representative of the equivalence class $x$.

2e0d27f9-7cc5-490a-ac30-5feb2a0abb27.text:
Let $G$ be a finitely generated $K$-vector space.
Let $S$ be a linearly independent subset of $G$.
Let $M$ be the subspace of $G$ generated by $S$.
If $M \ne G$, then $\forall b \in G: b \notin M$, the set $S \cup \set b$ is linearly independent.

0b9ef183-73ef-4193-b967-ffc373c6206a.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a finite complement topology on an uncountable set $S$.
Then $T$ is not first-countable.

aafad389-267a-4ea2-a2fb-e07f977333a7.text:
Let $\struct {R, +_R, \times_R}$ be a ring.
Let $\struct {G, +_G, \circ_G}_R$ be an $R$-module.
Let $\struct {H, +_H, \circ_H}_R$ be an $R$-algebraic structure.
Let $\phi: G \to H$ be a homomorphism.
Then the homomorphic image of $\phi$ is an $R$-module.

29e11112-4453-43d3-b88b-637bb3602960.text:
Let $e$ be  Euler's number defined by:
:$\ds e := \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \paren {1 + \frac 1 n}^n$
Then $e$ is the unique solution to the equation $\map \ln x = 1$.
That is:
:$\map \ln x = 1 \iff x = e$

109b05b4-e35c-4d62-bdd6-d82b50a1a90e.text:
:$\ds \sum_{i \mathop \ge 0} \binom n {2 i + 1} = 2^{n - 1}$
where $\dbinom n i$ is a binomial coefficient.
That is:
:$\dbinom n 1 + \dbinom n 3 + \dbinom n 5 + \dotsb = 2^{n - 1}$

d1de60d6-b7bf-42c6-88f4-1b6bf7e05430.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be such that $\size x < 1$.
Then:
:$\ds \pi x \cot {\pi x} = 1 - 2  \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \map \zeta {2 n} x^{2 n}$
where $\zeta$ denotes the Riemann zeta function.

3f924db8-41c8-41b1-bb2e-2fbe5c5aa2d8.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is concave on the open interval $I$.
Let $J = f \left[{I}\right]$.
If $f$ be strictly decreasing on $I$, then $f^{-1}$ is concave on $J$.

9a64b821-ed46-47d9-ac27-f23923013fdf.text:
Let $\struct {\mathbb K, 
orm {\,\cdot\,} }$ be a valued field.
Let the infinite product $\ds \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n$ converge absolutely to $a \in \mathbb K$.
Then $\ds \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty 
orm {a_n}$ converges absolutely to $
orm a$.

2dda48af-3317-43e6-b001-8232c519801e.text:
Let $a, b \in \R$ be real numbers such that $a \ne 0$.
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be the real function defined as:
:$\forall x \in \R: \map f x = a x + b$
Then the inverse of $f$ is given by:
:$\forall y \in \R: \map {f^{-1} } y = \dfrac {y - b} a$

5fdca505-96f9-46e7-b9d1-034fe323c822.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma}$ be a measurable space.
Let $\sequence {f_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$, $f_n: X \to \overline \R$ be a sequence of $\Sigma$-measurable functions.
Then the pointwise lower limit:
:$\ds \liminf_{n \mathop \to \infty} f_n: X \to \overline \R$
is also $\Sigma$-measurable.

e256e1f2-7f97-4e3a-8197-6219d3103351.text:
Let $\struct {R, +_R, \times_R}$ be a commutative ring.
Let $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}$ be a right module over $\struct {R, +_R, \times_R}$.
Let $\circ' : R \times G \to G$ be the binary operation defined by:
:$\forall \lambda \in R: \forall x \in G: \lambda \circ' x = x \circ \lambda $
Then $\struct {G, +_G, \circ', \circ}$ is a bimodule over $\struct {R, +_R, \times_R}$.

beca01b5-4af4-435c-8e21-149aad0c9675.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a sequence in $T$.
Let $l \in S$ such that:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n = l$
Let $\sequence {x_{n_r} }$ be a subsequence of $\sequence {x_n}$.
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{r \mathop \to \infty} x_{n_r} = l$
That is, the limit of a convergent sequence in a topological space equals the limit of any subsequence of it.

5c736ada-f36f-4de6-ae4e-52f37e513df2.text: $\forall a, b, c \in \Z_{>0}$, the equation $a^4 + b^4 = c^4$ has no solutions.

5bdc10d4-e831-41bb-a7c2-6dc5f0c6fd44.text:
Let $p, q, r \in \R_{\ge 1}$ satisfy:
:$1 + \dfrac 1 r = \dfrac 1 p + \dfrac 1 q$
Let $\map {L^p} {\R^n}$, $\map {L^q} {\R^n}$, and $\map {L^r} {\R^n}$ be Lebesgue spaces with seminorms $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_p$, $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_q$, and $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_r$ respectively.
Let $f \in \map {L^p} {\R^n}$ and $g \in \map {L^q} {\R^n}$.
Then the convolution $f * g$ is in $\map {L^r} {\R^n}$ and the following inequality is satisfied:
:$
orm {f * g}_r \le 
orm  f_p \cdot 
orm  g_q$

f9352e25-c351-46e8-abcc-2418324fad9e.text:
The Weierstrass Substitution of $\ds \int \frac {\d x} {p + q \sin a x}$ is:
:$\ds \frac 2 a \int \frac {\d u} {p u^2 + 2 q u + p}$
where $u = \tan \dfrac {a x} 2$.

239d5eed-ef37-4ac9-8b45-16896d4a92f1.text:
Given the relation $\RR$, its transitive closure $\RR^+$ can be constructed as follows:
Let:
:$\RR_n := \begin{cases}
\RR & : n = 0 \\
\RR_{n - 1} \cup \set {\tuple {x_1, x_3}: \exists x_2: \tuple {x_1, x_2} \in \RR_{n-1} \land \tuple {x_2, x_3} \in \RR_{n - 1} } & : n > 0
\end{cases}$
Finally, let:
:$\ds \RR^+ = \bigcup_{i \mathop \in \N} \RR_i$.
Then $R^+$ is the transitive closure of $R$.

43680ca9-7255-47f4-a178-1477316116b1.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma, \mu}$ be a measure space.
Let $f$ be an $A$-measurable function where $A \in \Sigma$.
Then:
:$\ds \map \mu {\set {x \in A: \size {\map f x} \ge t} } \le \frac 1 t \int_A \size f \rd \mu$
for any positive $t \in \R$.

fac1dc58-a521-4796-839b-54540b49f030.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=49|body=To find the second binomial straight line.}}

bc866d47-b70a-4323-aea2-3830b0ba5516.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the either-or space.
Then $T$ is non-meager.

46cb8391-f1c4-4405-b4b2-927506003cd9.text:
Denote with $\overline \R$ the extended real numbers.
Denote with $\cdot_{\overline \R}$ the extended real multiplication.
The algebraic structure $\struct {\overline \R, \cdot_{\overline \R} }$ is a monoid.

939a79b4-9635-4096-88fa-26ddc4a68683.text:
Let $f$ be a real function defined on the closed interval $\closedint a b$.
Let $f$ be piecewise continuous and bounded on $\closedint a b$.
Then $f$ is Darboux integrable on $\closedint a b$.

b270d61f-d46f-4a91-b413-c31823cf4e5e.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}$ be metric spaces.
Let $\AA := A_1 \times A_2$ be the cartesian product of $A_1$ and $A_2$.
Let $\MM = \struct {\AA, d}$ denote the metric space on $\AA$ where $d: \AA \to \R$ is the taxicab metric on $\AA$:
:$\map d {x, y} := \map {d_1} {x_1, y_1} + \map {d_2} {x_2, y_2}$
where $x = \tuple {x_1, x_2}, y = \tuple {y_1, y_2} \in \AA$.
Let $\pr_1: \MM \to M_1$ and $\pr_2: \MM \to M_2$ denote the first projection and second projection respectively on $\MM$.
Then $\pr_1$ and $\pr_2$ are both ‎continuous on $\MM$.

a0596e39-3dca-4955-8de4-3765e441ec1d.text:
Let $a$ and $b$ be real numbers.
Let $i$ be the imaginary unit.
Then:
:$\map \csch {a + b i} = \dfrac {\sinh a \cos b - i \cosh a \sin b} {\sinh^2 a \cos^2 b + \cosh^2 a \sin^2 b}$
where:
:$\csch$ denotes the hyperbolic cosecant function.
:$\sin$ denotes the real sine function
:$\cos$ denotes the real cosine function
:$\sinh$ denotes the hyperbolic sine function
:$\cosh$ denotes the hyperbolic cosine function

747b6451-8328-4e81-9f6c-72ddfd55ef62.text:
Let $m, n, k \in \N$ where $\N$ is the set of natural numbers.
Then:
:$m < n \iff m + k < n + k$

7b223240-d981-45da-a504-d782bfd3546e.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $N \lhd G$ be a normal subgroup of $G$.
Then every subgroup of the quotient group $G / N$ is of the form $H / N = \set {h N: h \in H}$, where $N \le H \le G$.
Conversely, if $N \le H \le G$ then $H / N \le G / N$.
The correspondence between subgroups of $G / N$ and subgroups of $G$ containing $N$ is a bijection.
This bijection maps normal subgroups of $G / N$ onto normal subgroups of $G$ which contain $N$.

087bd588-60bc-42bc-b78d-26770516a9c5.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $T^*_{\bar p} = \struct {S^*_p, \tau^*_{\bar p} }$ be the open extension space of $T$.
Let $U \subseteq S^*_p$.
Then $p$ is a limit point of $U$.

3e3f27c7-9b57-4261-a938-1c1aad3eaa7f.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H \le G$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Then:
:$H = \gen H$
where $\gen H$ denotes the subgroup generated by $H$.

626b653f-4eeb-4e90-b680-83cdafd8041e.text:
Let $\struct {K, +, \circ}$ be the field of quotients of a totally ordered integral domain $\struct {D, +, \circ, \le}$.
Then:
:$\forall z \in K: \exists x, y \in D: z = \dfrac x y, y \in D_{>0}$

19afcb13-0a1f-4144-968b-240b63b3357d.text:
Let $a \in \R_{>0}$ be a positive real number.
Let $x, y \in \R$ be real numbers.
Let $a^x$ be defined as $a$ to the power of $x$.
Then:
:$\dfrac{a^x} {a^y} = a^{x - y}$

3d8c1a1e-02d4-4506-bc84-e6ec01780dc1.text:
Let $S \subseteq \N_{>0}$.
Then, despite Non-Empty Subset of Initial Segment of Natural Numbers has Greatest Element, it is not necessarily the case that $S$ has a greatest element.

fc81b648-364c-4f7c-bd70-ae0bc43a6f9c.text:
Let $J_1, J_2, \ldots, J_n$ be ideals of a ring $\struct {R, +, \circ}$.
Then:
:$J = J_1 + J_2 + \cdots + J_n$ is an ideal of $R$.
where $J_1 + J_2 + \cdots + J_n$ is as defined in subset product.

c0908f22-a07a-4fd1-ac40-7ae19efc0205.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer such that $n$ is even.
Let $U_n = \set {z \in \C: z^n = 1}$ be the set of complex $n$th roots of unity.
The only $x \in U_n$ such that $x \in \R$ are:
:$x = 1$ or $x \in -1$
That is, $1$ and $-1$ are the only complex $n$th roots of unity which are real number.

776b6d63-f87d-4ca1-9517-c3a8006cef5b.text:
:$\ds \int_0^\infty \frac {x \sin m x} {x^2 + a^2} \rd x = \frac \pi 2 e^{-m a}$
where $m$ and $a$ are positive real numbers.

0d0b0470-13c5-4894-b63f-bdbc74c65e3e.text:
Let $z \in \C$ be a complex number expressed in polar form:
:$z = r \paren {\cos x + i \sin x}$
Then:
:$\forall n \in \Z_{>0}: \paren {r \paren {\cos x + i \sin x} }^n = r^n \paren {\map \cos {n x} + i \map \sin {n x} }$

5f6c1801-968f-48b8-bd94-878428774d64.text:
Let $\R$ denote the real numbers.
Let $f$ and $g$ be real functions defined on an open subset $S \subseteq \R$, except possibly at the point $c \in S$.
Let $f$ and $g$ tend to the following limits:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to c} \map f x = l$
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to c} \map g x = m$
Let $\lambda, \mu \in \R$ be arbitrary real numbers.
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to c} \paren {\lambda \map f x + \mu \map g x} = \lambda l + \mu m$

da5be8a8-0586-406e-87e6-807c0d84d4ad.text:
Let $T$ be a topological space.
Let $H \subseteq T$.
Let $\partial H$ denote the boundary of $H$.
While it is true that:
:$\map \partial {\partial H} \subseteq \partial H$
it is not necessarily the case that:
:$\map \partial {\partial H} = \partial H$

b08b1298-61a1-47bd-bcf5-10bc5a5fdf2b.text:
Let $S$ denote the open real interval:
:$S := \openint 0 1$
Let $x \in S$.
400px
Let $\arsech x$ denote the real inverse hyperbolic secant of $x$.
Then:
:$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {\arsech x} = \dfrac {-1} {x \sqrt{1 - x^2} }$

4c01f30f-5bb6-40e4-9f74-b88c0681550e.text:
Let $n$ be a positive integer.
Then $n$ is the sum of $3$ triangular numbers.

56c8697e-a4f9-4494-b70c-a562eb2bf5b9.text:
Let $F_n$ denote the $n$th Fibonacci number.
Let $L_n$ denote the $n$th Lucas number.
Then:
:$5 {F_n}^2 + 4 \paren {-1}^n = {L_n}^2$

193bd421-5bc3-4525-871a-cffbb1cc98c9.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $X$ be an $F_\sigma$ set of $T$.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $X$ is a closed set of $T$.

48acffea-4dbe-42dd-bf06-738afab8d3de.text: The inverse of a many-to-one relation is a one-to-many relation, and vice versa.

865a4065-7de6-4d72-964e-53a9753f4c36.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $\tau_A$ be the topology on $A$ induced by $d$.
Let $\struct {A \times A, \tau}$ be the product space of $\struct {A, \tau_A}$ and itself.
Then the distance function $d: A \times A \to \R$ is a continuous mapping.

da9f0151-b0d0-48a1-a7b9-5c44dc6c716c.text:
An integer $N$ expressed in decimal notation is divisible by $2$ {{iff}} the least significant digit of $N$ is divisible by $2$.
That is:
:$N = [a_n \ldots a_2 a_1 a_0]_{10} = a_0 + a_1 10 + a_2 10^2 + \cdots + a_n 10^n$ is divisible by $2$ 
{{iff}}:
:$a_0$ is divisible by $2$.

31c66726-7a39-4095-a40a-d8fc389e689d.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring.
Let $\EE$ be a congruence relation on $R$ for both $+$ and $\circ$.
Let $R / \EE$ be the quotient set of $R$ by $\EE$.
Let $+_\EE$ and $\circ_\EE$ be the operations induced on $R / \EE$ by $+$ and $\circ$ respectively.
Then $\struct {R / \EE, +_\EE, \circ_\EE}$ is a ring.

5532a3c9-40a4-44db-a3bf-e352948b653f.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $d_3: A^2 \to \R$ be the metric on $M$ defined as:
:$\forall \tuple {x, y} \in A^2: \map {d_3} {x, y} = \dfrac {\map d {x, y} } {1 + \map d {x, y} }$
$d_3$ is topologically equivalent to $d$.

fe1b4b3a-cc56-4679-a53d-a9bfcb3863a1.text:
:$\displaystyle \arcsin x = x \, {}_2 \map {F_1} {\frac 1 2, \frac 1 2; \frac 3 2; x^2}$
where:
:$x$ is a real number with $\size x \le 1$
:$\arcsin$ denotes the arcsine function
:${}_2 F_1$ denotes the Gaussian hypergeometric function.

9e94a85c-a492-4fb9-8d7a-411ebb6434c2.text: Every Hermitian matrix has eigenvalues which are all real numbers.

f0d63c45-83d3-4bfc-9e5a-e73dde073f32.text:
Let $f: \Z_{>0} \to \Z_{>0}$ be a multiplicative function.
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$.
Let $\ds \sum_{d \mathop \divides n} \map f d$ be the sum over the divisors of $n$.
Then $\ds \map F n = \sum_{d \mathop \divides n} \map f d$ is also a multiplicative function.

4c47fb63-c2da-4166-939e-5ddfbb48988e.text:
Let $\Bbb O$ be the set of odd integers.
Then $\Bbb O$ is countably infinite.

dd158feb-91b7-4be1-ba05-d6c26067fa28.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a complete lattice.
Let $X$ be upper way below open subset of $S$.
Let $x \in S$ such that
:$x \in \relcomp S X$
Then
:$\exists m \in S: x \preceq m \land m = \max \relcomp S X$

3c44db42-4502-4dc2-9173-fee8bbe03705.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\csc^2 a x \rd x} {\cot a x} = \frac {-\ln \size {\cot a x} } a + C$

a7303274-d59a-4d0f-9b8a-6c1c5883892b.text:
Let $A \subset \On$.
That is, let $A$ be a class of ordinals (every member of $A$ is an ordinal).
Then $\bigcup A$, the union of $A$, is the least upper bound of $A$:
:$\ds \forall x \in A: x \le A$
:$\ds \forall y \in A: y \le x \implies \bigcup A \le x$

6a9bc37c-1b3d-47b1-804a-b6c8d8cd04af.text:
Let $\laptrans f$ denote the Laplace transform of a function $f$.
Let $\map {I_\R} t$ denote the identity mapping on $\R$ for $t > 0$.
Then:
:$\laptrans {\map {I_\R} t} = \dfrac 1 {s^2}$
for $\map \Re s > 0$.

d0e222d0-73d2-4599-a651-c6ae518bec34.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\sin a x \cos a x} = \frac 1 a \ln \size {\tan a x} + C$

08bbc759-203f-4d1e-8327-a01f29c427ef.text:
:$\map \cot {a - b} = \dfrac {\cot a \cot b + 1} {\cot b - \cot a}$
where $\cot $ is cotangent.

6fefc98f-d4a2-44c9-bf60-56f148aa7f07.text:
Let $G$ and $H$ be groups.
Let $\map Z G$ denote the center of $G$.
Let $Z$ and $W$ be central subgroups of $G$ and $H$ respectively.
Let:
:$Z \cong W$
where $\cong$ denotes isomorphism.
Let such a group isomorphism be $\theta: Z \to W$.
Let $X$ be the set defined as:
:$X = \set {\tuple {x, \map \theta x^{-1} }: x \in Z}$
Then $X$ is a central subgroup of $G \times H$.

a7adf045-dd6f-4061-ae47-a2f66289f98f.text:
For any proper classes or sets $A_1, A_2, \ldots, A_n$:
:$\neg \paren {A_1 \in A_2 \land A_2 \in A_3 \land \cdots \land A_n \in A_1}$

d5870e55-04b7-4d5b-a95a-f51cbfffe99b.text:
Let $\KK$ be a central conic.
Let $\DD$ be the locus of the midpoints of a system of parallel chords of $\KK$.
Then $\DD$ passes through the center of $\KK$.

028025b3-0f7a-4041-8fa3-e994e4859c85.text:
Let $\map \DD \R$ be the test function space.
Let $\map \SS \R$ be the Schwartz space.
Let $\sequence {\phi_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ be a sequence of test functions in $\map \DD \R$.
Let $\mathbf 0 : \R \to 0$ be the zero mapping.
Suppose $\sequence {\phi_n}$ converges to $\mathbf 0$ in $\map \DD \R$:
:$\phi_n \stackrel \DD \longrightarrow \mathbf 0$
Then $\sequence {\phi_n}$ converges to $\mathbf 0$ in $\map \SS \R$:
:$\phi_n \stackrel \SS \longrightarrow \mathbf 0$

d8162466-5bcf-435e-98e0-b0de2bea709a.text:
Let $\struct {X, \preceq, \tau}$ be a linearly ordered space.
Then $\struct {X, \tau}$ is a Hausdorff space.

66de7397-debb-4492-9a7d-d3c7bd204c20.text:
Let $G_1 = \struct {\map V {G_1}, \map E {G_1} }$ and $G_2 = \struct {\map V {G_2}, \map E {G_2} }$ be simple graphs of order $1$.
Then $G_1$ and $G_2$ are isomorphic.

a8812098-8e4d-41b4-8f05-1d263405e28a.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $T \subseteq S$ admit both a supremum $M$ and an infimum $m$.
Then $m \preceq M$.

68309ee6-f5eb-4c59-9151-b56d089a9636.text:
:300px
:$\dfrac 2 \pi x \le \sin x \le x$
for all $x$ in the interval $\closedint 0 {\dfrac \pi 2}$

22e5e341-f53b-4e18-a601-d506aec23525.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring, and let $J$ be an ideal of $R$.
Then $J$ is a subring of $R$.

1b345916-11b2-4219-8066-f518b29a67a5.text:
Let $m \in \Z$ be an integer such that $m > 0$.
The $n$th derivative of $\dfrac 1 {x^m}$ {{WRT|Differentiation}} $x$ is:
:$\dfrac {\d^n} {\d x^n} \dfrac 1 {x^m} = \dfrac {\paren {-1}^n m^{\overline n}} {x^{m + n}}$
where $m^{\overline n}$ denotes the rising factorial.

5266ae4e-d895-4957-ae75-ae1cbf37b4cd.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a non-null ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let $x$ be a unit of $\struct {R, +, \circ}$.
Then $x$ is neither a left zero divisor nor a right zero divisor of $\struct {R, +, \circ}$.

6cd8cbd5-5744-4faf-937b-06e414ca8f64.text:
Let $V_n$ be the Vandermonde matrix of order $n$ given by:
:$V_n = \begin {bmatrix}
  x_1 & x_2 & \cdots & x_n \\
  x_1^2 & x_2^2 & \cdots & x_n^2 \\
\vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
  x_1^n & x_2^n & \cdots & x_n^n
\end{bmatrix}$
Then its inverse $V_n^{-1} = \sqbrk b_n$ can be specified as:
:$b_{i j} = \begin {cases}
\paren {-1}^{j - 1} \paren {\dfrac {\ds \sum_{\substack {1 \mathop \le m_1 \mathop < \ldots \mathop < m_{n - j} \mathop \le n \\ m_1, \ldots, m_{n - j} \mathop \ne i} } x_{m_1} \cdots x_{m_{n - j} } } {x_i \ds \prod_{\substack {1 \mathop \le m \mathop \le n \\ m \mathop \ne i} } \paren {x_m - x_i} } } & : 1 \le  j < n \\
\qquad \qquad \qquad \dfrac 1 {x_i \ds \prod_{\substack {1 \mathop \le m \mathop \le n \\ m \mathop \ne i} } \paren {x_i - x_m} } & : j = n
\end{cases}$

0d8e52f8-0a7c-4065-a4f8-a0e4046e653f.text:
Let $x \in \R$.
Then:
:$\map \arsinh {-x} = -\arsinh x$
where $\arsinh$ denotes the inverse hyperbolic sine function.

1b438260-b90b-463e-8388-592c387d6805.text:
For all $z, w \in \C$ such that it is not the case that $z$ is a negative integer and $w$ an integer:
:$\dbinom z {w - 1} + \dbinom z w = \dbinom {z + 1} w$
where $\dbinom z w$ is a binomial coefficient.

e58705ca-4604-4054-bb12-32f247ae8af1.text:
The set of complex numbers $\C$ is closed under multiplication:
:$\forall z, w \in \C: z \times w \in \C$

a67e8d32-5f84-4638-9f12-8dae3af772c1.text:
Let $X$ be a Hausdorff space.
Then the irreducible components of $X$ are the singleton sets.

10b99a9a-79fa-45c5-bfb3-e4bc86453603.text: The diagonal relation $\Delta_S$ on a set $S$ is universally compatible with every operation on $S$.

aff9f2be-3a4e-400b-ba24-ffdd0e2a41e1.text:
Let $\On$ denote the class of all ordinals.
Let $A$ denote a class.
Suppose that:
:For all elements $x$ of $\On$, if $x$ is a subset of $A$, then $x$ is an element of $A$.
Then $\On \subseteq A$.

5177b0dc-6898-4e25-87c8-15c0cc23c03f.text:
Let $R$ be a noetherian integral domain.
Then $R$ is a factorization domain.

fa0e7304-9cd6-4dce-b675-2dd7d611ecef.text:
Let $R$ be a division ring.
Let $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_1: R 	o \R_{\ge 0}$ and $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_2: R 	o \R_{\ge 0}$ be norms on $R$.
Let $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_1$ and $
orm {\, \cdot \,}_2$ satisfy:
:$ orall y \in R: 
orm y_1 < 1 \iff 
orm y_2 < 1$ 
Then:
:$ orall y \in R: 
orm y_1 > 1 \iff 
orm y_2 > 1$

09391dad-94b7-43db-8dd7-8d0345dc71d4.text:
Let $x$ be a set.
Let $a$ be the smallest set such that $x \in a$ and $a$ is transitive.
Let $b$ be the smallest set such that $x \subseteq b$ and $b$ is transitive.
Then $a = b \cup \set x$.

c07a57e9-a018-436a-b136-faa2d5769508.text:
The integer defined as:
:$\left({1}\right)_{111} \left({2}\right)_{111} \left({3}\right)_{111} \left({4}\right)_{111} \left({5}\right)_{111} \left({6}\right)_{111} \left({7}\right)_{111} \left({8}\right)_{111} \left({9}\right)_{111} \left({0}\right)_{2284} 1$
where $\left({a}\right)_b$ means $b$ instances of $a$ in a string, is a titanic prime.

057af7e1-608c-4cca-a3d6-95812039f2c9.text: In any finite group, each element has finite order.

56007235-f778-42cd-9dd5-0c49144ee9a0.text:
Let $P$ be a polygon embedded in $\R^2$.
Then there exists a Jordan curve $\gamma: \closedint 0 1 \to \R^2$ such that the image of $\gamma$ is equal to the boundary $\partial P$ of $P$.

9323c822-f3dc-40ae-b2b7-51b0a3fb9f24.text:
Let $D_n$ be the dihedral group of order $2 n$.
Let $D_n$ be defined by its group presentation:
:$D_n = \gen {\alpha, \beta: \alpha^n = \beta^2 = e, \beta \alpha \beta = \alpha^{−1} }$
Then for all $k \in \Z_{\ge 0}$:
:$\beta \alpha^k = \alpha^{n - k} \beta$

a04d89f0-cc4b-4268-a986-d0fdce57e826.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \times}$ be an ordered integral domain where $P$ is the (strict) positivity property.
Let the relation $<$ be defined on $D$ as:
:$\forall a, b \in D: a < b \iff \map P {-a + b}$
Then $<$ is compatible with $\times$ in the following sense:
:$\forall x, y, z \in D: x < y, \map P z \implies \paren {z \times x} < \paren {z \times y}$
:$\forall x, y, z \in D: x < y, \map P z \implies \paren {x \times z} < \paren {y \times z}$

fc17d498-3c12-48b6-8739-267fb5c8b753.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=XI|prop=18|body=If a straight line be at right angles to any plane, all the planes through it will be at right angles to the same plane.}}

f29c3677-288e-4981-9ea1-1d57e9b498b7.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \preceq, \tau}$ be a topological lattice.
Suppose that:
:for every subset $X$ of $S$ if $X$ is open, then $X$ is upper.
Let $x \in S$.
Then $x^\succeq$ is compact
where $x^\succeq$ denotes the upper closure of $x$.

6365c4fb-aea7-4b3c-a6c8-056ff6c1cd2c.text:
Let $G$ be an $n$-dimensional vector space over a field.
Let $J: G \to G^{**}$ be the evaluation isomorphism.
Let $G^*$ be the algebraic dual of $G$.
