{{explain|Does this hold for all subfields of $\C$?}}
Let $\HH$ be a Hilbert space over $\mathbb F$ with inner product $\innerprod \cdot \cdot$.
Let $\KK$ be a closed linear subspace of $\HH$.
Let $P_\KK$ denote the orthogonal projection on $\KK$.
Then $P_\KK$ is a linear transformation on $\HH$.

e35b3812-9568-4ca8-a594-2a3ad69ae378.text: The following definition of the concept of the real exponential function:

842c1828-52b5-4334-acf7-3f75ddf420ae.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let the characteristic of $R$ be $p$.
Let $a \in R$ such that $a$ is not a zero divisor of $R$.
Then:
:$n \cdot a = 0_R$
{{iff}}:
:$p \divides n$
where $\cdot$ denotes the multiple operation.

35599148-0c00-44c2-af3d-8f022b58fc62.text:
Let $\struct {R, \norm {\,\cdot\,}}$ be a normed division ring
Let $x \in \R$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be the sequence in $\R$ defined as $x_n = x^n$.
Then:
:$\norm x < 1$ {{iff}} $\sequence {x_n}$ is a null sequence.

40ef9ace-0f1b-45f3-b731-e2d041786fe2.text:
Let $\mu^*$ be an outer measure on a set $X$.
Let $\sequence {S_n}$ be an increasing sequence of $\mu^*$-measurable sets, and let $S_n \uparrow S$ (as $n \to \infty$).
Then for any subset $A \subseteq X$:
:$\ds \map {\mu^*} {A \cap S} = \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \map {\mu^*} {A \cap S_n}$

10d65248-8394-42cc-b3d3-01cc0060301f.text:
Let $a, b \in \Z$ be integers such that $b \ge a$.
Let $U$ be a set of $n = b - a + 1$ numbers $\set {x_a, x_{a + 1}, \ldots, x_b}$.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{a \mathop \le j_1 \mathop < j_2 \mathop < j_3 \mathop < j_4 \mathop \le b} x_{j_1} x_{j_2} x_{j_3} x_{j_4} = \dfrac { {S_1}^4} {24} - \dfrac { {S_1}^2 S_2} 4 + \dfrac { {S_2}^2} 8 + \dfrac {S_1 S_3} 3 - \dfrac {S_4} 4$
where:
:$\ds S_r := \sum_{k \mathop = a}^b {x_k}^r$.

406388f0-efc8-405e-ac2d-1bd3953db5b6.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is convex on the open interval $I$.
Let $J = f \left[{I}\right]$.
If $f$ be strictly increasing on $I$, then $f^{-1}$ is concave on $J$.

ab5ccc58-8a0f-415e-80ce-e10274c926a1.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the countable complement topology on an infinite set $S$.
Let $T' = \struct {S, \tau'}$ be the finite complement topology on the same infinite set $S$.
Then $\tau$ is an expansion of $\tau'$.

b1cabe8c-03a2-49c8-a9a0-5a45b3d414b7.text:
Let $\theta$ be an angle such that $\cos \theta \ne 0$.
Then:
:$\cos \theta = \dfrac 1 {\sec \theta}$
where $\cos$ denotes the cosine function and $\sec$ denotes the secant function.

959ab7bc-0f7d-4680-87fb-2dcce7a7401f.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \cdot}$ be a commutative ring.
Let $\struct {V, +, \circ}_R$ be an $R$-module.
Then for any $r \in R$, the rescaling:
:$m_r: V \to V, v \mapsto r \circ v$
is a linear transformation.

3c662535-3afe-4c24-996e-fbb123c2b310.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}$ be metric spaces.
Let $\AA := A_1 \times A_2$ be the cartesian product of $A_1$ and $A_2$.
Let $\MM = \struct {\AA, d}$ denote the metric space on $\AA$ where $d: \AA \to \R$ is the Euclidean metric on $\AA$:
:$\map d {x, y} := \sqrt {\paren {\map {d_1} {x_1, y_1} }^2 + \paren {\map {d_2} {x_2, y_2} }^2}$
where $x = \tuple {x_1, x_2}, y = \tuple {y_1, y_2} \in \AA$.
Let $\pr_1: \MM \to M_1$ and $\pr_2: \MM \to M_2$ denote the first projection and second projection respectively on $\MM$.
Then $\pr_1$ and $\pr_2$ are both ‎continuous on $\MM$.

a89f6598-25f9-460a-af00-9b03fe5fb246.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Let $x, y \in G$.
Let $x H$ denote the left coset of $H$ by $x$.
Then:
:$x H = y H \iff x \in y H$

c63e81c5-4a0f-4ce5-a3f8-68ee3484e8ad.text:
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times S$ be a relation.
Then $\RR$ is symmetric {{iff}} its complement $\relcomp {S \times S} \RR \subseteq S \times S$ is also symmetric.

2611c1ed-51ad-4026-ae54-86fce109c54b.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a Hausdorff space.
Let $V_1$ and $V_2$ be compact sets in $T$.
Then $V_1$ and $V_2$ have disjoint neighborhoods.

38128019-2c76-4da2-817e-bc3e875d4ca4.text: A group whose order is the square of a prime is abelian.

4c1a5be0-0d70-4cb2-9c5e-f1c9dcc807dc.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\AA = \family {A_\alpha}_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of subsets of $S$, all connected in $T$.
Let $\AA$ be such that no two of its elements are disjoint:
:$\forall B, C \in \AA: B \cap C \ne \O$
Then $\ds \bigcup \AA$ is itself connected.

c3e98639-6a1b-4629-b172-d56d1f6a20de.text:
Let $M = \left({A, d}\right)$ be a metric space.
Let $\left \langle {x_n} \right \rangle$ be a sequence in $M$.
Suppose $\left \langle {x_n} \right \rangle$ has a subsequence which is unbounded.
Then $\left \langle {x_n} \right \rangle$ is divergent.

950c0cc4-6cb4-4b8b-99fc-9173c8e965e0.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a magma.
Let $x \in S$ be an idempotent element of $\struct {S, \circ}$.
Then $\struct {\set x, \circ}$ is a submagma of $\struct {S, \circ}$.

e521597d-52f7-406e-931a-cfade3e115a1.text:
Let $f$ be a real function defined on a closed interval $\closedint a b$.
Let $f$ be piecewise continuous with one-sided limits:
$f$ is '''piecewise continuous with one-sided limits''' {{iff}}:
:there exists a finite subdivision $\set {x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_n}$ of $\closedint a b$, where $x_0 = a$ and $x_n = b$, such that, for all $i \in \set {1, 2, \ldots, n}$:
::$(1): \quad f$ is continuous on $\openint {x_{i − 1} } {x_i}$
::$(2): \quad$ the one-sided limits $\displaystyle \lim_{x \mathop \to {x_{i − 1} }^+} \map f x$ and $\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to {x_i}^-} \map f x$ exist.
Then:
:for all $i \in \set {1, 2, \ldots, n}$, $f$ is uniformly continuous on $\openint {x_{i − 1} } {x_i}$.

8953e400-7cb6-40a7-8d0d-c27936b36da2.text:
Let $\struct {\R^\omega, d}$ be the '''Fréchet space on $\R^\omega$'''.
Then $\struct {\R^\omega, d}$ is a metric space.

8e0b0f01-c0c7-4d1d-92a7-8d1df13ce4c4.text:
Let $H$ be a Hilbert space.
Let $K$ be a closed linear subspace of $H$.
Let $P_K$ denote the orthogonal projection on $K$.
Then: 
:$\map {P_K} H = K$

18594bf1-e540-407f-a5cb-a4eff2af912e.text:
Let $K$ be a division ring.
Let $V$ be a finitely generated vector space over $K$.
Then $V$ has a finite basis.

ee2b8fd4-5031-4624-8f71-6ab19ec130d3.text:
Let $\Omega, \Omega'$ be minimal uncountable well-ordered sets.
Then $\Omega$ is order isomorphic to $\Omega'$.
That is, the minimal uncountable well-ordered set is unique up to order isomorphism.

7fbf1b92-e0ad-451a-a684-75a87af7406f.text:
Let $\struct {X, \norm {\,\cdot\,} }$ be a normed vector space.
Let $K \subset X$ be a closed and bounded subset.
Then $K$ is not necessarily compact.

822678f8-9c01-4952-8751-45756791d86f.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=63|body=The square on the major straight line applied to a rational straight line produces as breadth the fourth binomial.}}

5b837a21-f528-4426-8b5c-725d9fe50210.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma}$ be a measurable space.
Let $f: X \to \R$ be a simple function, and let $\lambda \in \R$.
Then the pointwise scalar multiple $\lambda f: X \to \R$ of $f$ is also a simple function.

19318083-0cf8-4921-8283-391569a4e0e9.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma}$ be a measurable space.
Let $f, g : X \to \R$ be simple functions.
Then $f + g: X \to \R, \map {\paren {f + g} } x := \map f x + \map g x$ is also a simple function.

a99767a7-9960-4c4e-9f4b-0acf28f2c75d.text:
For all $m \in \N: m \ge 2$, the ring of integers modulo $m$:
:$\struct {\Z_m, +_m, \times_m}$
is a commutative ring with unity $\eqclass 1 m$.
The zero of $\struct {\Z_m, +_m, \times_m}$ is $\eqclass 0 m$.

a0b80105-be76-4093-983a-a065cdc1abd3.text:
For all $n \in \N_{> 0}$:
:$F_n \le \phi^{n - 1}$
where:
:$F_n$ is the $n$th Fibonacci number
:$\phi$ is the golden section: $\phi = \dfrac {1 + \sqrt 5} 2$

5a01fc85-ec1e-4c86-b3f8-994134549bad.text:
Let $F$ be a field whose zero is $0$ and whose unity is $1$.
Let $K / F$ be a finite field extension of degree $n$.
Let $\alpha \in K$ be algebraic over $F$.
Then the degree of $\alpha$ is a divisor of $n$.

5995a64f-344d-421e-86bb-45e9d75bbf49.text:
Let $H = \struct {A, \tau}$ be a Hausdorff space.
Let $C$ be a compact subspace of $H$.
Then $C$ is closed in $H$.

2d72f992-9915-4656-abbf-33b443453cb2.text:
Let $\floor x$ denote the floor function of $x$. 
Then:
:$\floor x = x + \map \OO 1$
where $\OO$ is big-O notation.

1553087e-c0e9-4ccf-b7e0-4c1dab11bc2d.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be defined on $\left [{0 \,.\,.\, \to} \right)$ with $f \left({x}\right) = x^x$.
Suppose there exist strictly positive real constants $M, K, a \in \R_{> 0}$ such that:
:$\forall t \ge M: \left\vert {f \left({t}\right)} \right \vert < K e^{a t}$
Then there exists a constant $C$ such that:
:$\forall t > C: \left\vert {f \left({t}\right)} \right \vert > K e^{a t}$

cea346cd-34e1-4034-a6d7-5b8c4f6c7a65.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\mathbf 2$ be the Boolean ring two.
Let $\powerset S$ be the power set of $S$; by Power Set is Boolean Ring, it is a Boolean ring.
Let $\mathbf 2^S$ be the set of all mappings $f: S \to \mathbf 2$; by Two-Valued Functions form Boolean Ring, it is also a Boolean ring
Let $\chi_{\paren \cdot}: \powerset S \to \mathbf 2^S$ be the characteristic function operation.
Then $\chi_{\paren \cdot}$ is a ring isomorphism.

3d25d6b9-8c28-4554-ac0c-586d4bb54727.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\struct {S^S, \circ}$ be the monoid of all the mappings from $S$ to itself.
Let $\GG$ be the set of all invertible mappings from $S$ to $S$.
Then $\struct {\GG, \circ}$ is the symmetric group on $S$.

a54ba4cd-626f-445a-8f9b-78079d18a481.text:
Let $z \in \R$ be a real number.
Let:
:$a \equiv b \pmod z$
and:
:$x \equiv y \pmod z$
where $a, b, x, y \in \R$.
Then it does '''not''' necessarily hold that:
: $a x \equiv b y \pmod z$

6221327a-c07b-48fe-8e10-723d83f23f43.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $\R$ denote the real numbers.
Let $f: M \to \R$ be a real-valued function from $M$ to $\R$ which is continuous on $M$.
Let $\lambda \in \R$ be an arbitrary real number.
Then:
:$\lambda f$ is ‎continuous on $M$.

06c2d98b-6da0-4d4b-a8a1-3a8186c725b6.text:
Let $\map \sigma \FF$ be the $\sigma$-algebra generated by $\EE$.
Let $\map \sigma \FF$ contain a set of sets $\EE$.
Let $\map \sigma \EE$ be the $\sigma$-algebra generated by $\EE$.
Then $\map \sigma \EE \subseteq \map \sigma \FF$.

fb6fb68c-3417-4636-ae24-be7cda5b0e8e.text:
:$\ds \map \Ei x = -\gamma - \ln x + \int_0^x \frac {1 - e^{-u} } u \rd u$
where:
:$\Ei$ denotes the exponential integral function
:$\gamma$ denotes the Euler-Mascheroni constant
:$x$ is a real number with $x > 0$.

525fe58a-8e26-4a0c-8edd-b8b5da48cf2b.text:
Let $A$ be a class.
Let $\RR$ be a set-like endorelation on $A$.
Let $\RR^+$ be the transitive closure of $\RR$.
Then $\RR^+$ is also a set-like relation.

0f32b4cd-8f2d-4f90-bf9a-8673c85094ff.text:
Let $\HH$ be a Hilbert space.
Let $\mathbf T: \HH \to \HH$ be a normal operator.
Let $\lambda_1, \lambda_2$ be distinct eigenvalues of $\mathbf T$.
Then:
:$\map \ker {\mathbf T - \lambda_1} \perp \map \ker {\mathbf T - \lambda_2}$
where:
:$\ker$ denotes kernel
:$\perp$ denotes orthogonality.

f9d3ff44-28df-40ed-a2a1-bb444eeab0ed.text:
Let $G$ be a finite group.
Let $\chi$ be the character of any $\C \left[{G}\right]$-module $\left({V, \rho}\right)$.
Then for all $g \in G$, it follows that $\chi \left({g}\right)$ is an algebraic integer.

5f39b005-791b-4ea5-86bb-119606a9571c.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $x \in S$.
Then $x^\gg \subseteq x^\succeq$
where
:$x^\gg$ denotes the way above closure of $x$,
:$x^\succeq$ denotes the upper closure of $x$.

32cb0ed5-cadd-4ad5-9daa-06769aef871e.text:
:$\dfrac \d {\d x} \paren {\map \Ei x} = -\dfrac {e^{-x} } x$
where:
:$\Ei$ denotes the exponential integral function
:$x$ is a strictly positive real number.

4a0c6253-3c2b-47e8-a589-c0c09927f098.text:
Let $A, B, S$ be sets or classes.
Suppose that $A \subseteq B$.
Then $S \setminus B \subseteq S \setminus A$, where $\setminus$ represents set difference.

ff34849c-0800-4193-ae34-2101b4ac51db.text:
Let $T = \struct {X, \tau}$ be a topological space.
For each $x \in X$, let $\BB_x$ be a local basis at $x$ which consists entirely of open sets.
Then $\ds \BB = \bigcup_{x \mathop \in X} \BB_x$ is a basis for the topology $\tau$.

50d746e5-1d4e-4c01-9727-21b1fad3321d.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $X$ be a subset of $S$.
Then $X \subseteq X^\succeq$
where $X^\succeq$ denotes the upper closure of $X$.

b0b6f1cc-c337-4c79-9633-134b44bdb460.text: :$\ds \int \dfrac 1 x \arccos \frac x a \rd x = \frac \pi 2 \ln \size x - \int \frac {\arcsin \frac x a \rd x} x + C$

c5ade7dd-ac3d-43cf-8004-751b58ba7992.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Then there exist an infinite number of Fibonacci numbers which are divisible by $p$.

5ba1e1b9-cd1c-44e6-97d1-6fdd8cd8b90e.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Let $N$ be a normal subgroup of $G$.
Let $a, b \in G$.
Then the coset product:
:$\paren {a \circ N} \circ \paren {b \circ N} = \paren {a \circ b} \circ N$
is well-defined.

dd893085-4121-48bf-98a7-e1a66dd9edfb.text:
Let $L_1 = \struct {S, \preceq_1}$ be an ordered set.
Let $L_2 = \struct {S, \preceq_2}$ be a dual ordered set of $L_1$.
Then $\map {\mathit {Filt} } {L_1} = \map {\mathit {Ids} } {L_2}$
where
:$\map {\mathit {Filt} } {L_1}$ denotes the set of all filters of $L_1$,
:$\map {\mathit {Ids} } {L_2}$ denotes the set of all ideals of $L_2$.

d3563f1e-00e6-4587-98f0-76fa6245cf1c.text:
:$\ds \int x^3 \sin a x \rd x = \paren {\frac {3 x^2} {a^2} - \frac 6 {a^4} } \sin a x + \paren {\frac {6 x} {a^3} - \frac {x^3} a} \cos a x + C$
where $C$ is an arbitrary constant.

f02e4cf6-a2e6-41b9-8ae5-b1d17c5a3725.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a bounded metric space.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $M$ is totally bounded.

001763b4-eb16-4e71-9761-a09e4d342fc0.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Then $S$ is a convex set in $S$.

cd80e862-fc78-422f-8e23-8e1cd26162b4.text:
:$(1): \quad \forall n \in \Z: x = \paren {n + \dfrac 1 2} \pi \implies \cos x = 0$
:$(2): \quad \forall n \in \Z: x = n \pi \implies \sin x = 0$

09b28982-1c92-4565-8213-3192ff6dfa6b.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $H \subseteq S$ be a subset of $S$.
Let $i_H: H \to S$ be the inclusion mapping on $H$.
Let $T \subseteq S$.
Then:
:$i_H^{-1} \left({T}\right) = T \cap H$
where $i_H^{-1} \left({T}\right)$ is the preimage of $T$ under $i_H$.

dc210e4b-0bee-456a-8f26-e79676903349.text:
Let $\mathbb A$ be one of the standard number systems $\N, \Z, \Q, \R, \C$.
Let $S$ be a finite set.
Let $0 : S \to \mathbb A$ be the zero mapping.
{{explain|Presumably the above is a constant mapping on $0$ -- needs to be made explicit.}}
Then the summation of $0$ over $S$ equals zero:
:$\ds \sum_{s \mathop \in S} 0 \left({s}\right) = 0$

4bcf88ef-c8e1-444d-93fb-d8e503b02698.text:
Let $G$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $\sequence {H_n}$ be a sequence of subgroups of $G$.
Then:
:the subgroup generated by $\ds \bigcup_{k \mathop = 1}^n H_k$ is the internal group direct product of $\sequence {H_n}$
{{iff}}:
:$\sequence {H_n}$ is an independent sequence of subgroups such that every element of $H_i$ commutes with every element of $H_j$ whenever $1 \le i < j \le n$.

b10e77aa-a1b2-4375-94b3-cf034875c494.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $M$ be separable.
Then $M$ is second-countable.

ce7a47b8-85f6-41ce-82a4-05c963fe9c35.text:
Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be cuts.
Let $0^*$ denote the rational cut associated with the (rational) number $0$.
Then:
:$\alpha \beta = 0^*$
{{iff}}:
:$\alpha = 0^*$ or $\beta = 0^*$
where $\alpha \beta$ denotes the product of $\alpha$ and $\beta$.

b29196b8-a951-4c85-8caa-51dc61274303.text:
Let $S_1, S_2, T_1, T_2$ be sets or classes.
Let $\RR_1 \subseteq S_1 \times T_1$ and $\RR_2 \subseteq S_2 \times T_2$ be left-total relations.
Then $\RR_1 \cup \RR_2$ is left-total.

db46e99a-0262-4c28-a7e0-3a3f4d8adddb.text: :$\ds \int \frac 1 {x^2} \arccos \frac x a \rd x  = -\frac 1 x \arccos \frac x a + \frac 1 a \map \ln {\frac {a + \sqrt {a^2 - x^2} } x} + C$

aad5cae4-da06-450f-95a3-e24c111ddab8.text:
Let $a, b \in \Q$ such that $a < b$.
Then $\exists c \in \Q: a < c < b$.
That is, the set of rational numbers is densely ordered.

3c56d757-efa3-4ef0-ad03-0d3c5df829ed.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\sqrt {a x + b} } {\paren {p x + q}^n} \rd x = \frac {-\sqrt {a x + b} } {\paren {n - 1} p \paren {p x + q}^{n - 1} } + \frac a {2 \paren {n - 1} p} \int \frac {\d x} {\paren {p x + q}^{n - 1} \sqrt {a x + b} }$

73bc482b-bf0c-4bcc-a8a8-b5f1fe00fe03.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $T$ be nonempty.
Suppose that $S \times T \sim \card {S \times T}$.
Then:
:$\card S \le \card {S \times T}$

5941ad28-0081-4035-bc83-63afeacbbad2.text:
Let $\omega$ be the set of natural numbers defined as the von Neumann construction.
Then every non-empty bounded subset of $\omega$ has a greatest element.

4c2040eb-3097-488a-b9cf-294a71e245ff.text:
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a sequence in $\R$.
Let $l \in A$ such that $\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n = l$.
Then $\sequence {x_n}$ is bounded.
That is, all convergent real sequences are bounded.

d532306e-3fa8-4211-befa-39a0a1af0b90.text:
Let $D$ be an integral domain.
Let $D \sqbrk X$ be the ring of polynomial forms in $X$ over $D$.
Let $\map P D$ be the ring of polynomial functions over $D$.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $D \sqbrk X$ is isomorphic with $\map P D$.

fbc80eb7-8fe8-40a8-b21d-0c6022b9e5fe.text:
Let $\mathbf S$ be a category with set of objects $S$.
Then the binary relation $\precsim$ defined by:
:$\forall a, b \in S: a \precsim b \iff \exists f: a \to b$
is a preorder on $S$.

9a7da574-8b89-4b57-b9e7-181336b80179.text: A commutative semigroup is an entropic structure.

e76b90d9-78b0-416c-ac0f-ae9668d210a3.text:
Let $T_1 = \struct {A_1, \tau_1}$ and $T_2 = \struct {A_2, \tau_2}$ be topological spaces.
Let $\struct {T, \tau} = T_1 \times T_2$ be the product space of $T_1$ and $T_2$.
Let $\tuple {x, y} \in A_1 \times A_2$.
Let $W \in \tau$ be an open set of $T$ such that $\tuple {x, y} \in W$.
Then:
:$\exists U_1 \in \tau_1, U_2 \in \tau_2: \tuple {x, y} \in U_1 \times U_2 \subseteq W$
That is, products of open sets from $T_1$ and $T_2$ form a local basis at $\tuple {x, y}$.

60fd678f-28c9-4db5-b0d8-ea86d6be6c3c.text:
Let $f: \C \to \C$ be an entire function of finite order $\omega$.
Let $0$ be a zero of $f$ of multiplicity $m \ge 0$.
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ be the sequence of nonzero zeroes of $f$, repeated according to multiplicity.
Then $f$ has finite rank $p \le \omega$ and there exists a polynomial $g$ of degree at most $\omega$ such that:
:$\ds \map f z = z^m e^{\map g z} \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty E_p \paren {\frac z {a_n} }$
where $E_p$ denotes the $p$th Weierstrass elementary factor.

86348b20-6c27-4302-8c64-dc601d48b162.text:
Let $x$ be an object.
Then the power set of the singleton $\set x$ is:
:$\powerset {\set x} = \set {\O, \set x}$

abfa0469-f9ca-42b2-8f70-d509bab1d7cb.text:
Let $n \ge 2$ be a natural number.
Let $S_n$ denote the symmetric group on $n$ letters.
Let $A_n$ be the alternating group on $n$ letters.
Then $A_n$ is a normal subgroup of $S_n$ whose index is $2$.

0763ab95-5f64-4e57-a9bd-e8e6e1a4f335.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a compact first-countable topological space.
Then every infinite sequence in $S$ has a convergent subsequence; that is, $T$ is sequentially compact.

cccac140-86dc-4448-b400-ae1c37317103.text:
Let $n!!$ denote the double factorial function.
The sequence of positive integers $n$ such that $n!! + 1$ is prime begins:
:$0, 1, 2, 518, 33 \, 416, 37 \, 310, 52 \, 608, 123 \, 998, 220 \, 502, \ldots$
{{OEIS|A080778}}

99ce430f-88a2-4b32-af51-f222b955a178.text:
Let $M = \struct {X, \norm {\, \cdot \,}}$ be a normed vector space.
Let $x \in X$.
Let $\epsilon \in \R_{>0}$.
Let $\map {B_\epsilon} x$ be an open $\epsilon$-ball of $x$ in $M$.
Then $\map {B_\epsilon} x$ is an open set of $M$.

327939c0-8d94-4bc1-8839-1084500ea4fa.text:
For all $z, w \in \C$ such that it is not the case that $z$ is a negative integer and $w$ an integer:
:$\dbinom z w = \dfrac z w \dbinom {z - 1} {w - 1}$
where $\dbinom z w$ is a binomial coefficient.

6f4342e1-9ba5-4fbb-b3f9-fc639eddb88c.text:
Let $m \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $\Z_m$ be the set of residue classes modulo $m$.
Then:
:$\card {Z_m} = m$
where $\card {\, \cdot \,}$ denotes cardinality.

250ec157-57b5-44a8-b919-7a32cdfe90fe.text: The only two consecutive positive integers whose sums of the squares of their divisors are equal are $6$ and $7$.

dd585c7e-b293-4dd9-b388-7bdbc294c381.text:
Consider Stirling's triangle of the first kind (signed) expressed as a (square) matrix $\mathbf A$, with the top left element holding $\map s {0, 0}$.
:$\begin{pmatrix}
1 &     0 &       0 &      0 &      0 &     0 & \cdots \\
0 &     1 &       0 &      0 &      0 &     0 & \cdots \\
0 &    -1 &       1 &      0 &      0 &     0 & \cdots \\
0 &     2 &      -3 &      1 &      0 &     0 & \cdots \\
0 &    -6 &      11 &     -6 &      1 &     0 & \cdots \\
0 &    24 &     -50 &     35 &    -10 &     1 & \cdots \\
\vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots &  \ddots \\
\end{pmatrix}$
Thenconsider Stirling's triangle of the second kind expressed as a (square) matrix $\mathbf B$, with the top left element holding $\ds {0 \brace 0}$.
:$\begin{pmatrix}
1 & 0 &   0 &    0 &    0 &    0 & \cdots \\
0 & 1 &   0 &    0 &    0 &    0 & \cdots \\
0 & 1 &   1 &    0 &    0 &    0 & \cdots \\
0 & 1 &   3 &    1 &    0 &    0 & \cdots \\
0 & 1 &   7 &    6 &    1 &    0 & \cdots \\
0 & 1 &  15 &   25 &   10 &    1 & \cdots \\
\vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots \\
\end{pmatrix}$
Then:
:$\mathbf A = \mathbf B^{-1}$
that is:
:$\mathbf B = \mathbf A^{-1}$

a9a277b7-de1a-466e-855c-6efd5894297b.text:
:$\laptrans {\map \Si t} = \dfrac 1 s \arctan \dfrac 1 s$
where:
:$\laptrans f$ denotes the Laplace transform of the function $f$
:$\Si$ denotes the sine integral function

cd652a91-d646-4c31-b258-a9269aab98ff.text: In every group, the identity, and only the identity, has order $1$.

94958825-db08-47e0-b8ad-9bde01681365.text:
Let $\CC$ be a Cartesian plane.
Let $P = \tuple {x, y}$ be a rational point in $\CC$.
Then $P$ is constructible using a compass and straightedge construction.

e3d43b10-6f65-4168-a23f-a26e322f75bb.text:
Let $n \in \N$ be a natural number such that $n \ge 2$.
Let $\N_n$ be defined as:
:$\N_n := \set {1, 2, \dotsc, n}$
Let $A_n = \set {a_1, a_2, \dotsc, a_n} \subseteq \Z$ be a set of $n$ integers.
From Expression for Integers as Powers of Same Primes, let:
:$\ds \forall i \in \N_n: a_i = \prod_{p_j \mathop \in T} {p_j}^{e_{i j} }$
where:
:$T = \set {p_j: j \in \N_r}$
such that:
:$\forall j \in \N_{r - 1}: p_j < p_{j - 1}$
:$\forall j \in \N_r: \exists i \in \N_n: p_j \divides a_i$
where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.
Then:
:$\ds \map \gcd {A_n} = \prod_{j \mathop \in \N_r} {p_j}^{\min \set {e_{i j}: \, i \in \N_n} }$
where $\map \gcd {A_n}$ denotes the greatest common divisor of $a_1, a_2, \dotsc, a_n$.

942be682-dc45-4cae-964b-944a8cacef4a.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a Fort space on an infinite set $S$.
Then $T$ is a $T_1$ (Fréchet) space.

7a5e7181-8c32-41f6-b58f-a8902fcdf936.text:
Let $G$ be a solvable group.
Let $\mathcal H$ be a composition series of $G$.
Then all factor groups of $\mathcal H$ must be prime.

5bf4da41-9f50-4ec5-95ff-f5685aa0cf32.text:
Let $G$ be a unitary $R$-module.
Let $S \subseteq G$.
Then the submodule $H$ generated by $S$ is the set of all linear combinations of $S$.

53e51b5a-6dd2-47bf-9856-fe3489f379d8.text:
Let $G$ be of order $12$.
Then $G$ has either:
:a normal Sylow $2$-subgroup
or:
:a normal Sylow $3$-subgroup.

c3e2a0ae-b29d-4f76-9429-58600c8dd6f0.text:
Let $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$ and $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ be ordered sets.
Let $\preccurlyeq_l$ denote the lexicographic order on $S_1 \times S_2$''':
:$\tuple {x_1, x_2} \preccurlyeq_l \tuple {y_1, y_2} \iff \tuple {x_1 \prec_1 y_1} \lor \tuple {x_1 = y_1 \land x_2 \preccurlyeq_2 y_2}$
Then:
:$\preccurlyeq_l$ is a well-ordering on $S_1 \times S_2$
{{iff}}
:both $\preccurlyeq_1$ and $\preccurlyeq_2$ are well-orderings.

c45bcf97-0e71-4eb9-a1a2-c0dd6cebdb23.text:
Let $S$ be a class.
Suppose the rank, denoted $\map {\operatorname{rank} } x$, of each $x \in S$ is bounded above by some ordinal $y$.
{{MissingLinks|rank}}
Then $S$ is a small class.

f2eeca5a-abf1-4e32-ab80-551af8747b0b.text:
Let $\alpha$ be a cut.
Let $0^*$ be the rational cut associated with the (rational) number $0$:
:$0^* = \set {r \in \Q: r < 0}$
Then there exists a unique cut $\beta$ such that:
:$\alpha + \beta = 0^*$
where $+$ denotes the operation of addition of cuts.

a788dd46-8f18-4c98-9715-d91ce867c709.text:
Let $A$ be a class.
Let $\bigcup A$ denote the union of $A$.
Let $A$ be such that every element of $A$ is transitive.
Then $\bigcup A$ is also transitive.

c7519003-821c-485e-8f14-0fdfcee4063c.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A, d_2}$ be metric spaces on the same underlying set $A$.
Let $d_1$ and $d_2$ be such that:
:$\forall x, y \in A: \map {d_2} {x, y} \le K \map {d_2} {x, y}$
Let $I_A: A \to A$ be the identity mapping on $A$.
Then $I_A$ is continuous from $M_1$ to $M_2$.

3271a964-65c8-4788-9264-2df805df324e.text:
All left cosets of a group $G$ with respect to a subgroup $H$ are equivalent.
That is, any two left cosets are in one-to-one correspondence.
The same applies to right cosets.
As a special case of this:
:$\forall x \in G: \order {x H} = \order H = \order {H x}$
where $H$ is a subgroup of $G$.

dedae22b-a35b-4dbf-98e9-bc42d0dd2d72.text:
Consider the subset $S$ of the complex plane defined as:
:$S := \set {\dfrac i n : n \in \Z_{>0} }$
That is:
:$S := \set {i, \dfrac i 2, \dfrac i 3, \dfrac i 4, \ldots}$
where $i$ is the imaginary unit.
The set $S$ is not closed.

fe771a01-fb68-4c55-874b-a91c1829c7d5.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x^3 \paren {a x + b} } = \frac {2 a x - b} {2 b^2 x^2} + \frac {a^2} {b^3} \ln \size {\frac x {a x + b} } + C$

525aecad-489a-46b1-9f51-d864adf1950e.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ_1}$ and $\struct {T, \circ_2}$ be algebraic structures.
Let $\struct {S \times T, \circ}$ be the external direct product of $\struct {S, \circ_1}$ and $\struct {T, \circ_2}$.
Let $\struct {S, \circ_1}$ and $\struct {T, \circ_2}$ be closed.
Then $\struct {S \times T, \circ}$ is also closed.

567df609-2d8e-4972-bc96-ca596a3816da.text: :$\ds \int \frac {a x + b} {p x + q} \rd x  = \frac {a x} p + \frac {b p - a q} {p^2} \ln \size {p x + q} + C$

bef3c9c4-a032-45cf-8516-e9927cc716b0.text:
Let $\struct {B, \circ}$ be a commutative $B$-algebra. 
Then:
:$\forall x, y, z \in X: \paren {z \circ y} \circ \paren {z \circ x} = x \circ y$

a4266a68-3623-440b-af17-531f3c9ce4d1.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x^2 \paren {a x + b} } = -\frac 1 {b x} + \frac a {b^2} \ln \size {\frac {a x + b} x} + C$

ce2a5077-7b79-4d1d-9772-a19bac9fad1d.text:
Let $K$ be a field.
Let $M$ be a subspace of the $n$-dimensional vector space $K^n$.
Let $\map \dim M = n - 1$.
Let $\sequence {\beta_n}$ be a sequence of scalars such that:
:$M = \set {\tuple {\lambda_1, \ldots, \lambda_n} \in K^n: \beta_1 \lambda_1 + \cdots + \beta_n \lambda_n = 0}$
Then there is a non-zero scalar $\gamma$ such that:
:$\forall k \in \closedint 1 n: \beta_k = \gamma \alpha_k$

ec20e921-0f4a-48c9-bcf7-0eb9ba897670.text:
Let $\mathcal B \left({\R^n}\right)$ be the Borel $\sigma$-algebra on $\R^n$.
Let $B \in \mathcal B$, and let $t \in \R_{>0}$.
Then also $t \cdot B := \left\{{t \mathbf b: \mathbf b \in B}\right\} \in \mathcal B$.

f31739da-0003-4c0e-9e4d-f16d3c8c007d.text: :$\forall a, b \in \R: \paren {a + 2 b}^2 = a^2 + 4 a b + 4 b^2$

4822611b-de71-44df-b924-d56fb4ee1e64.text:
Let $X$ be a set.
Let $w$ be a group word on $X$.
Then $w$ has a unique reduced form.

c1838c7d-ef65-46d8-a39b-b1d84fd9d029.text:
Let $m, n \in \Z$ be integers.
Let $\alpha \in \R$ be a real number.
Then:
:$\ds \int_\alpha^{\alpha + 2 \pi} \cos m x \cos n x \rd x = \begin {cases}
0 & : m \ne n \\
\pi & : m = n
\end {cases}$
That is:
:$\ds \int_\alpha^{\alpha + 2 \pi} \cos m x \cos n x \rd x = \pi \delta_{m n}$
where $\delta_{m n}$ is the Kronecker delta.

4429da49-817f-4f0d-87dc-d052c66c34d9.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group and let $a \in G$.
Then $\map {C_G} a$, the centralizer of $a$ in $G$, is a subgroup of $G$.

5b37d74e-3f77-4e43-9de2-1068592dd2ea.text:
Let $\family {S_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ and $\family {I_\lambda}_{\lambda \mathop \in \Lambda}$ be indexed families of sets.
Let $\ds I = \bigcap_{\lambda \mathop \in \Lambda} I_\lambda$.
Then:
:$\ds \bigcap_{i \mathop \in I} S_i = \bigcap_{\lambda \mathop \in \Lambda} \paren {\bigcap_{i \mathop \in I_\lambda} S_i}$

2a647ea6-dfce-48c1-ac12-3c85365f3df0.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preccurlyeq_1}$ and $\struct {T, \preccurlyeq_2}$ be ordered sets.
Let $\phi: \struct {S, \preccurlyeq_1} \to \struct {T, \preccurlyeq_2}$ be an order isomorphism.
Then $\struct {S, \preccurlyeq_1}$ is a lattice {{iff}} $\struct {T, \preccurlyeq_2}$ is also a lattice.

111d90de-72f5-4a2a-9861-82fb6d624db0.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be an abelian group whose identity is $e$.
Let $*: G \times G \to G$ be the conjugacy group action:
:$\forall g, h \in G: g * h = g \circ h \circ g^{-1}$
Then $*$ is a trivial group action.

2884592f-9d9e-4654-9f83-b0a98dafc8b0.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \set {\O, S} }$ be an indiscrete topological space.
Let $H \subseteq S$.
$H$ is a $G_\delta$ ($G$-delta) set of $T$ {{iff}} either $H = S$ or $H = \O$.

70567069-4dd5-4a44-b314-ef75181ad4ac.text:
Let $\struct {X, d}$ and $\struct {Y, e}$ be metric spaces.
Let $f: X \to Y$ be a mapping.
$f$ is continuous on $X$ {{iff}} $f$ is sequentially continuous on $X$.

793af597-482c-4c4f-924f-ab8486ccb721.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\norm {\,\cdot\,}_p$ be the $p$-adic norm on the rationals numbers $\Q$.
Let $\ds \sum_{n \mathop = m}^\infty d_n p^n$ be a $p$-adic expansion.
Then the sequence of partial sums of the series:
:$\ds \sum_{n \mathop = m}^\infty d_n p^n$
is a Cauchy sequence in the valued field  $\struct{\Q, \norm{\,\cdot\,}_p}$.

17e7c256-5924-4a2d-a2da-f54ea1c529bc.text:
Let $T_1 = \struct {S_1, \tau_1}$ and $T_2 = \struct {S_2, \tau_2}$ be topological spaces.
Let $f: T_1 \to T_2$ be a mapping.
Then $f$ is continuous {{iff}}:
:$\forall H \subseteq S_1: f \sqbrk {H^-} \subseteq \paren {f \sqbrk H}^-$
where $H^-$ denotes the closure of $H$ in $T_1$.
That is, {{iff}} the image of the closure is a subset of the closure of the image.

1a9a24fa-a00a-4dcc-8c30-3386a2257aa5.text:
Let $V$ be a vector space over $K$ with zero vector $\mathbf 0$.
The zero subspace $\set {\mathbf 0}$ is a subspace of $V$.

5b61928f-1f6e-488e-bdc3-470cd79ce8d3.text:
Let $\struct {R_1, +_1, \circ_1}, \struct {R_2, +_2, \circ_2}, \ldots, \struct {R_n, +_n, \circ_n}$ be ringoids.
Let $\ds \struct {R, +, \circ} = \prod_{k \mathop = 1}^n \struct {R_k, +_k, \circ_k}$ be their external direct product.
Then $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ is a ringoid.

f1b48f4a-770a-4625-be07-958387bd28f8.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\left({T, +, \circ}\right)$ be an algebraic structure with two operations $+$ and $\circ$.
Let $T^S$ be the set of all mappings from $S$ to $T$.
Let $\left({T^S, +', \circ'}\right)$ be the structure induced on $T^S$ by $+$ and $\circ$.
Let $\circ$ be distributive over $+$ in $T$.
Then $\circ'$ is distributive over $+'$ in $T$.

33b7de42-a189-4415-8613-b4ca759cd181.text: :$\paren {a \cos x + b \sin x}^2 + \paren {b \cos x - a \sin x}^2 = a^2 + b^2$

9636a117-bedc-49e1-9041-c3a4263b8fa5.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x^2 - a x + a^2} = \frac 2 {a \sqrt 3} \map \arctan {\frac {2 x - a} {a \sqrt 3} }$

50afe8f7-b3ef-4d9e-ac86-b1d4e3bf11bc.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring.
Let $\struct {S, +}$ and $\struct {T, +}$ be additive subgroups of $\struct {R, +, \circ}$.
Let $S T$ be defined as:
:$\ds S T = \set {\sum_{i \mathop = 1}^n s_i \circ t_i: s_1 \in S, t_i \in T, i \in \closedint 1 n}$
Then $\struct {S T, +}$ is a closed subset of $\struct {R, +}$.

af000149-b4a6-4d4e-8f26-86110cf7b24f.text:
Let $\phi: R \to S$ be a ring homomorphism.
Let $\map \ker \phi$ be the kernel of $\phi$.
Then:
:$\Img \phi \cong R / \map \ker \phi$
where $\cong$ denotes ring isomorphism.

1a054a48-6aff-4ea9-abcd-465ea2d0c1f8.text:
Let $\map {J_n} x$ denote the Bessel function of the first kind of order $n$, where $n$ is a positive integer.
Then:
:$\map {J_{-n} } x = \paren {-1}^n \map {J_n} x$

a0469c52-4997-435c-bb5e-bdd50b4857a4.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an up-complete ordered set.
Let $T = \struct {S, \preceq, \tau}$ be a relational structure with the Scott topology.
Let $x \in S$.
Let $x^\preceq$ denote the lower closure of $x$.
Then $x^\preceq$ is topologically closed.

cdaf248d-828a-45f8-b71c-0517ca5c96a7.text: The cancellable elements of a monoid $\struct {S, \circ}$ form a submonoid of $\struct {S, \circ}$.

acb67a45-0421-4f48-85db-d9c6cda37c68.text:
The closed-form expression for the $n$th triangular number is:
:$\ds T_n = \sum_{i \mathop = 1}^n i = \frac {n \paren {n + 1} } 2$
Plainly stated: the sum of the first $n$ natural numbers is equal to $\dfrac {n \paren {n + 1} } 2$.
This formula pops up frequently in fields as differing as calculus and computer science, and it is elegant in its simplicity.

3d2acde1-46c4-43d2-8666-b4fa9ece615c.text:
Let $\triangle ABC$ be a triangle whose sides $a, b, c$ are such that $a$ is opposite $A$, $b$ is opposite $B$ and $c$ is opposite $C$.
Then:
: $\sin A = \dfrac 2 {b c} \sqrt {s \paren {s - a} \paren {s - b} \paren {s - c} }$
where $\sin$ denotes sine and $s$ is the semiperimeter: $s = \dfrac {a + b + c} 2$.

1cafd433-1f9d-442d-a472-54cb3f0bf894.text:
Let $F$ be a field.
Let $\tuple {a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_n}$ be a finite continued fraction of length $n \ge 0$.
Let $p_n$ and $q_n$ be its $n$th numerator and denominator.
Then the value $\sqbrk {a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_n}$ equals $\dfrac {p_n} {q_n}$.

b4440bf9-9ea2-48a6-af23-9542c4ae53cb.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $R \sqbrk X$ be a polynomial ring over $R$ in the variable $X$.
Then the monomials of $R \sqbrk X$ are a basis of $R \sqbrk X$ as a module over $R$.

3ddae89c-035e-45d5-9231-e2c908b2bc91.text:
Let $A$ and $B$ be sets.
Let $f: A \leftrightarrow B$ be a bijection.
Then given $a \in A$ and $b \in B$, there exists another bijection $g: A \leftrightarrow B$ such that $\map g a = b$.

076001aa-e3c6-461f-bef3-20463f09b74c.text:
Let $\struct {\Z, +}$ be the additive group of integers.
Every subring of $\struct {\Z, +, \times}$ is an ideal of the ring $\struct {\Z, +, \times}$.

891e9ef4-0a38-485a-9161-e5a8d82e52a4.text:
Let $\left({T, \le}\right)$ be a well-ordered set.
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $f: S \to T$ be an injection.
Then $\le_f$, the ordering induced by $f$, is a well-ordering.

5779cc31-84fe-42d0-b8ca-895de8e7bd23.text:
Let $S$ be a set and let $\PP$ be a partition on $S$ which is not the (trivial) partition of singletons.
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the partition space whose basis is $\PP$.
Then $T$ is not a $T_1$ (Fréchet) space.

5bb9b190-b714-4e5e-9c39-9f3c72f3907f.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a countable complement space.
Then $\tau$ is a topology on $T$.

d43d1170-f787-4116-904f-43d0ca97c665.text:
Let $\struct{S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $f: S \to \R$ be a real-valued function.
Then $f$ is everywhere continuous {{iff}}:
:$\forall x \in S : \forall \epsilon \in \R_{>0} : \exists U \in \tau : x \in U : \map {f^\to} U \subseteq \openint {\map f x - \epsilon} {\map f x + \epsilon}$

8b2633bc-8924-476f-b29a-a0ae5bd36906.text:
Any pair of integers, not both zero, can be reduced to a pair of coprime ones by dividing them by their GCD:
:$\gcd \set {a, b} = d \iff \dfrac a d, \dfrac b d \in \Z \land \gcd \set {\dfrac a d, \dfrac b d} = 1$
That is:
:$\dfrac a {\gcd \set {a, b} } \perp \dfrac b {\gcd \set {a, b} }$

6cfc7e9d-0281-478a-8272-3cc95431e39f.text:
Let $\EE$, $\FF$ and $\GG$ be affine spaces with difference spaces $E$, $F$ and $G$ respectively.
Let $\LL: \EE \to \FF$ and $\MM: \FF \to \GG$ be affine transformations.
Let $L$ and $M$ be the tangent maps of $\LL$ and $\MM$ respectively.
Then the composition $\MM \circ \LL: \EE \to \FF$ is an affine transformation with tangent map $M \circ L$.

61271df2-9308-4982-a98e-cbb6b116655f.text:
:500px
Let the parabola $P$ defined as $y = x^2$ be plotted on the Cartesian plane.
Let $A = \tuple {x_a, y_a}$ and $B = \tuple {x_b, y_b}$ be points on the curve $\map f x$ so that $x_a < x_b$.
Then the line segment joining $A B$ will cross the $y$-axis at $-x_a x_b$.
Thus $P$ can be used as a nomogram to calculate the product of two numbers $x_a$ and $x_b$, as follows:
:$(1) \quad$ Find the points $-x_a$ and $x_b$ on the $x$-axis.
:$(2) \quad$ Find the points $A$ and $B$ where the lines $x = -x_a$ and $x = x_b$ cut $P$.
:$(3) \quad$ Lay a straightedge on the straight line joining $A$ and $B$ and locate its $y$-intercept $c$.
Then $x_a x_b$ can be read off from the $y$-axis as the position of $c$.

4b292e36-9561-4a7f-9047-d88fa1bf5dfb.text:
Let $D: \R \to \R$ denote the Dirichlet function:
:$\forall x \in \R: \map D x = \begin {cases} c & : x \in \Q \\ d & : x \notin \Q \end {cases}$
where $\Q$ denotes the set of rational numbers.
Then $D$ is discontinuous at every $x \in \R$.

3f9e539c-f047-47b2-bf9d-20000a904e98.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \preceq}$ be a bounded below join semilattice.
Let $I = \struct {\map {\mathit {Ids} } L, \precsim}$ be an inclusion ordered set
where:
:$\map {\mathit {Ids} } L$ denotes the set of all ideals in $L$
:$\mathord \precsim = \mathord \subseteq \cap \paren {\map {\mathit {Ids} } L \times \map {\mathit {Ids} } L}$
Let $P = \struct {\map K I, \precsim'}$ be an ordered subset of $I$
where:
:$\map K I$ denotes the compact subset of $I$.
Let $f: S \to \map K I$ be a mapping such that:
:$\forall x \in S: \map f x = x^\preceq$
Then $f$ is an order isomorphism between $L$ and $P$.

10520ae7-fa15-4b98-b2b4-8d1294cf3137.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $\struct {R \sqbrk X, \iota, X}$ be a polynomial ring over $R$ in one indeterminate $X$.
Then the canonical homomorphism $\iota : R \to R \sqbrk X$ is a ring monomorphism.

5d0455af-1175-46c6-97d4-b2a408ce1a9b.text:
Let $T$ be a topological space.
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\forall i \in I: H_i \subseteq T$.
Then:
:$\ds \map \cl {\bigcap_I H_i} \subseteq \bigcap_I \map \cl {H_i}$
where $\map \cl {H_i}$ denotes the closure of $H_i$.

6f159bd6-2eb9-4e49-9bf9-56151f5ff9b5.text:
Let $f$ be a polynomial with rational coefficients.
Let $\cont f$ be the content of $f$.
If $f$ is monic, then $\cont f = \dfrac 1 n$ for some integer $n$.

d007fb0a-8a7c-4d2c-80e9-e0825d0b471d.text:
Let $a, b \in \Z$ be integers.
Let $\size a$ denote the absolute value of $a$:
:$\size a = \begin {cases} a & : a \ge 0 \\ -a : a < 0 \end {cases}$
Then:
:$\size a \times \size b = \size {a \times b}$

0ca98c92-5101-4e21-9a70-9975fcd9d345.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=XI|prop=8|body=If two straight lines be parallel, and one of them be at right angles to any plane, the remaining one will also be at right angles to the same plane.}}

38f255e9-ad4f-4f93-b2ef-89c62918c33a.text:
:$\map \coth {a - b} = \dfrac {\coth a \coth b - 1} {\coth b - \coth a}$
where $\coth$ denotes the hyperbolic cotangent.

92cb88e8-3b8f-44c3-8469-9279d93c6c53.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $f: S \to T$ and $g: T \to S$ be injections.
Then there exists a bijection $\phi: S \to T$.

0955c5d4-9ac7-463b-a4b8-4ff1cfb9a3bb.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $T$ admit a infimum in $S$.
Then the infimum of $T$ in $S$ is not necessarily the smallest element of $T$.

27f84a12-8879-4b16-a724-1ed414bba309.text:
Let $\struct {K, +, \circ}$ be a ring.
Let $\mathbb K$ be the set of all subrings of $K$.
Then $\struct {\mathbb K, \subseteq}$ is a complete lattice.

7bce925c-c094-4f33-aa6b-d25ab94f828d.text:
Let $m \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $\struct {\Z_m, +, \times}$ denote the ring of integers modulo $m$.
The ideals of $\struct {\Z_m, +, \times}$ are of the form:
:$d \Z / m \Z$
where $d$ is a divisor of $m$.

1c78d6fb-deb8-461b-9a3c-b4f05786e2a8.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau_S}$ be a topological space.
Let $\struct {G, *, \tau_G}$ be a topological semigroup.
Let $\lambda \in G$.
Let $f: \struct {S, \tau_S} \to \struct {G, \tau_G}$ be a continuous mapping.
Let $\lambda * f: S \to G$ be the mapping defined by:
:$\forall x \in S: \map {\paren {\lambda * f} } x = \lambda * \map f x$
Let $f * \lambda: S \to G$ be the mapping defined by:
:$\forall x \in S: \map {\paren {f * \lambda} } x = \map f x * \lambda$
Then:
:$\lambda * f: \struct {S, \tau_S} \to \struct {G, \tau_G}$ is a continuous mapping
:$f * \lambda: \struct {S, \tau_S} \to \struct {G, \tau_G}$ is a continuous mapping.

7519f6a7-c58b-48a0-8d54-4b89ecc819f1.text:
Let $G$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $g \in G$.
Let $\phi: \Z \to G$ be the mapping defined as:
:$\forall n \in \Z: \map \phi n = g^n$.
Then:
:If $g$ has infinite order, then $\phi$ is a group isomorphism from $\struct {\Z, +}$ to $\gen g$.
:If $g$ has finite order such that $\order g = m$, then $\phi$ is a group epimorphism from $\struct {\Z, +}$ to $\gen g$ whose kernel is the principal ideal $\paren m$.
:Thus $\gen g$ is isomorphic to $\struct {\Z, +}$, and $m$ is the smallest (strictly) positive integer such that $g^m = e$.

3bba5a6b-673e-49d3-8e8f-392e4b5a8db4.text:
Let $\family {X_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of topological spaces, where $I$ is an arbitrary index set.
Let $X = \ds \prod_{i \mathop \in I} X_i$ be the product space of $\family {X_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$.
Let $U$ be nonempty open subset of $X$.
Let $x$ be a point in $X$.
For each point $y$ in $X$, let $\map K y = \set {i \in I : y_i \ne x_i}$.
Then there exists a point $u$ in $U$ such that $\map K u$ is finite.

a351b3a4-48b7-4278-b246-3fc54ab4aab2.text:
:$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {a x^2 + b x + c} = \frac 1 b \ln \size {b x + c} + C$
when $a = 0$.

9b9546b0-07c8-4ff6-83f6-39a44453ac28.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=69|body=A straight line commensurable with the side of a rational plus a medial area is itself also the side of a rational plus a medial area.}}

71f4f987-68a4-4a3f-aedb-3da7b51690a3.text:
For every pair of integers $a, b$ where $b > 0$, the integers $q, r$ such that $a = q b + r$ and $0 \le r < b$ are unique:
:$\forall a, b \in \Z, b > 0: \exists! q, r \in \Z: a = q b + r, 0 \le r < b$
In the above equation:
:$a$ is the '''dividend'''
:$b$ is the '''divisor'''
:$q$ is the '''quotient'''
:$r$ is the '''principal remainder''', or, more usually, just the '''remainder'''.

57616c1b-7d32-4c9c-878c-a4ec15b39431.text:
Let $\struct {R, \norm {\,\cdot\,} }$ be a normed division ring.
Let $a \in R$.
Let $\epsilon \in \R_{>0}$ be a strictly positive real number.
Let $\map {B_\epsilon} a$ be the open $\epsilon$-ball of $a$ in $\struct{R, \norm {\,\cdot\,} }$.
Then:
:$a \in \map {B_\epsilon} a$

145072db-bbed-4358-b685-4300bc580e59.text:
Let $\struct {\Z_p, +_p, \times_p}$‎ be the ring of integers modulo $p$.
The following statements are equivalent:
:$(1): \quad p$ is a prime.
:$(2): \quad \struct {\Z_p, +_p, \times_p}$ is an integral domain.
:$(3): \quad \struct {\Z_p, +_p, \times_p}$ is a field.

d523ac1f-0b24-436b-ba30-0e52011e5a9c.text:
For $n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$:
:$\ds \sum_k \map {A_k} {r, t} \map {A_{n - k} } {s, t} = \map {A_n} {r + s, t}$
where $\map {A_n} {x, t}$ is the polynomial of degree $n$ defined as:
:$\map {A_n} {x, t} = \dbinom {x - n t} n \dfrac x {x - n t}$
where $x \ne n t$.

c6e685e8-d92e-4fd0-9d2e-c6383e0341e5.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma, \mu}$ be a measure space.
Let $f: X \to \overline \R$ be a $\Sigma$-measurable.
Then: 
:$\set {x \in X : \map f x \in \R}$ is $\Sigma$-measurable.

41a20a02-7b99-4d2b-9ecf-689062e639bc.text:
Let $p \in \N$ be a prime.
Let $\norm{\,\cdot\,}_p: \Q_p \to \R_{\ge 0}$ be the $p$-adic norm on the $p$-adic numbers $\Q_p$.
Let $d_p$ be the $p$-adic metric on $\Q_p$:
:$\forall x, y \in \Q_p: \map {d_p} {x, y} = \norm{x - y}_p$
Then $d_p$ is a non-Archimedean metric that extends the $p$-adic metric on the rationals $\Q$ to $\Q_p$.

ab2d36e3-a6b5-4b59-8511-95328bc1f9f0.text:
Let $p, a \in \Z$.
If $p$ is a prime number then:
:$p \nmid a \implies p \perp a$
where:
:$p \nmid a$ denotes that $p$ does not divide $a$
:$p \perp a$ denotes that $p$ and $a$ are coprime.
It follows directly that if $p$ and $q$ are primes, then:
:$p \divides q \implies p = q$
:$p \ne q \implies p \perp q$

7070fb9f-4637-412c-be54-297f29953f84.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $T \subseteq S$ be a subset of $S$, and let $\preceq \restriction_T$ be the restricted ordering on $T$.
Then for all $t \in T$:
:$t^{\prec T} = T \cap t^{\prec S}$
where:
: $t^{\prec T}$ is the strict lower closure of $t$ in $\left({T, \preceq \restriction_T}\right)$
: $t^{\prec S}$ is the strict lower closure of $t$ in $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$.

e83b726c-f8f5-4a8f-9944-23fe02da6a9c.text:
Consider the subset $S$ of the complex plane defined as:
:$S := \set {\dfrac i n : n \in \Z_{>0} }$
That is:
:$S := \set {i, \dfrac i 2, \dfrac i 3, \dfrac i 4, \ldots}$
where $i$ is the imaginary unit.
$S$ is not an open region.

36829a1b-963a-411d-a7cf-76d1c26dc4ba.text:
Let $A$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $\mathfrak a \subseteq A$ be an ideal.
Then $\mathfrak a$ is contained in its radical:
:$\mathfrak a \subseteq \operatorname{Rad} \left({\mathfrak a}\right)$

b4a2a4fc-c36f-4623-ae69-52a5e23bbdf1.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ have an abundancy index greater than $9$.
Then $n$ has at least $35$ distinct prime factors.

dfd72f17-e7e9-4f96-9c43-90f240ad6eac.text:
Let $f$ be a meromorphic function that: 
:has only simple poles 
:is continuous, or has a removable singularity, at $0$. 
Let $X$ be the set of poles of $f$. 
For $N \in \N$, let $C_N$ be a disk, centred at the origin, of radius $R_N$ where: 
:$R_N \to \infty$ as $N \to \infty$ 
:$\partial C_N$ contains no poles of $f$ for any $N$. 
:there exists a real number $M > 0$ independent of $N$ such that for all $z \in \partial C_N$, $\cmod {\map f z} < M$ , for all $N \in \N$.
Then:
:$\ds \map f z = \map f 0 + \sum_{n \mathop \in X} \Res f n \paren {\frac 1 {z - n} + \frac 1 n}$ 
where:
:$\Res f n$ is the residue of $f$ at $n$
:$z$ is not a pole of $f$
:$\ds \map f 0 = \lim_{z \mathop \to 0} \map f z$ if $f$ has a removable singularity at $0$.

2877995a-406b-46b3-8344-10db17a774ef.text:
Let $R$, $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $S \times T$ be the Cartesian product of $S$ and $T$.
Then there exists a bijection from $R \times \paren {S \times T}$ to $\paren {R \times S} \times T$.
Hence:
:$\card {R \times \paren {S \times T} } = \card {\paren {R \times S} \times T}$

9eb23caa-fa38-4bcd-b23a-2dc3c49a3f09.text:
Let $\family {X_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be a family of sets where $I$ is an arbitrary index set.
Let $\ds X = \prod_{i \mathop \in I} X_i$ be the Cartesian product of $\family {X_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$.
Let $z \in X$.
Let $i \in I$. 
Let $Y_i = \set {x \in X: \forall j \in I \setminus \set i: x_j = z_j}$.
Let $p_i = \pr_i {\restriction_{Y_i} }$, where $\pr_i$ is the projection from $X$ to $X_i$.
Then:
:$p_i$ is a surjection.

be07ed27-0840-4ebe-87f3-3802429a1077.text:
The Diophantine equation:
:$n^x + n^y = n^z$
has exactly one form of solutions in integers:
:$2^x + 2^x = 2^{x + 1}$
for all $x \in \Z$.
'''Tamref's Last Theorem''' appears as '''tamreF's last theorem''' on the ''Math Fun Facts'' page of Harvey Mudd College.
The name is an obvious reversal of the surname of {{AuthorRef|Pierre de Fermat}}, in homage to the famous Fermat's Last Theorem.

1345f116-3cd1-4cef-badc-6a4723b0a0a4.text:
Let $\set {E_n : n \in \N}$ be a sequence of sets.
Then:
:$\ds \liminf_{n \mathop \to \infty} E_n \subseteq \limsup_{n \mathop \to \infty} E_n$

393f489e-bfc7-4d50-9092-c6a4490ebfeb.text:
The Min operation is commutative:
:$\map \min {x, y} = \map \min {y, x}$

7318b594-1207-4a46-98ca-1ff57baf73b5.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring with unity $1_R$.
Let $U_R$ be the set of units in $R$.
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\struct {R^S, +', \circ'}$ be the ring of mappings on the set of mappings $R^S$.
Let $\Img f \subseteq U_R$ where $\Img f$ is the image of $f$.
Then:
:$f \in R^S$ is a unit of $R^S$
and the inverse of $f$ is the mapping $f^{-1} : S \to U_R$ defined by:
:$\forall x \in S : \map {f^{-1}} {x} = \map f x^{-1}$

eee69c71-dfff-4e35-a32c-abff87fe2ac7.text:
Let $\struct {\overline \R, \le}$ be the extended real numbers with the usual ordering.
Then $+\infty$ is a maximal element of $\overline \R$.

5145e8a4-02c2-49d0-ab5f-8bd4320b101e.text:
Let $\mathscr S = \struct {S, \wedge, \preceq}$ be an up-complete meet semilattice.
Let $f: \map {\it Ids} {\mathscr S} \to S$ be a mapping such that:
:$\forall I \in \map {\it Ids} {\mathscr S}: \map f I = \sup_{\mathscr S} I$
where 
:$\map {\it Ids} {\mathscr S}$ denotes the set of all ideals in $\mathscr S$
Let
:$\forall I_1, I_2 \in \map {\it Ids} {\mathscr S}: \paren {\sup I_1} \wedge \paren {\sup I_2} = \sup \set {i \wedge j: i \in I_1, j \in I_2}$
Then:
$f$ preserves meet as a mapping from $\struct {\map {\it Ids} {\mathscr S}, \subseteq}$ into $\mathscr S$

9805831a-33af-4920-b011-5e3c937bb696.text:
Let $n$ be an integer such that $n \ge 1$.
Let $\map D n$ denote the product of the divisors of $n$.
Then:
:$\map D n = n^{\map {\sigma_0} n / 2}$
where $\map {\sigma_0} n$ denotes the divisor counting function of $n$.

614d7a2a-8541-41c0-ae7b-a0c4a2ff9f76.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ and $K$ be subgroups of $G$.
Then:
:$\order {H K} = \dfrac {\order H \order K} {\order {H \cap K} }$
where:
:$H K$ denotes subset product
:$\order H$ denotes the order of $H$.

bf956a8e-ade0-429f-9ec2-ca6d1429ed39.text:
Let $X$ be one of the standard number fields $\Q, \R, \C$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a sequence in $X$ which converges to $l$.
That is:
: $\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n = l$
Then:
: $\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \cmod {x_n - l} = 0$

95e8b41f-843d-464f-9b98-5c6c02754dd5.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space where $S$ is a finite set.
Then $T$ is a second-countable space.

f64fd224-79bf-470d-8e4b-b8c610bd64aa.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=XIII|prop=2|qual=Lemma|body=That the double of $AC$ is greater than $BC$ is to be proved thus.}}

71843d12-3a80-4c67-9440-080f236533a4.text:
Let $\map f x$ be the real function defined on $\openint 0 \pi$ as:
:$\map f x = x \paren {\pi - x}$
Then its half-range Fourier sine series can be expressed as:
:$\ds \map f x \sim \frac 8 \pi \sum_{r \mathop = 0}^\infty \frac {\sin \paren {2 r + 1} x} {\paren {2 r + 1}^3}$

34b3dc18-9593-4607-8545-c495e9d9356d.text:
Let $\mathbf {A, B}$ be square matrices of order $n$
Let $\mathbf I$ be the $n \times n$ unit matrix.
Let $\mathbf A$ and $\mathbf B$ be invertible.
Then the matrix product $\mathbf {AB}$ is also invertible, and:
:$\paren {\mathbf A \mathbf B}^{-1} = \mathbf B^{-1} \mathbf A^{-1}$

cade2677-43d8-4428-ba2c-9a7b96f3f1a6.text:
Let $\struct {A, +, \circ}$ be a commutative ring.
Let $e$ be an idempotent element of $A$.
Then the ideal $I := \ideal e$ generated by $e$ is a commutative ring with unity $\struct {I, +, \circ}$ with unity $e$.

1330db3a-e6da-426b-ade1-0972df40f26c.text:
Let $z \in \C$ be a complex number.
Let $\overline z$ be the complex conjugate of $z$.
Then $z = \overline z$ {{iff}} $z$ is wholly real.

0ae59c20-6708-46a9-a252-6a1b107942c2.text:
Let $\left({G, \circ}\right)$ be a group.
Let $S \subseteq G$.
Let $S$ be a normal subset of $G$ by Definition 2.
Then $S$ is a normal subset of $G$ by Definition 3.
That is, if:
:$\forall g \in G: g \circ S \circ g^{-1} = S$
or:
:$\forall g \in G: g^{-1} \circ S \circ g = S$
then:
:$\forall g \in G: g \circ S \circ g^{-1} \subseteq S$
and:
:$\forall g \in G: g^{-1} \circ S \circ g \subseteq S$

19bfdb3b-b7ad-419e-a80b-5d4a689cf20f.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a $T_4$ topological space.
Let $A, B \subseteq S$ be closed sets of $T$ such that $A \cap B = \O$.
Then there exists an Urysohn function for $A$ and $B$.

2890caca-de42-4dcf-b464-20013d50a754.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $\prec$ be the relation on $S$ defined as:
:$a \prec b \iff \paren {a \ne b} \land \paren {a \preceq b}$
That is, $a \prec b$ {{iff}} $a$ strictly precedes $b$.
Then:
:$a \preceq b \iff \paren {a = b} \lor \paren {a \prec b}$
and $\prec$ is a strict ordering on $S$.

c8995bfa-a461-40fa-805f-c726c009b260.text:
Let $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_R$ be an $R$-module.
Then the null module:
:$\struct {\set {e_G}, +_G, \circ}_R$
is a submodule of $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_R$.

4b604d87-9bc0-493d-892c-ac9a66ccd624.text:
Let $\struct {F, +, \circ}$ be a field whose unity is $1_F$.
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be a subdomain of $\struct {F, +, \circ}$ whose unity is $1_D$.
Let:
:$K = \set {\dfrac x y: x \in D, y \in D^*}$
where $\dfrac x y$ is the division product of $x$ by $y$.
Then $\struct {K, +, \circ}$ is a field of quotients of $\struct {D, +, \circ}$.

2b2c3128-ff3e-4c65-b277-792338662185.text:
Let $\struct {R, \norm {\, \cdot \,} }$ be a normed division ring with zero: $0$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a sequence in $R$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be convergent in the norm $\norm {\, \cdot \,}$ to the following limit:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n = l$
Suppose $l \ne 0$.
Then:
:$\exists k \in \N : \forall n \in \N: x_{k + n} \ne 0$
and the subsequence $\sequence { x_{k+n}^{-1} }$ is well-defined and convergent with:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} {x_{k + n} }^{-1} = l^{-1}$.
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} {y_n}^{-1} = l^{-1}$
{{qed}}

19be4663-a5b3-4d68-8ba0-4c984244e75d.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\powerset S$ be the power set of $S$.
Let $\TT \subseteq \powerset S$ be a subset of $\powerset S$.
The greatest set of $\TT$ may not exist.

9c24741e-31d9-4ce2-ac7a-14c8840054aa.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $k > 0$ be a positive integer.
Let $f \left({X}\right) \in \Z \left[{X}\right]$ be a polynomial.
Let $x_k \in \Z$ such that:
:$f \left({x_k}\right) \equiv 0 \pmod {p^k}$
:$f' \left({x_k}\right) \not \equiv 0 \pmod p$
Then for every integer $l \ge 0$, there exists an integer $x_{k + l}$ such that:
:$f \left({x_{k + l} }\right) \equiv 0 \pmod {p^{k + l} }$
:$x_{k + l}\equiv x_k \pmod {p^k}$
and any two integers satisfying these congruences are congruent modulo $p^{k + l}$.
Moreover, for all $l\geq0$ and any solutions $x_{k + l}$ and $x_{k + l + 1}$:
:$x_{k + l + 1} \equiv x_{k + l} - \dfrac {f \left({x_{k + l} }\right)} {f' \left({x_{k + l} }\right)} \pmod {p^{k + l + 1} }$
:$x_{k + l + 1} \equiv x_{k + l} \pmod {p^{k + l} }$

0e5be19e-05b6-4889-8c87-4fec0d54f3ff.text:
All infinite cyclic groups are isomorphic.
That is, up to isomorphism, there is only one infinite cyclic group.

6427a78f-76fd-4d47-af9b-f0b38e8a098a.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be an algebraic structure.
Let $\struct {T, \circ}$ be an algebraic substructure of $S$.
Let $\iota: T \to S$ be the inclusion mapping from $T$ to $S$.
Then $\iota$ is a monomorphism.

399359fa-f2b0-4051-a678-19bd22879da6.text:
Let $n_1, n_2, \ldots, n_r$ be pairwise coprime positive integers.
Let $\ds N = \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^r n_i$.
For an integer $k$, let $\Z / k \Z$ denote the ring of integers modulo $k$.
Then we have a ring isomorphism:
:$\Z / N \Z \simeq \Z / n_1 \Z \times \cdots \times \Z / n_r \Z$

d08d1bf8-9388-464f-9d6c-6ea415c00844.text: :$\ds \int x^2 \paren {\sqrt {x^2 + a^2} }^3 \rd x = \frac {x \paren {\sqrt {x^2 + a^2} }^5} 6 - \frac {a^2 x \paren {\sqrt {x^2 + a^2} }^3} {24} - \frac {a^4 x \sqrt {x^2 + a^2} } {16} - \frac {a^6} {16} \map \ln {x + \sqrt {x^2 + a^2} } + C$

2a97cc90-2f5a-4e32-9449-0a6a3e794954.text:
Let $a, b$ be real numbers with $a < b$.
Let $f : \closedint a b \to \R$ be a continuously differentiable function.
Let $V_f$ be the total variation of $f$ on $\closedint a b$.
Then:
:$\ds V_f = \int_a^b \size {\map {f'} x} \rd x$

58eb9366-4e91-4620-b6b9-fab8ecbd18ec.text:
Let $T$ be a subset of the set of real numbers.
Let $T$ be bounded below.
Let $\xi \in \R$.
Then:
:$\ds \map {\inf_{x \mathop \in T} } {x + \xi} = \xi + \map {\inf_{x \mathop \in T} } x$
where $\inf$ denotes infimum.

d3a34e20-3672-40e9-aba2-59bbccd1e1c3.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $U$ and $V$ be regular open sets of $T$.
Then $U \cup V$ is not also necessarily a regular open set of $T$.

e6adbf8c-86a0-4879-8722-8f067f9cd997.text: The ring of Eisenstein integers $\struct {\Z \sqbrk \omega, +, \times}$ is an integral domain.

c51327cc-e249-4bd4-8afa-e8954811a2f5.text:
Let $\struct {R, \norm {\, \cdot \,} }$ be a normed division ring with zero: $0$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a Cauchy sequence in $R$.
Let $\sequence {x_{n_r} }$ be a subsequence of $\sequence {x_n}$.
Then:
:$\sequence {x_{n_r} }$ is a Cauchy sequence in $R$.

196aa88c-3cf0-42d3-b4be-8813b99d5ab3.text: The evolute of a cycloid is another cycloid.

e38e1eaf-5cde-41ce-9be1-00cc5801c94c.text:
Let $H, K$ be Hilbert spaces, and let $A: H \to K$ be a linear transformation.
Then the following four statements are equivalent:
:$(1): \quad A$ is continuous
:$(2): \quad A$ is continuous at $\mathbf 0_H$
:$(3): \quad A$ is continuous at some point
:$(4): \quad \exists c > 0: \forall h \in H: \norm {\map A h}_K \le c \norm h_H$

8feb9f3d-0e30-4fb4-a7c8-1c19531c44af.text:
Let $S$ be the set defined as:
:$S = \set {\set {n_1, n_2}: n_1, n_2 \in \N, n_1 \ne n_2}$
where $\N$ denotes the set of natural numbers.
Then $S$ is countably infinite.

5a87aa4a-4945-4426-9976-07d47faf6515.text:
Let $T$ be a topological space.
Let $H \subseteq T$.
Let $H^-$ denote the closure of $H$ and $H^\circ$ denote the interior of $H$.
Let $H^\prime$ denote the complement of $H$ in $T$:
:$H^\prime = T \setminus H$
Then:
:$H^\circ = H^{\prime \, - \, \prime}$

8400edf2-487d-4564-abc7-b914d69ab85c.text:
Let $\zeta$ be the Riemann zeta function.
Then
:$\ds \frac {\pi^{s / 2} } {\map \Gamma {\frac s 2}} \cdot \paren {- \frac 1 {s \paren{1 - s}} + \int_1^\infty \paren {x^{s / 2 - 1} + x^{- \paren {s + 1} / 2} } \map \omega x \rd x}$
defines an analytic continuation of $\zeta$ to the half-plane $\map \Re s > 0$ minus $s = 1$.

1f484f65-71eb-4e40-9c70-fb3a713d85a9.text:
Let $S$ be a sphere.
Let $\bigcirc FCD$ be a small circle on $S$.
Let $C$ and $D$ be the points on $\bigcirc FCD$ such that $CD$ is the arc of $\bigcirc FCD$ whose length is to be determined.

b19ec1d7-ad75-4235-afa1-4aba66785d43.text:
Let $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ be the real number line under the usual (Euclidean) topology.
 
Let $H_1 = \hointl a b$ and $H_2 = \hointr a b$ be half-open intervals of $\R$.
Then the closure of both $H_1$ and $H_2$ in $\R$ are the closed interval $\closedint a b$.

f68b8f22-c6dd-4bc3-b8e2-8adab6b9b252.text:
Let $S$ be a subset of the set of real numbers $\R$.
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $\map d {x, S}$ be the distance between $x$ and $S$.
Let $S$ be bounded below such that $\xi = \inf S$.
Then:
:$\map d {\xi, S} = 0$

76c0d21f-7cfd-483e-ba02-d41bcdffbe85.text: If a square matrix has a zero column, its determinant is zero.

e0c3c715-29ef-41b9-b6dd-2aeec9e1b3ad.text:
Multiplication modulo $m$ has an identity:
:$\forall \eqclass x m \in \Z_m: \eqclass x m \times_m \eqclass 1 m = \eqclass x m = \eqclass 1 m \times_m \eqclass x m$

69d85b5b-bc0f-463a-84cf-bb15c19af75d.text:
Let $\struct {\PP, \preceq}$ be a partially ordered set.
Then there exists a maximal chain in $\PP$.

4447614b-c7b4-44c5-8ff2-b6faee18363a.text:
Let $T_1 = \struct {S_1, \tau_1}$ be a topological space.
Let $S_2$ and $S_3$ be sets.
Let $f_1: S_1 \to S_2$ and $f_2: S_2 \to S_3$ be mappings.
Let $\tau_2$ be the identification topology on $S_2$ with respect to $f_1$ and $\tau_1$.
Let $\tau_3$ be the identification topology on $S_3$ with respect to $f_2$ and $\tau_2$.
Let $\phi: S_1 \to S_3$ be the composition of $f_2$ with $f_1$:
:$\phi = f_2 \circ f_1$
Then $\phi$ is itself an identification mapping.

d994b6c9-1f45-43fc-8774-a5ec079c0682.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Let $\iota: G \to G$ be the inversion mapping on $G$.
Then $\iota$ is indeed a mapping.

11e899fd-a36e-48bf-b54a-433301fb7927.text:
Let $T_A = \struct {X_A, \tau_A}$ be a topological space which is paracompact.
Let $T_B = \struct {X_B, \tau_B}$ be another topological space.
Let $\phi: T_A \to T_B$ be a mapping which is both continuous and open.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $T_B$ is also paracompact.

dabc444f-8b48-4d6f-ba8e-e2f2d764bb59.text:
Let $x$ be an ordinal.
Let $\card x$ denote the cardinal number of $x$.
Then:
:$x \sim \card x$
where $\sim$ denotes set equivalence.

725d2d32-83c5-4fb1-9f63-24f48228bec6.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma}$ be a measurable space.
Let $f: X \to \R$ be a simple function.
Then $f^+: X \to \R$, the positive part of $f$, is also a simple function.

76b36f75-381a-4c01-8995-7b22daac0a98.text:
Let $m, n \in \Z$ such that:
: $m \perp n$
that is, such that $m$ and $n$ are coprime.
Then:
:$\exists n' \in \Z: n n' \equiv 1 \pmod m$
where:
:$n' \equiv n^{\map \phi n - 1} \pmod m$
where $\map \phi n$ is the Euler $\phi$ function.

ec0eaf00-9182-4f66-a8c7-c6ecbbe54503.text: The center $\map Z G$ of any group $G$ is a normal subgroup of $G$ which is abelian.

617bcb4a-0322-4ace-be44-2801b7f27db9.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $R$ be an open ray in $\struct {S, \preceq}$.
Then $R$ is an open ray in $\struct {S, \succeq}$, where $\succeq$ is the dual ordering of $\preceq$.

312a0460-d6b2-48d7-aa28-65823f0a895c.text:
Let $\phi$ be a group homomorphism.
Then the kernel of $\phi$ is a normal subgroup of the domain of $\phi$:
:$\map \ker \phi \lhd \Dom \phi$

a6a5f04e-6836-4e92-8982-d11ca67a321b.text:
Let $R$ be a ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $\struct {\map {\MM_R} n, +, \times}$ denote the ring of square matrices of order $n$ over $R$.
The unit matrix over $R$:
:$\mathbf I_n = \begin {pmatrix} 1_R & 0_R & 0_R & \cdots & 0_R \\ 0_R & 1_R & 0_R & \cdots & 0_R \\ 0_R & 0_R & 1_R & \cdots & 0_R \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0_R & 0_R & 0_R & \cdots & 1_R \end {pmatrix}$
is the identity element of $\struct {\map {\MM_R} n, +, \times}$.

2c9f2b63-ff74-4267-8e05-9a5eec7c3544.text: :$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {\tanh a x} = a \sech^2 a x$

881344ad-c8d7-4eb9-b5ce-0ff69fe66a45.text:
Let $\struct {\Z, +, \times}$ be the integral domain of integers.
Let $\ideal 0$ be the principal ideal of $\struct {\Z, +, \times}$ generated by $0$.
The quotient ring $\struct {\Z / \ideal 0, +, \times}$ is isomorphic to $\struct {\Z, +, \times}$.

e6240abe-23de-422c-966f-25a2fc1b80ab.text:
Let $a = \tuple {a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n}$ and $b = \tuple {b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_n}$ be ordered tuples.
Then:
:$a = b \iff \forall i: 1 \le i \le n: a_i = b_i$
That is, for two ordered tuples to be equal, all the corresponding elements have to be equal.

d54c829c-c918-4ddd-b59b-c90c96a2538a.text:
The roots of the polynomial:
:$z^4 - 81$
are:
:$\set {3, 3 i, -3, -3 i}$

bca7d58d-ae60-4781-8956-f5b58c079743.text:
Let $\mathbb F \in \set {\R, \C}$.
Let $\HH$ be a Hilbert space over $\mathbb F$. 
Let $A : \HH \to \HH$ be a bounded Hermitian operator.
Let $\innerprod \cdot \cdot_\HH$ denote the inner product on $\HH$.
Suppose that:
:$\forall h \in \HH: \innerprod {A h} h_\HH = 0$
Then $A$ is the zero operator $\mathbf 0$.

19d8c799-b567-4a56-b681-75e62a7f7534.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n}$ be an algebraic structure.
Let:
:$\phi: \struct {S, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n} \to \struct {S, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n}$
:$\psi: \struct {S, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n} \to \struct {S, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n}$
be automorphisms.
Then the composite of $\phi$ and $\psi$ is also an automorphism.

11b39567-33b6-40c8-b642-d98a60572352.text:
Let $M = \struct {S, d}$ be a metric space or pseudometric space.
Let $p \in S$.
Let $\sequence {r_n}$ be a null sequence in $\R$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a sequence in $S$ such that:
:$\forall n \in \N: \map d {p, x_n} \le r_n$.
Then $\sequence {x_n}$ converges to $p$.

5a77f407-5831-4b9d-80f2-452f5811c809.text:
Let $\powerset S$ be the power set of a set $S$.
Let $\struct {\powerset S, \subseteq}$ be the set $\powerset S$ ordered by $\subseteq$.
Then $\struct {\powerset S, \subseteq}$ is totally ordered {{iff}} $S$ is either the empty set or a singleton.

d191f8ef-bf18-4008-bfee-5c28fe6a70ac.text:
Let $D$ be an open subset of the set of complex numbers $\C$.
Let $f: D \to \C$ be a complex-differentiable function on $D$.
Let $c \in \C$ be a constant.
Then:
:$\forall z \in D : \map {D_z} {c \map f z} = c \map {D_z} {\map f z}$

a7ad4e2c-16d0-4ddc-bfce-687b347ed638.text:
Let $G$ be a finite group.
Let $N$ be a normal subgroup of $G$.
Let $G / N$ be the quotient group of $G$ by $N$.
Then:
:$\dfrac {\order G} {\order N} = \order {G / N}$
where $\order G$ denotes the order of $G$.

d20712b0-3211-4032-9b70-e31b7ab03262.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let $J$ be an ideal of $R$.
Let $\struct {R / J, +, \circ}$ be the quotient ring of $R$ by $J$.
Then $+$ is well-defined on $R / J$, that is:
:$x_1 + J = x_2 + J, y_1 + J = y_2 + J \implies \paren {x_1 + y_1} + J = \paren {x_2 + y_2} + J$

bd1308fa-c924-4835-85f1-043742de025c.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{> 0}$ be a positive integer.
Let $I_n$ be defined as:
:$\ds I_n = \int_0^{\frac \pi 2} \sin^n x \rd x$
Then $\sequence {I_n}$ is a decreasing sequence of real numbers which satisfies:
:$n I_n = \paren {n - 1} I_{n - 2}$
Thus:
:$I_n = \dfrac {n - 1} n  I_{n - 2}$
is a reduction formula for $I_n$.

44e1f140-a861-451a-a9f9-9e8dcdd8287a.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=36|body=If two rational straight lines commensurable in square only be added together, the whole is irrational; and let it be called '''''binomial'''''.}}

8aa5e0ee-a3d2-4394-aea1-c999764fe5a3.text:
Let $\norm {\,\cdot\,}_p$ be the $p$-adic norm on the rationals $\Q$ for some prime number $p$.
Let $\size {\,\cdot\,}$ be the absolute value on the rationals $\Q$.
Then $\norm {\,\cdot\,}_p$ and $\size {\,\cdot\,}$ are not equivalent norms.
That is, the topology induced by $\norm {\,\cdot\,}_p$ does not equal the topology induced by $\size {\,\cdot\,}$.

2eab41bf-320c-42e1-8be1-684a43aaa482.text:
Let $\cos t$ be the cosine of $t$, where $t \in \R$.
Then $\cos t$ is of exponential order $0$.

72590e00-bd8f-476d-a1bb-9189175d3ce3.text: A sequentially compact topological space is also countably compact.

7e2c6943-5c93-44ea-84b7-2626eecb7fea.text:
Let $U_\C$ be the set of units of the Gaussian integers:
:$U_\C = \set {1, i, -1, -i}$
where $i$ is the imaginary unit: $i = \sqrt {-1}$.
Let $\struct {U_\C, \times}$ be the algebraic structure formed by $U_\C$ under the operation of complex multiplication.
Then $\struct {U_\C, \times}$ forms a cyclic group under complex multiplication.

820a6529-d130-4a83-a5a4-016dd4c74ae3.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$.
Then:
:$\ds {n + 1 \brace 1} = 1$
where $\ds {n + 1 \brace 1}$ denotes a Stirling number of the second kind.

f79b566c-62ba-4fa3-928d-11190e4ea994.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a strictly positive integer.
Let $b \in \Z_{>1}$ be an integer greater than $1$.
Let $n$ be expressed in base $b$.
Then the number of digits $d$ in this expression for $n$ is:
:$d = 1 + \floor {\log_b n}$
where:
:$\floor {\, \cdot \,}$ denotes the floor function
:$\log_b$ denotes the logarithm to base $b$.

b7846c2c-32fd-4771-9fb8-f6a18eccf920.text:
Let $\mathbb J = \set {x \in \R: a \le x \le b}$ be a closed interval of the real number line $\R$.
Let $\map \RR {\mathbb J}$ be the set of all Riemann integrable functions on $\mathbb J$.
Then $\struct {\map \RR {\mathbb J}, +, \times}_\R$ is a subspace of the $\R$-vector space $\struct {\R^{\mathbb J}, +, \times}_\R$.

31a1c59e-790d-4482-98ce-345e55924abe.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A, d_2}$ be metric spaces on the same underlying set $A$.
Let $I_A$ denote the identity mapping on $A$.
Then:
:$d_1$ and $d_2$ are topologically equivalent
{{iff}}:
:$I_A: M_1 \to M_2$ is a homeomorphism.

395a4299-d373-4f01-9379-d5c3aa473441.text:
:$\ds \int_0^\infty \frac {e^{-a x} \sin b x} x \rd x = \map \arctan {\frac b a}$
where $a$ and $b$ are real number with $a > 0$.

5683122f-090b-4064-914a-050aff86cf05.text:
Let $\sequence {s_n}$ be the sequence defined as:
:$s_n$ is the smallest positive integer the decimal expansion of whose reciprocal has a period of $n$
for $n = 0, 1, 2, \ldots$
Then $\sequence {s_n}$ begins:
:$1, 3, 11, 27, 101, 41, 7, 239, 73, 81, 451, \ldots$
{{OEIS|A003060}}

6aba559b-568b-4331-a4cc-bac4d9850c50.text:
There exist exactly $2$ Pythagorean triples which define a Pythagorean triangle whose area equals its perimeter:
:$(1): \quad \tuple {6, 8, 10}$, leading to an area and perimeter of $24$
:$(2): \quad \tuple {5, 12, 13}$, leading to an area and perimeter of $30$.

e1bff36a-6058-4160-bf29-5e4307063203.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the Arens-Fort space.
Then $T$ is not extremally disconnected.

81765949-01e3-4278-ad7b-9efb4bdf6713.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\prec$ be a strict ordering on $S$.
Let $\preceq$ be the reflexive closure of $\prec$.
Then $\preceq$ is an ordering.

ad8ab72d-3eb6-4d1b-ac7d-7b4e2776ad8b.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a commutative ring.
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be an integral subdomain of $R$.
Then $\forall x \in R$, the set $D \sqbrk x$ of polynomials in $x$ over $D$ is a subring of $R$.

7b3edf2f-f48c-4c07-b92e-4080c42a8a10.text: :$\ds \int e^{a x} \sin b x \rd x = \frac {e^{a x} \paren {a \sin b x - b \cos b x} } {a^2 + b^2} + C$

53dbff6d-1963-40e6-82fd-64828bd642fc.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_R$ be a unitary $R$-module such that $\map \dim G = n$.
Let $\struct {H, +_H, \circ}_R$ be a unitary $R$-module such that $\map \dim H = m$.
Let $\map {\LL_R} {G, H}$ be the set of all linear transformations from $G$ to $H$.
Then:
:$\map \dim {\map {\LL_R} {G, H} } = n m$
where $\map \dim {\map {\LL_R} {G, H} }$ denotes the dimension of $\map {\LL_R} {G, H}$.

d3c38523-5c3e-488a-8f99-53c0091b10a4.text:
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ be a sequence of strictly positive real numbers.
{{TFAE}}:
:$(1): \quad$ The infinite product $\ds \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n$ diverges to $+\infty$.
:$(2): \quad$ The series $\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \log a_n$ diverges to $+\infty$.

e427a481-f7a8-4759-831e-2a79ae371ca9.text:
The operation of multiplication on the set of complex numbers $\C$ is commutative:
:$\forall z_1, z_2 \in \C: z_1 z_2 = z_2 z_1$

964f866f-80ba-486f-84cf-20bc7786b23c.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a discrete topological space.
Let $A \subseteq S$.
Then:
:$\partial A = \O$
where:
:$\partial A$ is the boundary of $A$ in $T$.

d960d4a1-7441-419a-b43c-e85c1e65d932.text:
Let $\ds \struct {\SS, \circ} = \prod_{k \mathop = 1}^n S_k$ be the external direct product of the algebraic structures $\struct {S_1, \circ_1}, \struct {S_2, \circ_2}, \ldots, \struct {S_n, \circ_n}$.
Let $\tuple {x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n} \in S$.
Let $y_k$ be an inverse of $x_k$ in $\struct {S_k, \circ_k}$ for each of $k \in \N^*_n$.
Then $\tuple {y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_n}$ is the inverse of $\tuple {x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n} \in \SS$ in $\struct {\SS, \circ}$.

5e0593d5-675b-4cf7-9a0c-13e648ebe60b.text:
Let $T$ be a topological space, and let $H \subseteq T$.
Then $H$ is closed in $T$ {{iff}}:
:$\partial H \subseteq H$
where $\partial H$ is the boundary of $H$.

f0a083e1-2943-4820-b346-df422eaefc6c.text:
The equation:
:$1 + a^n = 2^m$
has no solutions in the integers for $n, m > 1$.
This is an elementary special case of Catalan's Conjecture.

a88edb27-d0bf-4f4e-b648-ecdde9c1cb33.text:
Let $a \in \R_{>0}$ be a strictly positive real constant.
Then:
:$\map \ln {\dfrac {a + x} {a - x} }$ is defined {{iff}} $\size x < a$
:$\map \ln {\dfrac {x + a} {x - a} }$ is defined {{iff}} $\size x > a$

78d90a59-ad0b-43dc-b280-f82970ee88fd.text:
Let $\closedint a b$ be a closed real interval.
Let $f$ be a bounded real function defined on $\closedint a b$.
Let $P$ and $Q$ be finite subdivisions of $\closedint a b$.
Let $\map L P$ be the lower sum of $f$ on $\closedint a b$ with respect to $P$.
Let $\map U Q$ be the upper sum of $f$ on $\closedint a b$ with respect to $Q$.
Then $\map L P \le \map U Q$.

31c56551-6cc4-4170-b3d2-64c1176f7ade.text:
The set of spheres in real Cartesian $3$-dimensional space can be described by the system of partial differential equations:
:$\dfrac {1 + z_x^2} {z_{xx} } = \dfrac {z_x z_x} {z_{xy} } = \dfrac {1 + z_y^2} {z_{yy} }$
and if the spheres are expected to be real:
:$z_{xx} z_{yy} > z_{xy}$

0013da41-20df-4a8d-99d8-dee5464513b2.text:
Let $f : \R \to \R$ be a real function.
Let $a \in \R$ be  real number.
Let $f$ be continuous on $\R$ and continuously differentiable in $\R \setminus \set a$.
Suppose that $a$ is a removable discontinuity of $f'$.
That is, suppose the limit $\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to a} \map {f'} x$ exists.
Then $f$ is continuously differentiable at $a$.

dedfa996-314c-45fb-addc-d94af6888310.text:
:$\ds \int \frac {\rd x} {p^2 - q^2 \cos^2 a x} = \begin {cases}
\dfrac 1 {a p \sqrt {p^2 - q^2} } \arctan \dfrac {p \tan a x} {\sqrt {p^2 - q^2} } & : p^2 > q^2 \\
\dfrac 1 {2 a p \sqrt {q^2 - p^2} } \ln \size {\dfrac {p \tan a x - \sqrt {q^2 - p^2} } {p \tan a x + \sqrt {q^2 - p^2} } } & : p^2 < q^2
\end {cases}$

f8d1d043-1ce0-47cb-a809-8506623c43b5.text:
:$\ds \int \frac {x^2 \rd x} {\paren {\sqrt {x^2 - a^2} }^3} = \frac {-x} {\sqrt {x^2 - a^2} } + \ln \size {x + \sqrt {x^2 - a^2} } + C$
for $\size x > a$.

a8222921-451d-4555-9611-d5ac88f4e885.text:
Let $\mathbf A$ be a square matrix of order $n$.
Then:
:$(1): \quad \ds \sum_{j \mathop = 1}^n \delta_{i j} a_{j k} = a_{i k}$
:$(2): \quad \ds \sum_{j \mathop = 1}^n \delta_{i j} a_{k j} = a_{k i}$
where:
:$\delta_{i j}$ is the Kronecker delta
:$a_{j k}$ is element $\tuple {j, k}$ of $\mathbf A$.

a424fc68-dc6d-4f40-8b04-8d3a834943a6.text:
:$\dbinom {k_1 + k_2 + \cdots + k_m} {k_1, k_2, \ldots, k_m} = \dbinom {k_1 + k_2} {k_1} \dbinom {k_1 + k_2 + k_3} {k_1 + k_2} \cdots \dbinom {k_1 + k_2 + \cdots + k_m} {k_1 + k_2 + \cdots + k_{m - 1} }$
where:
:$\dbinom {k_1 + k_2 + \cdots + k_m} {k_1, k_2, \ldots, k_m}$ denotes a multinomial coefficient
:$\dbinom {k_1 + k_2} {k_1}$ etc. denotes binomial coefficients.

379ffa28-7e04-4d78-bf25-3ede1c574ab5.text: :$\ds \int \frac {x \rd x} {1 + \sin a x} = -\frac x a \map \tan {\frac \pi 4 - \frac {a x} 2} + \frac 2 {a^2} \ln \size {\map \sin {\frac \pi 4 + \frac {a x} 2} } + C$

0c0a0df1-7d82-489f-9048-8421491e3819.text: The operation of multiplication on the set of real numbers $\R$ is well-defined.

352ec378-f8a4-4d9c-81b3-4ac8dd219ff4.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $a \in S$ and $T \subseteq S$.
The following are dual statements:
:$a$ is an upper bound for $T$
:$a$ is a lower bound for $T$

6be0db58-0d0f-4b69-9d39-2a7f402a8eaa.text:
Let $F$ be a field whose characteristic is $p$ where $p \ne 0$.
Let $n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$ be any positive integer.
Let $\phi_n: F \to F$ be the mapping on $F$ defined as:
:$\forall x \in F: \map {\phi_n} x = x^{p^n}$
Then $\phi_n$ is a (field) monomorphism.

7cee4e5d-2d24-47dc-941e-0f3f361c82ff.text:
Let the real number line $\R$ be considered as a topology under the usual (Euclidean) topology.
Then:
:$\BB := \set {\openint \gets a, \openint b \to: a, b \in \R}$ is a sub-basis for $\R$.

ef02f0d0-dbe0-402d-904b-96f1406fda3c.text:
Let $S \subseteq \N$ be a subset of the natural numbers $\N$.
Let $\struct {S, \max}$ denote the algebraic structure formed from $S$ and the max operation.
Then $\struct {S, \max}$ is a monoid.
Its identity element is the smallest element of $S$.

dcee7ea1-a2e1-4392-9cb2-fc42b34ca23d.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $a \in A$.
Let $\map {B_\epsilon} a$ be an open $\epsilon$-ball of $a$ in $M$.
Let $x \in \map {B_\epsilon} a$.
Then $\map {B_\epsilon} a$ is a neighborhoods of $x$ in $M$.

ba0e6294-c831-40f4-a8bf-f84da52bcf81.text: The class $\NN$ of all cardinal numbers is a proper class.

cb33ddad-ad72-4675-87f0-a3c4c60db6a9.text:
Let $A$, $B$, $C$, and $D$ be sets or classes.
Let $A \cap B = C \cap D = \O$.
Let $f: A \to C$ and $g: D \to B$ be bijections.
Then $f \cup g^{-1}: A \cup B \to C \cup D$ is also a bijection.

7ce5c4a4-91ba-4b4f-94a9-8cb6ca03862c.text: :The function $\map f x = \exp x$ is strictly increasing.

fdd43c9a-5a36-45b8-95a5-16098593bdfd.text:
Let $\struct {R, \norm {\, \cdot \,} }$ be a normed division ring.
Let $\CC$ be the ring of Cauchy sequences over $R$.
Let $\NN$ be the set of null sequences.
That is:
:$\NN = \set {\sequence {x_n}: \displaystyle \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n = 0 }$
Then $\NN$ is a ring ideal of $\CC$ that is a maximal left ideal and a maximal right ideal.

17643ba1-203e-49fd-8973-9947c642d1d4.text:
Let $\family {X_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be a family of sets where $I$ is an arbitrary index set.
Let $\ds X = \prod_{i \mathop \in I} X_i$ be the Cartesian product of $\family {X_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$.
Let $z \in X$.
Let $i \in I$. 
Let $Y_i = \set {x \in X: \forall j \in I \setminus \set i: x_j = z_j}$.
Let $p_i = \pr_i {\restriction_{Y_i}}$, where $\pr_i$ is the projection from $X$ to $X_i$.
Then:
:$p_i$ is an injection.

a5581938-da24-41b8-98e8-4f30e125625a.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be non-empty sets.
Let $S \times T$ be the Cartesian product of $S$ and $T$.
Let $\pr_1: S \times T \to T$ and $\pr_2: S \times T \to T$ be the first projection and second projection respectively on $S \times T$.
Then $\pr_1$ and $\pr_2$ are both surjections.

1cdc4c4f-0b95-485a-8153-e9b69e3c9907.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $\floor x$ be the floor of $x$, and $\ceiling x$ be the ceiling of $x$.
Then:
:$\ceiling {-x} = -\floor x$

b501c2d0-66a3-435d-8e02-26727e8a3e8e.text:
Let $S$ be a set and let $\PP$ be a partition on $S$ which is not the (trivial) partition of singletons.
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the partition space whose basis is $\PP$.
Then $T$ is a $T_5$ space.

36db1468-9225-4119-a259-9b71a7b70589.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$ be a non-negative integer.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_k \dbinom {r + t k} k \dbinom {s - t k} {n - k} = \sum_{k \mathop \ge 0} \dbinom {r + s - k} {n - k} t^k$
where $\dbinom {r + t k} k$ and so on denotes a binomial coefficient.

41b99688-da0a-4751-ae80-071e5b0b181c.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\struct {\map \Gamma S, \circ}$ be the symmetric group on $S$.
Let $*: \map \Gamma S \times S \to S$ be the group action defined as:
:$\forall \pi \in \map \Gamma S, \forall s \in S: \pi * s = \map \pi s$
Then $*$ is a transitive group action.
In other words, $\struct {\map \Gamma S, \circ}$ acts transitively on $S$ by $*$.

ea02b944-4984-4321-ae7b-474dc5531ef7.text: A straight lines has zero curvature.

eae205f4-04ef-47bf-af01-9d0eeacda23b.text:
Let:
:$\struct {S_1 \times S_2, \circ}$ be the external direct product of two algebraic structures $\struct {S_1, \circ_1}$ and $\struct {S_2, \circ_2}$
:$\struct {T_1 \times T_2, *}$ be the external direct product of two algebraic structures $\struct {T_1, *_1}$ and $\struct {T_2, *_2}$
:$\phi_1$ be an isomorphism from $\struct {S_1, \circ_1}$ onto $\struct {T_1, *_1}$
:$\phi_2$ be an isomorphism from $\struct {S_2, \circ_2}$ onto $\struct {T_2, *_2}$.
Then the mapping $\phi_1 \times \phi_2: \struct {S_1 \times S_2, \circ} \to \struct {T_1 \times T_2, *}$ defined as:
