:$\map {\paren {\phi_1 \times \phi_2} } {x, y} = \tuple {\map {\phi_1} x, \map {\phi_2} y}$
is an isomorphism from $\struct {S_1 \times S_2, \circ}$ to $\struct {T_1 \times T_2, *}$.

ac7c6f61-fcb7-4731-9ac9-8875411eee07.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\BB$ be a synthetic basis on $S$.
Let $\tau$ be the topology on $S$ generated by the synthetic basis $\BB$:
:$\ds \tau = \set {\bigcup \AA: \AA \subseteq \BB}$
Then:
:$\forall U \subseteq S: U \in \tau \iff \forall x \in U: \exists B \in \BB: x \in B \subseteq U$

0a1099b9-aac1-4305-854c-756e8e80f0c3.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Then $M$ is a completely normal space.

75b3ea27-21c1-4be9-9110-84a13443caf4.text:
Let $\N_{>0}$ be the set of natural numbers without zero, i.e. $\N_{>0} = \N \setminus \set 0$.
The structure $\struct {\N_{>0}, +}$ does ''not'' form a monoid.

3fb6f48e-8d2b-43d6-b11b-f90a5af2b0f8.text:
Let $E$ be a field.
Let $G \le \Aut E$ be a subgroup of its automorphism group.
Let $F = \map {\operatorname {Fix}_E} G$ be its fixed field.
Let $\alpha \in E$ have a finite orbit under $G$.
Then $\alpha$ is separable over $F$.

a5ff3570-8f20-4e7d-b4e7-4f3f061c95ac.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Then there exists a prime number $q$ such that:
:$p < q \le p! + 1$
where $p!$ denotes the factorial of $p$.

a530f04c-5647-4ef8-9843-e9ac6f786bf2.text: Two prime groups of the same order are isomorphic to each other.

a313c965-9a44-4c56-8065-1014ea85971d.text:
Let $a, b \in \Z: a b \ne 0$.
The lowest common multiple of $a$ and $b$, denoted $\lcm \set {a, b}$, always exists.

a4b7f6c8-7302-40ae-a117-e045b20e57e7.text:
Let $f$ be a differentiable real function such that $f$ is even.
Then its derivative $f'$ is an odd function.

529aff1e-92ef-45d7-8d2d-3ed2cb79be5c.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \preceq}$ be a lattice.
Let $X$ be a subset of $S$.
Then
:$X$ is a prime filter in $L$
{{iff}}:
:$X$ is a prime ideal in $L^{-1}$
where $L^{-1} = \struct {S, \succeq}$ denotes the dual of $L$.

b6663f94-9cd0-4109-be68-7992ff7de726.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\powerset S$ be the power set of $S$.
Let $\BB \subset \powerset S$.
Then:
:$\FF = \set {V \subseteq S: \exists U \in \BB: U \subseteq V}$ is a filter on $S$
{{iff}}:
:$(1): \quad \forall V_1, V_2 \in \BB: \exists U \in \BB: U \subseteq V_1 \cap V_2$
:$(2): \quad \O \notin \BB, \BB \ne \O$
That is, $\BB$ is a filter basis of the filter $\FF$, which is generated by $\BB$.

1bd56c0a-11c5-4a0c-8829-fe9a828676ff.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
The intersection of the set difference of $S$ and $T$ with $T$ is the empty set:
:$\paren {S \setminus T} \cap T = \O$

12c207d7-9f20-4c52-9291-f62eda788318.text: The complex cosine function is unbounded.

3719afb6-b9ec-45ed-839a-b52fd34657e9.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $H_1, H_2 \le G$.
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be the internal group direct product of $H_1$ and $H_2$.
Then:
:$\forall h_1 \in H_1, h_2 \in H_2: h_1 \circ h_2 = h_2 \circ h_1$

18df8421-3d44-4628-9b61-fee749644aba.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $a \in A$ be a point in $M$.
Let $N$ be a neighborhood of $a$ in $M$.
Let $N \subseteq N' \subseteq A$.
Then $N'$ is a neighborhood of $a$ in $M$.

5fe94369-c96e-4cb7-ada0-854c27b1fbac.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number such that $x > 0$.
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer such that $n < 0$.
Then there is at most one $y \in \R: y \ge 0$ such that $y^n = x$.

e45fe866-bd72-4062-96eb-168719d2786f.text:
Let $T = \struct {\CC, \tau_d}$ be the Cantor space.
Then $T$ is not extremally disconnected.

ec80d1fb-c2bf-4aa9-adc2-bfd24cbcf9b7.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \preceq}, R = \struct {T, \precsim}$ be ordered sets.
Let $g: S \to T, d: T \to S$ be mappings such that
:$\forall t \in T: \map d t = \min \set {g^{-1} \sqbrk {\set t} }$
Then $g \circ d = I_T$
where $I_T$ denotes the identity mapping of $T$.

cdcb6118-66aa-4209-a0cf-8c4eeae46c94.text:
Let $a, b, c \in \Z$.
Let $a \divides b c$, where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.
Let $a \perp b$, where $\perp$ denotes relative primeness.
Then $a \divides c$.

0995a88f-47d9-434e-bd47-f6ffd1d2437b.text:
Let $f$ and $g$ be functions holomorphic on some region containing $a$. 
Let $g$ have a zero of multiplicity $1$ at $a$. 
Then:
:$\Res {\dfrac f g} a = \dfrac {\map f a} {\map {g'} a}$
{{explain|definition of "Res", by a link to Residue}}

c7995d13-48dd-4bba-b02c-322c2c8cb3de.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a particular point space.
Then $T$ is first-countable.

05248f15-9a68-4288-a741-8cac801f26a2.text:
Let $S \subset \R$ be a proper subset of the set $\R$ of real numbers.
Let $S$ admit a supremum $M$.
Then $M$ may or may not be an element of $S$.

6b198e0b-d9dd-47b4-ad89-4e88d4ae7d2d.text:
Let $c$ be a common divisor of a set of integers $A := \set {a_1, a_2, \dotsc, a_n}$.
That is:
:$\forall x \in A: c \divides x$
Then $c$ divides any integer combination of elements of $A$:
:$\forall x_1, x_2, \dotsc, x_n \in \Z: c \divides \paren {a_1 x_2 + a_2 x_2 + \dotsb + a_n x_n}$

d98675de-e09b-43a2-8812-e7aa2c308a4f.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $G$ be a mapping such that $\map G x = x \cup \bigcup x$.
{{explain|Domain and range of $G$ needed}}
Let $F$ be defined using the Principle of Recursive Definition:
:$\map F 0 = S$
:$\map F {n^+} = \map G {\map F n}$
Let $\ds T = \bigcup_{n \mathop \in \omega} \map F n$.
Then:
:$T$ is a set and is transitive
:$S \subseteq T$
:If $R$ is transitive and $S \subseteq R$, then $T \subseteq R$.
That is, given any set $S$, there is an explicit construction for its transitive closure.

c1b0d8a9-e02f-472f-8868-14849948e016.text:
Let $\alpha$ denote the relation defined on the natural numbers $\N$ by:
:$\forall x, y \in \N: x \mathrel \alpha y \iff \exists n \in \Z: x = 2^n y$
We have that $\alpha$ is an equivalence relation.
Let $c, d \in \N$ such that $c \mathrel \alpha d$.
Then either:
:$c \divides d$
or:
:$d \divides c$
where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.

07112b51-e715-4897-82c6-890f7e80e45f.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological spaces.
Let $H$ and $K$ be compact subsets of $T$.
Then $H \cup K$ is compact in $T$.

866e0a71-e98d-4cf4-9201-46cb1dbc3efc.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets such that $T \ne \O$.
Let $S \times T$ denote their cartesian product.
Let $t \in T$ be given.
Let $j_t: S \to S \times T$ be the injection from $S$ to $S \times T$ defined as:
:$\forall s \in S: \map {j_t} s = \tuple {s, t}$
Let $W \subseteq S \times T$.
Let $V = {j_t}^{-1} \sqbrk W$ denote the preimage of $W$ under $j_t$.
Then:
:$V = \set {s \in S : \tuple {s, t} \in W}$

166086ef-bb4e-448e-b346-bbf28f32c2c7.text: There exist irrational numbers $a$ and $b$ such that $a^b$ is rational.

18f75010-f317-4c17-8fbe-35e0fde15046.text:
Recall the generalised pentagonal numbers $GP_n$ for $n = 0, 1, 2, \ldots$
Consider the sequence defined as $\Delta_n = GP_{n + 1} - GP_n$:
:$1, 1, 3, 2, 5, 3, 7, 4, 9, 5, 11, 6, 13, 7, 15, 8, \ldots$
{{OEIS|A026741}}
Then:
:The values of $\Delta_n$ for odd $n$ consist of the odd numbers
:The values of $\Delta_n$ for even $n$ consist of the natural numbers.

c3c42686-7866-44c8-8186-29ff9f375de2.text: The following definitions of the distance to nearest integer function $\norm \cdot: \R \to \closedint 0 {\dfrac 1 2}$ are equivalent:

9b88df49-52f3-4fe3-b845-09f08c656eeb.text:
Let $\phi: \struct {F_1, +_1, \times_1} \to \struct {F_2, +_2, \times_2}$ be a field homomorphism.
Then:
:$\forall x \in F_1^*: \map \phi {x^{-1} } = \map \phi x^{-1}$

113b0089-29a5-428b-8b59-42ad3fd8d5d0.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a totally ordered set. 
Let $x, y \in S$.
Then:
:$\map \min {x, y} = \map \inf {\set {x, y} }$
where:
:$\min$ denotes the min operation
:$\inf$ denotes the infimum.

33ee6c40-4c14-4c5f-881d-d50570e8b5e9.text: The algebraic structure $\struct {\N, +}$ consisting of the set of natural numbers $\N$ under addition $+$ is not a group.

95ff4a3d-2980-4c13-a990-1408445ddf56.text:
Let $V$ be a basic universe
Then $V$ is not the empty class.

16450142-8c6c-49ac-a941-ba09f40e8a05.text:
Let $T = \left({S, \preceq, \tau}\right)$ be a complete topological lattice with Scott topology.
Then $T$ is a $T_0$ space.

add4b9da-62e7-43fb-89a9-76462287a58b.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\chi_S: S \to \set {0, 1}$ be its characteristic function (in itself).
Then:
:$\chi_S = f_1$
where $f_1: S \to \set {0, 1}$ is the constant mapping with value $1$.

a5187f0b-7b3a-4ca6-922c-0cf1dc6e376b.text:
Let $\N_{> 0}$ be the $1$-based natural numbers.
Let $\times$ denote multiplication on $\N_{>0}$.
Let $<$ be the strict ordering on $\N_{>0}$.
Then:
:$\forall a, b, n \in \N_{>0}: a < b \implies a \times n < b \times n$
That is, $<$ is compatible with $\times$ on $\N_{>0}$.

1aecd83f-a23f-4111-b1a4-c7a7ab572088.text:
Let $c \in \R$ be a constant.
Let $f: \N \to \R$ denotes the mapping defined as:
:$\forall n \in \N: \map f n = c^k$
where $k$ is number of distinct primes that divide $n$.
Then $f$ is multiplicative.

4c7f69d1-c4f0-4988-b7af-e6d33ab26f8c.text:
Let $K$ be a division ring.
Let $G$ be a finitely generated $K$-vector space.
Then any two bases of $G$ are finite and equivalent.

21b7dfdb-5388-497d-bb92-adbe6e5ac141.text:
:$\ds \forall n \in \Z: \sum_{i \mathop = 0}^n \paren {-1}^i \binom n i = \delta_{n 0}$
where:
:$\dbinom n i$ is a binomial coefficient
:$\delta_{n 0}$ denotes the Kronecker delta.

20665196-f268-42d1-b63c-aef9f668e7bb.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $x_1, x_2, \dotsc, x_n \in S$ for some $n \in \N_{>0}$.
Then:
:$\exists i \in \closedint 1 n : x_i = \max \set {x_1, x_2, \dotsc, x_n}$
where:
:$\max$ denotes the max operation.

aa81992a-6f9c-4784-a2d7-684ae3f4654c.text:
Lrt $L = \left({S, \vee, \preceq}\right)$ be a bounded below join semilattice.
Then
:$\ll$ is auxiliary relation
where $\ll$ denotes the way below relation.

3c2c0bc9-1702-457b-8fd2-94496da4cd4c.text:
Let $\RR$ be a relation on a set $S$.
If $\RR$ is antireflexive, then so is $\RR^{-1}$.

d7c35c68-801e-4dc2-a021-b5d2d33c80de.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group which has an identity element $e \in G$.
Then $e$ is unique.

388da442-f94f-43f9-a2dc-f130c080e277.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a well-ordered set.
Let:
:$A = \set {a^\prec: a \in S}$
where $a^\prec$ is the strict lower closure of $S$ determined by $a$.
Then:
:$\struct {S, \preceq} \cong \struct {A, \subseteq}$
where $\cong$ denotes order isomorphism.

57bb6817-05b7-41d7-827d-982d7c4263da.text: Every reflexive relation is also a serial relation.

3a51ddb4-3064-460b-b552-5c27691baab0.text:
Let $\N_{> 0}$ be the $1$-based natural numbers.
Let $+$ be addition on $\N_{>0}$.
Then:
:$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a + c = b + c \implies a = b$
:$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a + b = a + c \implies b = c$
That is, $+$ is cancellable on $\N_{>0}$.

58c03c5a-ce8c-4fe0-aa68-cbf38b41b5ab.text:
Let $A$ be a countable set.
Then the set of finite subsets of $A$ is countable.

cba1340b-4370-4bf4-8420-5246feae33e5.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a positive integer.
Then the $n$th cyclotomic polynomial $\map {\Phi_n} x$ has integer coefficients.

77162e30-59c2-496f-894d-8c4844885281.text:
:$\ds \map \zeta 2 = \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty {\frac 1 {n^2} } = \frac {\pi^2} 6$
where $\zeta$ denotes the Riemann zeta function.

be5104ae-688a-46a2-8667-0c85054987f1.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $a \in \Q_p$.
For all $\epsilon \in \R_{>0}$:
:let $\map { {B_\epsilon}^-} a$ denote the closed $\epsilon$-ball of $a$
and:
:let $\map {B_\epsilon} a$ denote the open $\epsilon$-ball of $a$. 
Then:
:$(1): \quad \forall n \in Z : \map {B^-_{p^{-n} } } a = \ds \bigcup_{i \mathop = 0}^{p - 1} \map {B_{p^{-n} } } {a + i p^n}$
:$(2): \quad \forall n \in Z : \set {\map {B_{p^{-n} } } {a + i p^n} : i = 0, \dotsc, p - 1}$ is a set of pairwise disjoint open balls.

a3b3b46f-6823-4a3f-bc12-358853eaa8c0.text:
Let $\sgn_\Z: \Z \to \set {-1, 0, 1}$ be the signum function on the integers.
Let $\sgn_\N: \N \to \set {0, 1}$ be the signum function on the natural numbers.
Then $\sgn_\Z: \Z \to \Z$ is an extension of $\sgn_\N: \N \to \N$.

30d2868d-e53d-4b36-b584-dc805ec1809d.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a totally ordered set. 
Let $x, y \in S$.
Then:
:$\max \set {x, y} = \sup \set {x, y}$
where:
:$\max$ denotes the max operation
:$\sup$ denotes the supremum.

20121840-436d-4a4d-b5dc-30c3c32b4b60.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set such that:
:$\forall T \subseteq S: \exists a \in T: \forall x \in T: a \preceq x$
That is, such that $\preceq$ is a well-ordering by definition 1.
Then $\preceq$ is a total ordering.

4876afac-8b0e-46ae-adc5-b109432dd576.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space which is both totally disconnected and locally connected.
Then $T$ is the discrete space on $S$.

85f2c19e-7599-4d97-a84f-5f7e1e39a75b.text:
Let $G$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $a \in G$ have finite order such that $\order a = k$.
Then:
:$\forall n \in \Z: n = q k + r: 0 \le r < k \iff a^n = a^r$

059b9b36-39d9-4f3f-8dcd-d841293267a6.text: :$\dfrac 1 {x^3 + a^3} = \dfrac 1 {3 a^2 \paren {x + a} } - \dfrac {x - 2 a} {3 a^2 \paren {x^2 - a x + a^2} }$

3cf9622c-ef5c-44e8-809f-70b7c4964040.text: The set of rational numbers $\Q$ does not form a discrete space.

f0b171e7-fffe-4c64-bf7e-aa8b30242fff.text:
Let $S$ be a finite set whose cardinality is $n$:
:$\card S = n$
Let $T$ be a non-empty set
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Then:
:$\card f = n$

47f4199a-9109-402c-8298-55ddc4749eb8.text: If two square matrices of order $n > 1$ over a ring with unity $R$ are equivalent, they are not necessarily similar.

2205f06f-e037-4da1-8cca-22c0a057637e.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be an additive function which is not linear.
Then the graph of $f$ is dense in the real number plane.

7db58431-51a8-4492-9f3e-c2fe36c02a84.text:
Let $z_1$ and $z_2$ be complex numbers.
Then:
:$\overline {z_1} z_2 = \cmod {z_1} \, \cmod {z_2} e^{i \theta}$
where:
:$\overline {z_1}$ denotes the complex conjugate of $z_1$
:$\cmod {z_1}$ denotes the complex modulus of $z_1$
:$\theta$ denotes the angle from $z_1$ to $z_2$, measured in the positive direction.

21743a22-8e72-46f0-af9a-3845adf4b464.text: The magic constant of the order $4$ magic square is $34$.

44307424-0b81-479a-9e8d-b42508bed16b.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\alpha \subseteq S \times S$ be a relation on $S$.
Let $\alpha$ be both symmetric and transitive.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $\alpha$ is also reflexive.

21ce25c6-c71a-4542-ad92-0c0ff101de76.text: The integers $\Z$ form an integral domain under addition and multiplication.

3c92e34b-2944-423d-bacf-3bc44c1d060a.text:
Let $\EE$ be an experiment with a probability space $\struct {\Omega, \Sigma, \Pr}$.
The event space $\Sigma$ of $\EE$ has the property that:
:$A, B \in \Sigma \implies A \ast B \in \Sigma$
That is, the symmetric difference of two events is also an event in the event space.

d79105cd-f16c-4764-bdc8-3e2866d96dd8.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Then $\struct {G, \circ}$ is a quasigroup.

9a504fec-1734-4aa1-890c-caf09d70976a.text:
Let $x \in \Q$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be the sequence in $\Q$ defined as $x_n = x^n$.
Then:
:$\size x < 1$ {{iff}} $\sequence {x_n}$ is a null sequence.

d90371b4-d8af-4535-bc71-aae54568189b.text:
Let $m \in \Z$ be an integer.
Let $m \Z$ denote the set of integer multiples of $m$.
Then $m \Z$ is an integral ideal.

4f056931-56b9-4681-ae7f-8666d7f95ea9.text:
Let $S$ be a subset of the set of real numbers $\R$.
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $\map d {x, S}$ be the distance between $x$ and $S$.
Let $I \subseteq \R$ be an open real interval such that $I \ne \O$ and $I \ne \R$.
Then:
:$\exists x \notin I: \map d {x, I} = 0$

7fa2112a-2ba2-485c-bf95-c9ef059759b0.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $T$ be such that there are no two non-empty separated sets whose union is $S$.
Then there exists no continuous surjection from $T$ onto a discrete two-point space.

88190835-1903-4497-87c1-52366fb55ee5.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $\struct {R_n, \times}$ be the complex $n$th roots of unity under complex multiplication.
Let $\struct {\Z_n, +_n}$ be the integers modulo $n$ under modulo addition.
Then $\struct {R_n, \times}$ and $\struct {\Z_n, +_n}$ are isomorphic algebraic structures.

cec694ca-e11c-48ce-992c-37b5628dc53f.text:
Let $a$ and $b$ be real numbers.
Let $i$ be the imaginary unit.
Then:
:$\tan \paren {a + b i} = \dfrac {\sin 2 a + i \sinh 2 b} {\cos 2 a + \cosh 2 b}$
where:
:$\tan$ denotes the complex tangent function
:$\sin$ denotes the real sine function
:$\cos$ denotes the real cosine function
:$\sinh$ denotes the hyperbolic sine function
:$\cosh$ denotes the hyperbolic cosine function.

78c7d453-66ee-4c2d-920c-dd23e67cdcb5.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be a real function.
Let $F$ be a primitive of $f$ that is bounded on all of $\R$.
Let $f$ be periodic with period $L$.
Then $F$ is also periodic with period $L$.

6d625184-3db8-47da-ac59-2b6b1f0e5c3f.text:
Let $\struct {F, +_F, \circ}$ be a field whose zero is $0_F$.
Let $\struct {S, +_S, *}$ be a ring whose zero is $0_S$.
Let $\phi: F \to S$ be a ring homomorphism.
Then either:
:$(1): \quad \phi$ is a monomorphism (that is, $\phi$ is injective)
or
:$(2): \quad \phi$ is the zero homomorphism (that is, $\forall a \in F: \map \phi a = 0_S$).

a22fd358-eb4b-4013-b061-9ff701bc8688.text:
Let $\map \MM {m, n}$ be a $m \times n$ matrix space over one of the standard number systems.
For $\mathbf A, \mathbf B \in \map \MM {m, n}$, let $\mathbf A + \mathbf B$ be defined as the matrix entrywise sum of $\mathbf A$ and $\mathbf B$.
The operation $+$ is commutative on $\map \MM {m, n}$.
That is:
:$\mathbf A + \mathbf B = \mathbf B + \mathbf A$
for all $\mathbf A$ and $\mathbf B$ in $\map \MM {m, n}$.

5676a0f5-c420-452a-ae3b-27c1142845dd.text:
Let $\closedint a b \subseteq \R$ be a closed real interval.
Let $\mathscr C \closedint a b$ be the set of all continuous functions $f: \closedint a b \to \R$.
Let $\map {\mathscr B} {\closedint a b, \R}$ be the set of all bounded real functions $f: \closedint a b \to \R$.
Let $d$ be the supremum metric on $\map {\mathscr B} {\closedint a b, \R}$.
Then $\struct {\mathscr C \closedint a b, d_{\mathscr C} }$ is a subspace of $\struct {\map {\mathscr B} {\closedint a b, \R}, d}$.

319c2e73-f321-4f97-81fc-45501c8a656b.text:
Let $\struct {\Z, +}$ denote the additive group of integers.
Let $n \Z$ be the set of integer multiples of $n$.
Then $\struct {n \Z, +}$ is a subgroup of $\struct {\Z, +}$.
Hence $\struct {n \Z, +}$ can be justifiably referred to as the additive group of integer multiples.

5d856134-b148-4232-a693-eb0c76ae0730.text:
Let $\RR_1, \RR_2, \ldots \RR_n$ be relations.
Let $\SS_1, \SS_2, \ldots \SS_m$ be operations.
Let $T$ be a small class.
Let the image of $\RR_i$ over any small class $x$ be small classes for $1 \le i \le n$.
Let the image of $\SS_i$ over any Cartesian product $x \times x$ be small classes for $1 \le i \le m$.
Then there exists a small class $X$ such that:
:$(1): \quad$ $T \subseteq X$
:$(2): \quad$ Each $\RR_i$ is closed with respect to $X$.  Each $\SS_i$ is closed with respect to $X \times X$.
:$(3): \quad$ $X$ is the smallest small class satisfying conditions $(1)$ and $(2)$ above.
If $Y$ satisfies conditions $(1)$ and $(2)$, then $X \subseteq Y$.

67e1c64c-e7db-4424-981c-7353f4413b88.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma, \mu}$ be a measure space.
Let $f: X \to \overline \R$ be a $\mu$-integrable function.
Let $\lambda \in \R$.
Let $\lambda f$ be the pointwise $\lambda$-multiple of $f$.
Then $\lambda f$ is $\mu$-integrable, and:
:$\ds \int \lambda f \rd \mu = \lambda \int f \rd \mu$

9e1a4dbd-4216-4226-95e7-ec8eec12d417.text:
Let $F_n = 2^{\left({2^n}\right)} + 1$ be the $n$th Fermat number.
Let $k \in \Z_{>0}$.
Then:
:$F_{n + k} - 1 = \left({F_n - 1}\right)^{2^k}$

517f08a8-43ad-4ec4-b46b-9b95a4f71a9a.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring whose zero is $0_R$.
Let $\struct {\set {0_R}, +, \circ}$ be the null ideal of $\struct {R, +, \circ}$.
Let $\struct {R / \set {0_R}, +, \circ}$ be the quotient ring of $R$ defined by $\set {0_R}$.
Then $\struct {R / \set {0_R}, +, \circ}$ is isomorphic to $\struct {R, +, \circ}$.

db1b3d17-0ab6-4656-ac2f-fad5877adf64.text:
Let $H_n$ be the Hilbert matrix of order $n$:
:$\begin{bmatrix} a_{i j} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \dfrac 1 {i + j - 1} \end{bmatrix}$
Then its inverse $H_n^{-1} = \sqbrk b_n$ can be specified as:
:$\begin{bmatrix} b_{i j} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \dfrac {\paren {-1}^{i + j} \paren {i + n - 1}! \paren {j + n - 1}!} {\paren {\paren {i - 1}!}^2 \paren {\paren {j - 1}!}^2 \paren {n - j}! \paren {n - i}! \paren {i + j - 1} } \end{bmatrix}$

a02adcd8-e292-4b8b-9e45-e46c9f8b4468.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
{{TFAENocat|def = Symmetric Difference|view = symmetric difference $S \symdif T$ between $S$ and $T$}}

43339caa-a833-4af5-96f5-75ac02d400bb.text:
:$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\paren {a^2 - x^2}^2} = \frac x {2 a^2 \paren {a^2 - x^2} } + \frac 1 {4 a^3} \map \ln {\frac {a + x} {a - x} } + C$
for $x^2 < a^2$.

2851b97e-f040-4340-89c6-8b10c0e7181d.text:
Let $\struct {\R^{2 \times2}, \norm {\, \cdot \,}_\infty}$ be the normed real matrix vector space.
Let $\map O {1, 1} := \set {\mathbf R \in \R^{2 \times2} : \mathbf R^\intercal \mathbf J_{1,1} \mathbf R = \mathbf J_{1,1}}$ be the indefinite orthogonal group of degree $\paren {1, 1}$ over real numbers where:
:$\ds \mathbf J_{1,1} := \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0\\
0 & -1 \\
\end{bmatrix}$
Then $\map O {1, 1}$ is not a compact set in $\struct {\R^{2 \times 2}, \norm {\, \cdot \,}_\infty}$.

daa3b0c0-76e1-40ca-a859-47aca879043c.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a strictly positive real number.
Let $n \in \R$ be any natural number.
Let $\ln x$ be the natural logarithm of $x$.
Then:
:$\map \ln {x^n} = n \ln x$

2a798bb2-af6d-45e3-845a-cc1b6c79d518.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_{\bar p} }$ be an excluded point space.
Then $T$ is a $T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space.

7c2c66fc-8690-42a9-8122-9ac5d597c207.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=84|body=To a straight line which produces with a medial area a medial whole only one straight line can be annexed which is incommensurable in square with the whole straight line and which with the whole straight line makes the sum of the squares on them medial and twice the rectangle contained by them both medial and also incommensurable with the sum of the squares on them.}}

9f074a0f-2679-4200-a6de-193b23525354.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be a real function which is bijective.
Let its graph be embedded in the Cartesian plane $\mathcal C$:
:520px
Every horizontal line through a point $b$ in the codomain of $f$ intersects the graph of $f$ on exactly one point $P = \tuple {a, b}$ where $b = \map f a$.

ff86b939-5e58-4907-9e05-c134e17842fe.text:
Let $\sin t$ be the sine of $t$, where $t \in \R$.
Then $\sin t$ is of exponential order $0$.

6fe06842-3879-403d-8f2d-b9fdb4bdb4cf.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $a$ be a $p$-adic number, that is left coset, in $\Q_p$.
Let $\sequence{x_n}$ be a rational sequence.
Then:
:$\sequence{x_n}$ converges to $a$ {{iff}} $\sequence{x_n}$ is a representative of $a$

d1adeb83-ba9e-4dde-ae66-77cdabac4c66.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}$ be metric spaces.
Let $M_1$ and $M_2$ be homeomorphic.
Then it is not necessarily the case that:
:$M_1$ is bounded {{iff}} $M_2$ is bounded.
That is, boundedness is not a topological property.

11a2173a-b9af-46a6-aa2e-82d4bcf713b3.text:
Let $\AA$ be an algebra of sets.
Let $f: \AA \to \overline \R$ be an additive function such that:
:$\forall A \in \AA: \map f A \ge 0$
Then $f$ is subadditive.

f02adc09-5c9e-4bfe-9e5e-ab653234be22.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a semigroup.
Let $a, b \in S$ be idempotent elements of $S$.
Let $a$ and $b$ commute:
:$a \circ b = b \circ a$
Then $a \circ b$ is idempotent.

2444face-b968-4389-b72b-e061a530eda6.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a semigroup.
Let $\mathbb S$ be a set of subsemigroups of $\struct {S, \circ}$, where $\mathbb S \ne \O$.
Then the intersection $\bigcap \mathbb S$ of the members of $\mathbb S$ is itself a subsemigroup of $\struct {S, \circ}$.
Also, $\bigcap \mathbb S$ is the largest subsemigroup of $\struct {S, \circ}$ contained in each member of $\mathbb S$.

49eaa008-d7fb-4ab1-99c9-d1612b96ecdb.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $H, K$ be normal subgroups of $G$.
Let $H \cap K = e$.
Then $H K$ is isomorphic to $H \times K$ where:
: $H K$ denotes the subset product of $H$ and $K$
: $H \times K$ denotes the direct product of $H$ and $K$.

730681c0-a280-4635-8b79-ae4a26172206.text:
For each $k \in \N$, let $S_k = \openint {\dfrac 1 k} k$.
Then $\sequence {S_k}_k$ is an exhausting sequence of sets on $\R_{>0}$.

ac07fd7b-3c77-4c85-9e34-e36fe0447e37.text:
Let $G$ be a group acting by homeomorphisms on a topological space $X$.
Then the projection map $\pi: X \to X / G$ is open.

04859018-ccc0-4c8d-bb5f-8c741327349d.text:
:$\sin \left({\dfrac \pi 2 - \theta}\right) = \cos \theta$
where $\sin$ and $\cos$ are sine and cosine respectively.
That is, the cosine of an angle is the sine of its complement.

328830c4-2604-43e4-8ab6-6cb6354d989e.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \times}$ be an ordered integral domain where $P$ is the (strict) positivity property.
Let the relation $<$ be defined on $D$ as:
:$\forall a, b \in D: a < b \iff \map P {-a + b}$
Then $<$ is a transitive relation.

16ccd1d4-5ca2-4be6-b8a7-2f9558ed9521.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring whose zero is $0_R$.
Then:
:$\forall x \in R: 0_R \circ x = 0_R = x \circ 0_R$
That is, the zero is a zero element for the ring product, thereby justifying its name.

b40d8997-926f-4efd-83a9-47d5fd9f9f48.text:
Let $\mathbb S = \family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of non-empty topological spaces for $\alpha$ in some indexing set $I$.
Let $\ds T = \struct{S, \tau} = \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct{S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be the product space of $\mathbb S$.
Let $T$ be a $T_{3 \frac 1 2}$ space.
Then for each $\alpha \in I$, $\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ is a $T_{3 \frac 1 2}$ space.

c77cce6b-9fd2-4bab-a8e0-493ee00fa7e0.text:
Let $\SS$ be a semiring of sets.
Let $\map \RR \SS$ be the minimal ring generated by $\SS$.
Let $\LL$ be the system of sets $A$ with the finite expansions:
:$\ds A = \bigcup_{k \mathop = 1}^n A_k$
with respect to the sets $A_k \in \SS$.
Then $\LL = \map \RR \SS$.

f4fc75d0-055a-4e30-b78e-fd70686747fc.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ, \le}$ be an ordered field whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Suppose that $\forall a \in R: 0 < a \implies 0 < a^{-1}$.
Let $x, y \in \struct {R, +, \circ, \le}$ such that $0_R \le x, y$.
Then $x \le y \iff x \circ x \le y \circ y$.
That is, the square function is an order embedding of $\struct {R_{\ge 0}, \le}$ into itself.
When $R$ is one of the standard fields of numbers $\Q$ and $\R$, then this translates into:
:If $x, y$ are positive then $x \le y \iff x^2 \le y^2$.

6f49a03f-f8f1-477d-bc5a-271c85d886cf.text:
Let $\struct {S, \prec_1}$ and $\struct {T, \prec_2}$ be strictly ordered sets.
Let $\phi: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Let $\pi: S \to T$ be a mapping with the property that:
:$\forall x, y \in S: x \prec_1 y \iff \map \pi x \prec_2 \map \pi y$
Then it is not necessarily the case that $\pi$ is an injection.

2bc6564f-9936-4a85-a2ca-5da7829a541e.text:
Let $a \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $c + d i \in \C$ be a complex number.
Then:
:$a \times \left({c + d i}\right) = \left({c + d i}\right) \times a = a c + i a d$

31f1306f-91b4-40b0-a453-50cba6bafa36.text: The canonical form of a rational number is unique.

554beb84-4680-475e-a79d-143f35343bd3.text:
{{Cross-Relation Inverse Completion Context Definition}}
This cross-relation is a congruence relation on $S \times C$.
Let the quotient structure defined by $\boxtimes$ be:
:$\struct {T', \oplus'} := \struct {\dfrac {S \times C} \boxtimes, \oplus_\boxtimes}$
where $\oplus_\boxtimes$ is the operation induced on $\dfrac {S \times C} \boxtimes$ by $\oplus$.

a190197a-69c9-45d5-b0ec-ec1f384e030e.text:
Let $B_\alpha$ be the singleton containing the rational number $\alpha$.
Let $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ be the real number line with the usual (Euclidean) topology $\tau_d$.
Then the exterior in $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ of the union of all $B_\alpha$ is the empty set:
:$\ds \paren {\bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in \Q} B_\alpha}^e = \O$

7137a79f-af49-42c4-8cc2-a26f8b576f3a.text:
Let $L$ be a lattice in $\R^n$.
Let $d$ be the covolume of $L$.
Let $\mu$ be a translation invariant measure on $\R^n$
Let $S$ be a convex subset of $\R^n$ that is symmetric about the origin, i.e. such that:
:$\forall p \in S : -p \in S$ 
Let the volume of $S$ be greater than $2^n d$.
Then $S$ contains a non-zero point of $L$.

20d5de86-2ea1-4e25-b967-9e337bd619b1.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a particular point space.
Let $\sequence {a_i}$ be an infinite sequence in $T$.
Let $\beta$ be an accumulation point of $\sequence {a_i}$.
Then $\beta$ is such that an infinite number of terms of $\sequence {a_i}$ are equal either to $\beta$ or to $p$.

efcf589a-115e-43fe-ae7d-35f96291eeeb.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$.
Then:
:$\ds {n + 1 \brace 0} = 0$
where $\ds {n + 1 \brace 0}$ denotes a Stirling number of the second kind.

eb148a5e-aad3-42db-8feb-c9dac08ec398.text:
Let $\Gamma$ denote the gamma function.
Let $y$ be a positive number.
Then for any positive number $c$:
:$\ds \frac 1 {2 \pi i} \int_{c - i \infty}^{c + i \infty} \map \Gamma t y^{-t} \rd t = e^{-y}$

5469d2d8-b7e9-48ff-b72d-3695959a630d.text:
Let $\phi$ denote the Euler $\phi$ function.
$7$ and $8$ are two successive integers which are solutions to the equation:
:$\map \phi n = \map \phi {n + 2}$

abd161db-b59a-4476-ba9f-9ca0433f306a.text:
Let $\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n$ and $\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty b_n$ be two real or complex series that are absolutely convergent.
Then the series $\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \paren {a_n - b_n}$ is absolutely convergent, and:
:$\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \paren {a_n - b_n} = \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n - \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty b_n$

b3432098-9dad-4971-917a-4213df2996fd.text:
Let $a \in \R$ be a real number such that $a > 1$.
Let $f: \Q \to \R$ be the real-valued function defined as:
:$\map f q = a^q$
where $a^q$ denotes $a$ to the power of $q$.
Then $f$ is strictly increasing.

45394bb6-4029-4356-b0d0-31f8f1f910da.text:
Let $A, B \subseteq S$.
Let $\chi_{A \mathop \cup B}$ be the characteristic function of their union $A \cup B$.
Then:
:$\chi_{A \mathop \cup B} = \min \set {\chi_A + \chi_B, 1}$
where $\min$ denotes the min operation.

544225ac-c412-4247-b63c-4f157a0cf5e7.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\sin^n a x} = \frac {-\cos a x} {a \paren {n - 1} \sin^{n - 1} a x} + \frac {n - 2} {n - 1} \int \frac {\d x} {\sin^{n - 2} a x}$

c1389b23-b1c0-412b-86ca-595e99210e06.text:
Let $V$ be a basic universe.
Let $A$ and $B$ be sets in $V$.
Then $A \times B$ is also a set.

213ebdd2-32eb-46f0-b2bc-e88bc5c7ce03.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preccurlyeq}$ be an ordered set.
It may be the case that $S$ has no maximal elements.

e0b871a5-27a7-4d98-be7b-c5c7ad63d2b0.text:
Let $\mathbf x, \mathbf y$ be quaternions.
Let $\size {\mathbf x}$ be the modulus of $\mathbf x$.
Then:
:$\size {\mathbf {x y} } = \size {\mathbf x} \size {\mathbf y}$

4815380f-a3af-48c2-9807-a907753ef05e.text:
Let $a$ and $b$ be sets.
By application of the comprehension principle, the set $\set {a, b}$ can be formed.
Hence the '''doubleton''' $\set {a, b}$ can be derived as a valid object in Frege set theory.

1175f883-d908-438c-bd04-d010aa58b470.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be an algebraic structure.
Let $\circ$ be left cancellable and also commutative.
Then $\circ$ is also right cancellable.

db44cf6f-4a1b-42da-90ff-0576eb300493.text: :$\ds \int \sqrt {\paren {a x + b} \paren {p x + q} } \rd x = \frac {2 a p x + b p + a q} {4 a p} \sqrt {\paren {a x + b} \paren {p x + q} } - \frac {\paren {b p - a q}^2} {8 a p} \int \frac {\d x} {\sqrt {\paren {a x + b} \paren {p x + q} } }$

c344160e-a706-4889-8ba0-a9aefc68ee16.text:
Let $n \ge 1$ be a natural number.
Then the $2^n$th cyclotomic polynomial is:
:$\map {\Phi_{2^n} } x = x^{2^{n - 1} } + 1$

517bfde9-1e5b-47d3-8894-0a7b1dca60b5.text:
:$\forall g \in G: g \circ N \circ g^{-1} = N$
:$\forall g \in G: g^{-1} \circ N \circ g = N$

77bf7373-83ab-47d9-b9b2-7aae50b5338f.text:
:$\ds \int \csch^2 x \rd x = -\coth x + C$
where $C$ is an arbitrary constant.

67fcfe24-c982-4239-94a8-12010e0d57ed.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a toset.
Let $\tau$ be the order topology on $S$.
Then $\struct {S, \tau}$ is normal.

f0504792-0a2d-4b3f-98ba-1bdbdb45eeab.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=XI|prop=24|body=If a solid be contained by parallel planes, the opposite planes in it are equal and parallelogrammic.}}

208ba65d-74d8-4481-8b5c-2029c5486705.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be a division ring.
Let $S \subseteq D$ be a subset of $D$.
Let $L$ be the intersection of the set of all division subrings of $D$ containing $S$.
Then $L$ is the smallest division subring of $D$ containing $S$.

29d3daf0-9e35-47cf-8d8e-67855a85ac66.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{> 0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $\struct {\Z_m, +_m}$ denote the additive group of integers modulo $m$.
The subgroups of $\struct {\Z_m, +_m}$ are the additive groups of integers modulo $k$ where:
:$k \divides m$

906b51c6-233d-4f39-88c7-6f6160b6f895.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a strictly positive real number.
Let $a \in \R$ be a real number such that $a > 1$.
Let $r \in \R$ be any real number.
Let $\log_a x$ be the logarithm to the base $a$ of $x$.
Then:
:$\map {\log_a} {x^r} = r \log_a x$

fad2ad2f-089f-4d2d-b748-9bba23ef6e66.text:
Let $a, b, c, x$ be real numbers with $a \ne 0$.
Then:
:$a x^2 + b x + c = \dfrac {\paren {2 a x + b}^2 + 4 a c - b^2} {4 a}$
This process is known as '''completing the square'''.

af81cf49-1598-49b8-963d-92dcc2411304.text:
Let $\gen g = G$ be an infinite cyclic group.
Then the only other generator of $G$ is $g^{-1}$.
Thus an infinite cyclic group has exactly $2$ generators.

1a3094c7-7274-4614-a0a2-e88d19271106.text:
:$\map s {n, n} = 1$
where $\map s {n, n}$ denotes a signed Stirling number of the first kind.

60043899-934a-4e4c-b2ed-3b3a74ba793a.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $*: G \times S \to S$ be the trivial group action:
:$\forall \tuple {g, s} \in G \times S: g * s = s$
Then $*$ is indeed a group action.

fdf64b10-cf97-4120-b0ae-a1742104afa0.text: The set of rational numbers $\Q$ forms an integral domain under addition and multiplication: $\struct {\Q, +, \times}$.

67998837-6946-4acb-8802-c16bd10a0010.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number such that $x > 0$.
Let $\sequence {f_n}$ be the sequence of mappings $f_n : \R_{>0} \to \R$ defined as:
:$\map {f_n} x = n \paren {\sqrt [n] x - 1}$
Then $\forall x \in \R_{>0}: \sequence {\map {f_n} x}$ is strictly decreasing.

19a9cc62-0718-49ea-810b-50451e4f37f7.text: The Riemann zeta function has a unique analytic continuation to $\set {s \in \C : \map \Re s > 0} \setminus \set 1$, the half-plane $\map \Re s > 0$ minus the point $s = 1$.

95cff4ae-3aeb-4acc-81f9-c1dfa45c0df8.text:
Let $x$, $y$, and $z$ be ordinals.
Then:
:$x^y \times x^z = x^{y + z}$

b9826dcd-aae9-45da-b49b-10e5e24e75ee.text:
Let $M = \struct {S, d}$ be the standard discrete metric space on a set $A$.
Let $H \subseteq S$ be a subset of $S$.
Let $\alpha \in H$.
The $\alpha$ is an isolated point of $H$.

e1f7a151-4009-4191-9363-e92e2a784541.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\powerset S$ be the power set of $S$.
Let $f: \powerset S \to \powerset S$ be a $\subseteq$-increasing mapping.
That is, suppose that for all $T, U \in \powerset S$:
:$T \subseteq U \implies \map f T \subseteq \map f U$
Then $f$ has a greatest fixed point and a least fixed point.

41c87c52-1976-40c9-a02f-01ea62d779d0.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau}$ be an Urysohn space.
Then $\struct {S, \tau}$ is also a $T_{2 \frac 1 2}$ (completely Hausdorff) space.

d0d08603-e5ef-4f13-a738-00f36a653928.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\paren {p + q \cos a x}^2} = \frac {q \sin a x} {a \paren {q^2 - p^2} \paren {p + q \cos a x} } - \frac p {q^2 - p^2} \int \frac {\d x} {p + q \cos a x}$

7c131f4f-abf2-4d60-89b2-9c55e062b23f.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a finite complement topology on an uncountable set $S$.
Then countably infinite subsets of $S$ are $F_\sigma$ sets and are neither open nor closed sets.
Their relative complements in $S$ are $G_\delta$ sets, and are also neither open nor closed sets.

a0d30338-c8d8-4575-834e-bb317a9ca871.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $T \subseteq S$.
Then $\left({T, \preceq \restriction_T}\right)$ is also a totally ordered set.
In the above, $\preceq \restriction_T$ denotes the restriction of $\preceq$ to $T$.

6a8f5d17-0d47-46ad-b57c-067dedaca74f.text:
Let $\mathbf A$ be an $m \times n$ matrix and $\mathbf B$ be an $n \times p$ matrix such that the columns of $\mathbf A$ and $\mathbf B$ are members of $\R^m$ and $\R^n$, respectively.
Let $\lambda \in \mathbb F \in \set {\R, \C}$ be a scalar.
Then:
:$\mathbf A \paren {\lambda \mathbf B} = \lambda \paren {\mathbf A \mathbf B}$

78e1856a-1b9e-4ce2-881e-a01accfee5c9.text:
Let $x$ be a set of sets.
Let $\powerset x$ denote the power set of $x$.
Let $\ds \map \bigcup {\powerset x}$ denote the union of $\powerset x$.
Then:
:$x = \ds \map \bigcup {\powerset x}$

0d7a6f73-a131-44c1-a00c-ec5a1936e562.text:
Define the real-valued functions $x, y: \C \to \R$ by:
:$\forall z \in \C: \map x z = \map \Re z$
:$\forall z \in \C: \map y z = \map \Im z$
Equip $\R$ with the usual Euclidean metric.
Equip $\C$ with the usual Euclidean metric.
{{refactor|Reconsider the above link so that it goes to an actual definition page.}}
Then both $x$ and $y$ are continuous functions.

f0cd84d3-607a-4b56-b0ac-08f3c0a8af22.text: A finite integral domain is a Galois field.

c2eeddae-0157-4af7-86b3-45ec7b4e641f.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ, \preceq}$ and $\struct {S', \circ', \preceq'}$ be naturally ordered semigroups.
Let:
:$0'$ be the smallest element of $S'$
:$1'$ be the smallest element of $S' \setminus \set {0'} = S'^*$.
Then the mapping $g: S \to S'$ defined as:
:$\forall a \in S: \map g a = \circ'^a 1'$
is an isomorphism from $\struct {S, \circ, \preceq}$ to $\struct {S', \circ', \preceq'}$.
This isomorphism is unique.
Thus, up to isomorphism, there is only one naturally ordered semigroup.

90673292-ce3d-4e0d-be6c-055b2db02324.text: The semiring of natural numbers $\struct {\N, +, \times}$ forms a commutative semiring.

669d50fe-93f4-4912-8650-6f87e21c9565.text:
Let $\exp z$ be the complex exponential function.
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{\map \Re z \mathop \to +\infty} e^{-z} = 0$
where $\map \Re z$ denotes the real part of $z$.

411765f5-160b-43df-9875-332cfa7e7f69.text:
Let $f$ be a real function that is everywhere differentiable.
Let $I \subseteq \Dom f$ be a real interval.
Then:
:$f' \sqbrk I$ is a real interval
where $f'$ denotes the derivative of $f$

6b46d20d-1f42-4ffb-a53a-bd8791cc86e0.text:
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\family {\struct {X_i, \Sigma_i} }_{i \mathop \in I}$ be a family of measurable spaces.
Let $X$ be a set.
Let $\family {f_i: X \to X_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be a family of mappings.
Then $\map \sigma {f_i: i \in I}$, the $\sigma$-algebra generated by $\family {f_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$, exists and is unique.

792cf5a5-1c1c-40aa-9f36-a139e893a19b.text:
Let $F$ be a field whose characteristic is $p$.
Then there exists a unique $P \subseteq F$ such that:
:$(1): \quad P$ is a subfield of $F$
:$(2): \quad P \cong \Z_p$.
That is, $P \cong \Z_p$ is a unique minimal subfield of $F$, and all other subfields of $F$ contain $P$.
This field $P$ is called the prime subfield of $F$.

1eb817ec-0032-4c00-a143-a47e4b3dfacc.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\cos a x \paren {1 + \sin a x} } = \frac {-1} {2 a \paren {1 + \sin a x} } + \frac 1 {2 a} \ln \size {\map \tan {\frac {a x} 2 + \frac \pi 4} } + C$

92df9f8a-166b-4cae-9bb8-814eeab1287c.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $n \in \Z$ be an even integer.
Then $x^n \ge 0$.
That is, all even powers are positive.

dcd3eee5-ce2f-4012-ba8e-a1eb423657ba.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preccurlyeq}$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $a, b \in S$.
Then:
:$a^\preccurlyeq \cap b^\preccurlyeq = \paren {\min \set {a, b} }^\preccurlyeq$
where:
:$a^\preccurlyeq$ denotes the weak lower closure of $a$
:$\min$ denotes the min operation.

c9fc7678-5d5f-47af-a87e-7d91617951bf.text: :$\ds \int x^2 \paren {\sqrt {a^2 - x^2} }^3 \rd x = \frac {-x \paren {\sqrt {a^2 - x^2} }^5} 6 + \frac {a^2 x \paren {\sqrt {a^2 - x^2} }^3} {24} + \frac {a^4 x \sqrt {a^2 - x^2} } {16} + \frac {a^6} {16} \arcsin \frac x a + C$

d71df962-f347-41d5-a70e-79d8b5217bc1.text: :$\ds \int \frac {x \rd x} {a x + b} = \frac x a - \frac b {a^2} \ln \size {a x + b} + C$

900efed6-bde7-4850-90f0-a9757c08ca68.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ and $\struct {H, *}$ be groups.
Let $\phi: \struct {G, \circ} \to \struct {H, *}$ be a group homomorphism.
Let $\map \ker \phi$ be the kernel of $\phi$.
Then there exists $N \lhd G$, a normal subgroup of $G$ such that:
:$N = \map \ker \phi$
Conversely, let $N \lhd G$ be normal subgroup of $G$.
Then there exists $\phi: \struct {G, \circ} \to \struct {H, *}$, a group homomorphism, whose kernel $\map \ker \phi$ is such that:
:$\map \ker \phi = N$

5b31e08f-62ec-4c46-8bca-f0176290483d.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {p + q e^{a x} } = \frac x p - \frac 1 {a p} \ln \size {p + q e^{a x} } + C$

b2609cfa-111c-40f1-a630-91455a87a144.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a Fort space on an infinite set $S$.
Then $T$ is a $T_5$ space.

7f2a615b-f614-4ec1-ab81-77856a6702a2.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=XI|prop=9|body=Straight lines which are parallel to the same straight line and are not in the same plane with it are also parallel to one another.}}

62dbf562-885d-43cb-9ed4-a97e4543c2c0.text:
Let $\triangle ABC$ and $\triangle A'B'C'$ be triangles lying in the same or different planes.
Let the lines $AA'$, $BB'$ and $CC'$ intersect in the point $O$.
Then $BC$ meets $B'C'$ in $L$, $CA$ meets $C'A'$ in $M$ and $AB$ meets $A'B'$ in $N$, where $L, M, N$ are collinear.

fe7b28d5-c90f-4bda-a203-0e48831eb31f.text: No unitary perfect numbers exist which are odd.

305c34bf-784e-4d99-9def-a0654efb4236.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Then $M$ is a perfectly $T_4$ space.

74d65275-6e8b-4263-9bfe-52ea272faaf1.text:
Let $\CC$ denote the set of cuts.
Let $<$ denote the strict ordering on cuts defined as:
:$\forall \alpha, \beta \in \CC: \alpha < \beta \iff \exists p \in \Q: p \in \alpha, p \notin \beta$
Then $<$ is a (strict) total ordering on $\CC$.

dea0fa58-2e56-4a49-b77a-6078f967181a.text:
Let $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ be the real number line with the usual (Euclidean) topology.
Let $\closedint a b$ be a closed interval of $\R$.
Then $\closedint a b$ is closed (in the topological sense) in $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$.

5ab042c5-5d72-449a-b63d-9fc40154de71.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the Arens-Fort space.
Then $T$ is not a countably compact space.

563a8f92-854e-4e86-9da0-b0ec692911d4.text:
Let $S$ be the set of square matrices of order $2$ whose diagonal elements are zero.
Then the algebraic structure $\struct {S, +, \times}$ is not a ring.
Note that $\times$ denotes conventional matrix multiplication.

9bbb13d8-df17-4de7-a208-1ba89e333ab4.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_R$ be a unitary $R$-module such that $\map \dim G = n$.
Let $\struct {H, +_H, \circ}_R$ be a unitary $R$-module such that $\map \dim H = m$.
Let $\map {\LL_R} {G, H}$ be the set of all linear transformations from $G$ to $H$.
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ be an ordered basis for $G$.
Let $\sequence {b_m}$ be an ordered basis for $H$.
Let $\phi_{i j}: G \to H$ be the unique linear transformation defined for each $i \in \closedint 1 n, j \in \closedint 1 m$ which satisfies:
:$\forall k \in \closedint 1 n: \map {\phi_{i j} } {a_k} = \delta_{i k} b_j$
where $\delta$ is the Kronecker delta.
Then:
:$\set {\phi_{i j}: i \in \closedint 1 n, j \in \closedint 1 m}$
is a basis for $\map {\LL_R} {G, H}$.

a62413d4-f357-4369-9f88-5cb6b4a4bec5.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H \le G$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Then the conjugate of $H$ by $a$ is a subgroup of $G$:
:$\forall H \le G, a \in G: H^a \le G$

e7309eda-ced1-4ed8-8a1b-45c02bc1f057.text:
:$\cosh 2 x = \dfrac {1 + \tanh^2 x}{1 - \tanh^2 x}$
where $\cosh$ and $\tanh$ denote hyperbolic cosine and hyperbolic tangent respectively.

6673caaa-e953-4e15-b736-6975e1b0f27f.text:
Let $V$ be a basic universe.
Let $\RR \subseteq V \times V$ be a relation.
Let $\RR$ be a set.
Then $\Dom \RR$ and $\Img \RR$ are also sets.

3fc94a14-54b6-4115-bbd1-b269ef17d8ea.text:
Let $\lambda \in \R \setminus \Z$ be a real number which is not an integer.
Then:
:$\ds \pi \csc \pi \lambda = \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \paren {-1}^n \paren {\frac 1 {n + \lambda} + \frac 1 {n - 1 - \lambda} }$

e41e4a78-27c4-4f02-8a5d-28cd346bf117.text:
For $n \in \Z_{>1}$:
:$\cos n \theta = \map \sin {\paren {n - 1} \theta} \paren {a_0 + \cfrac 1 {a_1 + \cfrac 1 {a_2 + \cfrac 1 {\ddots \cfrac {} {a_{n - r} } } } } }$
where:
:$r = \begin {cases} 1 & : \text {$n$ is even} \\ 2 & : \text {$n$ is odd} \end {cases}$
:$a_k = \begin {cases} -2 \sin \theta & : \text {$k$ is even  and $k < n - 1$} \\ 2 \sin \theta & : \text {$k$ is odd} \\ \sin \theta & : k = n - 1 \end {cases}$

3f392be6-b9b7-4d36-9731-824f96a0c440.text:
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer.
Then:
:$F_{2 n + 1} \phi \bmod 1 = \phi^{-2 n - 1}$
where:
:$F_n$ denotes the $n$th Fibonacci number
:$\phi$ is the golden mean: $\phi = \dfrac {1 + \sqrt 5} 2$

831c28ba-e80d-4103-b5bb-0eac4e9df7d3.text:
Let $\phi: \struct {R_1, +_1, \circ_1} \to \struct {R_2, +_2, \circ_2}$ be a ring homomorphism.
Then $\phi: \struct {R_1, +_1} \to \struct {R_2, +_2}$ is a group homomorphism.

d584b781-6d75-4e40-88c6-3628ef5fda33.text:
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\family {X_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of non-empty topological spaces.
Let $\ds X = \prod_{i \mathop \in I} X_i$ be the corresponding product space.
Then $X$ is compact {{iff}} each $X_i$ is compact.
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\family {X_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of non-empty Hausdorff spaces.
Let $\ds X = \prod_{i \mathop \in I} X_i$ be the corresponding product space.
Then $X$ is compact {{iff}} each $X_i$ is compact.

b94de1f2-5462-4e1d-b141-0d1ca1a21ce2.text:
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times S$ be a relation which is not null.
Let $\RR$ be antireflexive and transitive.
Then $\RR$ is also antisymmetric.

91859ecc-7b15-48d8-9f81-8e0da08608cf.text:
For all $n \in \Z_{>0}$, let $\map {\phi_n} x$ be the real function defined on the interval $\openint 0 \lambda$ as:
:$\map {\phi_n} x = \sqrt {\dfrac 2 \lambda} \sin \dfrac {n \pi x} \lambda$
Let $S$ be the set:
:$S = \set {\phi_n: n \in \Z_{>0} }$
Then $S$ is an orthonormal set.

6782fca1-cff9-4e24-8505-ce638ab8e955.text:
:$\ds \paren {x + y}^{\overline n} = \sum_k \binom n k x^{\overline k} y^{\overline {n - k} }$
where:
:$\dbinom n k$ denotes a binomial coefficient
:$x^{\overline k}$ denotes $x$ to the $k$ rising.

8e793786-6bb5-400a-be91-1b8deeed008a.text:
Let $z$ be a complex number.
Let $\csc z$ denote the cosecant function and $i$ denote the imaginary unit: $i^2 = -1$.
Then:
:$\csc z = \dfrac {2 i} {e^{i z} - e^{-i z} }$

0c094257-5edc-4352-b0b2-330cb2d453a8.text:
Let $S$ be a subset of the set of real numbers $\R$.
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $\map d {x, S}$ be the distance between $x$ and $S$.
Let $S$ be bounded above such that $\xi = \sup S$.
Then:
:$\map d {\xi, S} = 0$

91c839c8-9b99-4082-ae4f-52564717a5e5.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a semigroup.
For $a \in S$, let $\circ^n a = a^n$ be the $n$th power of $a$.
Then:
:$\forall m, n \in \N_{>0}: a^{n m} = \paren {a^n}^m = \paren {a^m}^n$
That is:
:$\forall m, n \in \N_{>0}: \circ^{n m} a = \circ^m \paren {\circ^n a} = \circ^n \paren {\circ^m a}$

3c2e84e0-3e76-4d24-b5e8-4beb1222e430.text:
The usual ordering on the integers is preserved by the operation of addition:
:$\forall a, b, c, d, \in \Z: a \le b, c \le d \implies a + c \le b + d$

e56fea7a-6369-45e6-934d-1ec7fc5efd6a.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space which is arc-connected.
Then $T$ is path-connected.

3f0bfa14-78ab-4834-a027-2942faee2d2e.text:
Let $G$ be a cyclic group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Then $H$ is cyclic.

6e332159-d230-4a29-b685-ce3a00788ad0.text:
{{TFAE|def = Division Ring}}
A '''division ring''' is a ring with unity $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ with the following properties:

5e72c192-6244-4362-b0fc-10a768d73415.text:
Let $f$ be a real-valued function.
Then:
: $f$ is bounded on the union of a finite number of sets within the domain of $f$
{{iff}}:
:$f$ is bounded on each of the sets.

c2c6c97c-d30b-41cb-8260-6e208dfd2303.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number such that $x > 1$.
Let set $S = \set {x^n: n \in \N}$.
Then $S$ is unbounded above.

ed3d23cc-ce8b-43a8-aef5-8aaefe911dee.text:
Let $m \in \Z$ be an integer.
Let $\Z_m$ be the set of integers modulo $m$.
The modulo addition operation on $\Z_m$, defined by the rule:
:$\eqclass a m +_m \eqclass b m = \eqclass {a + b} m$
is a well-defined operation.
That is:
:If $a \equiv b \pmod m$ and $x \equiv y \pmod m$, then $a + x \equiv b + y \pmod m$.

9215b88c-88c1-4784-be6c-804ced35afa9.text: The set of even natural numbers is infinite.

bcaa16e0-087b-4081-ae71-08afbc8d614b.text:
: $\cosh 2 x = 2 \cosh^2 x - 1$
where $\cosh$ denotes hyperbolic cosine.

43c218c8-5cde-4328-b315-ed0b3c74ed85.text:
The only solution to:
:$x^m = y^n + 1$
is:
:$\tuple {x, m, y, n} = \tuple {3, 2, 2, 3}$
for positive integers $x, y, m, n > 1$, and $x$ is a prime number.
This is a special case of Catalan's Conjecture.

d92c80c0-616e-466a-9ff8-ef86b56fe478.text:
Let $\R$ be the set of real numbers.
Let $\BB = \set {\hointr a b: a, b \in \R}$.
Let $\tau$ be the topology generated by $\BB$, that is, the Sorgenfrey line.
Then $\tau$ is first-countable.

3cc6aae6-b99e-43eb-8161-3f199500f2a7.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $m$ be a minimal element of $\struct {S, \preceq}$.
Then:
:$(1): \quad m$ is the smallest element of $\struct {S, \preceq}$
:$(2): \quad m$ is the only minimal element of $\struct {S, \preceq}$.

924aa116-0b78-42af-8856-bf2842f84497.text:
Let $\Z$ be the set of all integers.
Let $\Z_{>0}$ be the set of strictly positive integers.
Let $m \in \Z_{>0}$ and let $n \in \Z$.
Let $\ideal m$ be the principal ideal of $\Z$ generated by $m$.
Then:
:$m \divides n \iff \ideal n \subseteq \ideal m$

f607c36d-edf9-4d92-8ae3-82e63620e276.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring.
Then:
:$\forall x, y \in \struct {R, +, \circ}: \paren {-x} \circ \paren {-y} = x \circ y$
where $\paren {-x}$ denotes the negative of $x$.

9ec4a6b4-5bf2-436a-87d3-99d555778270.text: Every field has an algebraic closure.

a4d92ecc-ed7f-474f-bec4-d76da69887c3.text:
Let $A$ be a transitive class.
Let $\ds \bigcup A$ denote the union of $A$.
Then:
:$\ds \bigcup A \subseteq A$

bef0148a-59e0-4483-835e-2f202ef6d382.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \set {\O, S} }$ be an indiscrete topological space.
Then $T$ is a $T_5$ space.

a49433bc-54fe-4f0b-8115-dbb930d30532.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring whose zero is $0_R$.
For $r \in R$, let $\ideal r$ denote the ideal generated by $r$.
Then $\ideal {0_R}$ is the null ideal.

7343e549-6272-4f26-825a-4409a8458ef9.text:
Intersection is distributive over symmetric difference:
:$\paren {R \symdif S} \cap T = \paren {R \cap T} \symdif \paren {S \cap T}$
:$T \cap \paren {R \symdif S} = \paren {T \cap R} \symdif \paren {T \cap S}$

b049845f-487a-4ad6-a476-72f2b14a05a0.text:
The distance $d$ between two points $A = \tuple {x_1, y_1}$ and $B = \tuple {x_2, y_2}$ on a Cartesian plane is:
:$d = \sqrt {\paren {x_1 - x_2}^2 + \paren {y_1 - y_2}^2}$

b6487102-d6f8-4c4d-805d-f3ce39e7d26e.text:
:$\ds \int \map F {\arccos \frac x a} \rd x = -a \int \map F u \sin u \rd u$
where $u = \arccos \dfrac x a$.

a22e3fcd-64dc-49ed-bdb1-db53262ddd71.text:
Let $\struct {\R^n, d}$ be a real Euclidean space of $n$ dimensions.
Let $S$ be the set of all mappings $f: \R^n \to \R^n$ which preserve distance:
That is:
:$\map d {\map f a, \map f b} = \map d {a, b}$
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be the algebraic structure formed from $S$ and the composition operation $\circ$.
Then $\struct {S, \circ}$ is a group.

72cdcffb-89ec-4973-bf1f-97dd3afa4a1a.text: Zorn's Lemma implies the Well-Ordering Theorem.

41c29791-f6a2-4034-a591-73171ac1827e.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $M$ be complete and totally bounded.
Then $M$ is sequentially compact.

f310618e-751f-4619-847a-ba4a9aa0dadf.text: The set of non-negative real numbers $\R_{\ge 0}$ is not well-ordered under the usual ordering $\le$.

7c11ddbc-4ac2-415f-9e92-54f63049c933.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a particular point space.
Let $U \in \tau_p$ be open in $T$ such that $U \ne \O$.
Then:
:$U^- = S$
where $U^-$ denotes the closure of $U$.

6b5eeba4-0d80-4978-a686-ee914647dbff.text:
Let $T = \struct{S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $T$ be weakly locally connected at each point of $T$.
That is, each point of $T$ has a neighborhood basis consisting of connected sets of $T$.
Then:
:each point of $T$ has a local basis consisting entirely of connected sets in $T$.

ab79d840-1517-4972-a5c8-b793ca14634a.text:
Let $\struct {\mathbf V, +, \circ}_F$ be a vector space over a field $F$, as defined by the vector space axioms.
Then for every $\mathbf v \in \mathbf V$, the additive inverse of $\mathbf v$ is unique:
:$\forall \mathbf v \in \mathbf V: \exists! \paren {-\mathbf v} \in \mathbf V: \mathbf v + \paren {-\mathbf v} = \mathbf 0$

1c093bcd-07ab-463d-b5cd-27c61df70577.text: The divisor relation is a partial ordering of $\Z_{>0}$.

9329a3bd-72a2-4347-9410-f9d637501234.text:
Let:
:$(1): \quad \ds \struct {S, \circ} = \prod_{k \mathop = 1}^n S_k = \struct {S_1, \circ_1} \times \struct {S_2, \circ_2} \times \cdots \times \struct {S_n, \circ_n}$
:$(2): \quad \ds \struct {T, \ast} = \prod_{k \mathop = 1}^n T_k = \struct {T_1, \ast_1} \times \struct {T_2, \ast_2} \times \cdots \times \struct {T_n, \ast_n}$
be external direct products of algebraic structures.
Let $\phi_k: \struct {S_k, \circ_k} \to \struct {T_k, \ast_k}$ be an isomorphism for each $k \in \closedint 1 n$.
Then:
:$\phi: \struct {s_1, \ldots, s_n} \to \struct {\map {\phi_1} {s_1}, \ldots, \map {\phi_n} {s_n} }$
is an isomorphism from $\struct {S, \circ}$ to $\struct {T, \ast}$.

85d6a507-294b-4256-9ea5-5646bcbd1524.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $\Z_p^\times$ be the $p$-adic units.
Let $a \in \Q_p$.
Then there exists $n \in \Z$ such that:
:$p^n a \in \Z_p^\times$
where
:$p^n = \norm a_p$

2970bd31-edb5-479d-a270-0551ece637df.text:
Let $\RR_2 \circ \RR_1$ be a composite relation.
Then the domain of $\RR_2 \circ \RR_1$ is the domain of $\RR_1$:
:$\Dom {\RR_2 \circ \RR_1} = \Dom {\RR_1}$

2478760d-002a-4ad7-b23e-7b556eca029d.text:
The total length of the arcs of a nephroid constructed around a stator of radius $a$ is given by:
:$\LL = 12 a$

de3586f7-abf1-4d6d-90b8-ebbbe6090773.text:
The Weierstrass Substitution for $\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\paren {p + q \sin a x}^2}$ yields:
:$\ds \frac 2 a \int \frac {\paren {u^2 + 1} \rd u} {\paren {p u^2 + 2 q u + p}^2}$
where $u = \tan \dfrac {a x} 2$.

8dd77267-5f66-486b-b25c-e935676422b1.text: There exists at least one example of a topological space for which none of the Tychonoff separation axioms are satisfied except for the $T_4$ axiom.

9a33d872-d758-4e40-8d19-d57cfa4999cb.text:
Let $\alpha \in \R$ be a real number which is specifically not an integer.
For $0 \le \theta < 2 \pi$:
:$\ds \dfrac 1 \alpha + \sum_{n \mathop \ge 1} \dfrac {2 \alpha} {\alpha^2 - n^2} = \sum_{n \mathop \in \Z} \dfrac {\cos \paren {n + \alpha} \theta} {n + \alpha}$

6b891794-fe75-48c0-8831-df8391b0a31e.text:
:$\tan^2x = \dfrac {1 - \cos2x} {1 + \cos2x}$
where $\cos$ and $\tan$ denote cosine and tangent respectively.

905b02e9-8406-4372-8187-a902a7945a74.text: :$\ds \int e^{a x} \rd x = \frac {e^{a x} } a + C$

52ecb6b2-c3b7-4141-ac32-a5340b97c00a.text:
The Max operation is commutative:
:$\map \max {x, y} = \map \max {y, x}$

a6743160-28a1-4b94-9e95-3c4a7b0f684e.text: :$\ds \int \frac {x^2 \rd x} {\sqrt {x^2 + a^2} } = \frac {\paren {\sqrt {x^2 + a^2} }^3} 3 - a^2 \sqrt {x^2 + a^2} + C$

d5b30ece-72f0-46ed-824c-4b1ec1369d24.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be an semigroup.
Let $T \subseteq S$.
Let $T$ be closed under $\circ$.
Then $\struct {T, \circ_T}$ is also a semigroup, where $\circ_T$ is the restriction of $\circ$ to $T$.

10f88eda-c739-4364-93fe-637c6926bff2.text:
Let $\R^n$ be the $n$-dimensional Euclidean space for $n \in \N$ a natural number.
Then $\R^n$ is path-connected.

83bf65c3-d237-4047-b21f-32ec04c12918.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a particular point space.
Then $p$ is dispersion point of $T$.

c7b5a345-08de-4abe-9487-a3631fd6a98b.text:
Let there be $53$ people in a room.
The probability that no $2$ of them have the same birthday is approximately $\dfrac 1 {53}$.

7391b1e6-3214-4854-ba7b-78b32abf1e23.text:
Let $a, b$ be real numbers with $a < b$.
Let $f : \closedint a b \to \R$ be a continuous function.
Let $f$ be differentiable on $\openint a b$, with bounded derivative.
Then $f$ is of bounded variation.

c693af81-2a8d-4b8a-b7d3-a3f2aac8f74b.text:
Let $z \in \R$ be a real number.
Then addition modulo $z$ on the set of residue classes modulo $z$ is closed:
:$\forall \eqclass x z, \eqclass y z \in \R_z: \eqclass x z +_z \eqclass y z \in \R_z$.

53cfebf6-e0f1-4d9d-b7a7-457b9c67b2f2.text:
Let $n \in \N$.
For all $k \in \set {1, \ldots, n}$, let $T_k = \struct {X_k, \tau_k}$ be topological spaces.
Let $\ds X = \prod_{k \mathop = 1}^n X_k$ be the cartesian product of $X_1, \ldots, X_n$.
Then the box topology and the product topology on $X$ are identical.

945d18da-5f1b-4615-8c1d-ec43566f4da7.text:
Let $S$ be a set which is non-empty.
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times S$ be the null relation.
Then $\RR$ is antireflexive, symmetric and transitive.
If $S = \O$ then Relation on Empty Set is Equivalence applies.

a8f58a9d-4c27-40d3-9aec-d56f06b7ca6c.text: The total solid angle subtended by a spherical surface is $4 \pi$.

1b25acfc-8c9e-40f3-9559-1ae5d9888f40.text:
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\family {A_\alpha}_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ and $\family {B_\alpha}_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be indexed families of subsets of a set $S$.
Let:
:$\forall \beta \in I: A_\beta \subseteq B_\beta$
Then:
:$\ds \bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in I} A_\alpha \subseteq \bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in I} B_\alpha$

2220e98f-6d21-4e22-846f-f48c5656169a.text:
Let $\HH, \KK$ be Hilbert spaces.
Let $A: \HH 	o \KK$ be a bounded linear transformation.
Let $
orm A$ denote the norm of $A$ defined by:
:$
orm A = \inf \set {c > 0:  orall h \in \HH: 
orm {A h}_\KK \le c 
orm h_\HH}$
Then:
:$ orall h \in \HH: 
orm {A h}_\KK \le 
orm A 
orm h_\HH$

bca3638c-7247-42a4-a35b-5a5f930b4c53.text:
:$\ds \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n \dfrac {H_k} {n + 1 - k} = {H_{n + 1} }^2 - H_{n + 1}^{\paren 2}$
where $H_k$ denotes the $k$th harmonic number.

53d82dd8-a740-42bf-acbb-2eca54627277.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Then $p$ can be expressed as the sum of two squares {{iff}} either:
: $p = 2$
or:
: $p \equiv 1 \pmod 4$
The expression of a prime of the form $4 k + 1$ as the sum of two squares is unique except for the order of the two summands.

ba1ede86-3247-42b0-990f-812f7858fa8b.text:
Let $f$ and $g$ be real functions.
Let $f$ and $g$ agree for all $x$ in a deleted neighborhood of $c$.
Let the limit:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to c} \map f x$
exist.
Then the limit:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to c} \map g x$
also exists, and:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to c} \map f x = \lim_{x \mathop \to c} \map g x$

2a6a8590-2e75-48af-820e-444993af5179.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{> 0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Then:
:$\ds \int \sin^n x \rd x = \dfrac {n - 1} n \int \sin^{n - 2} x \rd x - \dfrac {\sin^{n - 1} x \cos x} n$
is a reduction formula for $\ds \int \sin^n x \rd x$.

b40f63fc-a32f-4141-8104-388f61f05df8.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_{a, b}}$ be a modified Fort space.
Let $H$ be a subset of $S$ with more than one point.
Then $H$ is disconnected.

6552a5d6-8cee-4493-b741-c259cd21e9ac.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a continuous lattice.
Let $p \in S$ be a pseudoprime element.
Let $A$ be a non-empty finite subset of $S$ such that
:$\inf A \ll p$
where $\ll$ denotes the way below relation.
Then $\exists a \in A: a \preceq p$

05794b3b-0a76-4b6d-9f8e-ce239192f08c.text:
Let $m, n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$.
:$\ds \sum_k {n + 1 \brack k + 1} {k \brace m} \paren {-1}^{k - m} = \sqbrk {n \ge m} \dfrac {n!} {m!}$
where:
:$\sqbrk {n \ge m}$ is Iverson's convention
:$\ds {n + 1 \brack k + 1}$ denotes an unsigned Stirling number of the first kind
:$\ds {k \brace m}$ denotes a Stirling number of the second kind.

4b644729-2274-4b8e-914a-c31dc65785bd.text:
Let $z_1, z_2, \dotsc, z_n \in \C$ be complex numbers.
Let $\cmod z$ be the modulus of $z$.
Then:
:$\cmod {z_1 + z_2 + \dotsb + z_n} \le \cmod {z_1} + \cmod {z_2} + \dotsb + \cmod {z_n}$

9e998de6-ce44-4fb4-b570-12f54be05326.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ, \le}$ be an ordered ring.
Let $x, y \in R$.
Let $n \in \N_{>0}$ be a strictly positive integer.
Let $0 < x < y$.
Then:
:$0 < \map {\circ^n} x < \map {\circ^n} y$

c01d0d15-b761-49ba-abba-61c66529db01.text:
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ be the sequence defined as:
:$\forall n \in \N_{> 0}: a_n = n - 1$
That is:
:$\sequence {a_n} = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, \ldots$
Then the generating function for $\sequence {a_n}$ is given as:
:$G \paren z = \dfrac 1 {\paren {1 - z}^2}$

c106366e-7392-4de0-8b85-fbe3e7115d36.text:
Let $S$ be a set of $n + 1$ non-non-zero natural numbers all less than or equal to $2 n$.
Then there exists $a, b \in S$ such that
:$a \divides b$
where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.

7ab9f85e-2d5f-489d-b79c-4ee4fb531852.text:
Let $f$ and $g$ be real functions which are continuous on the closed interval $\closedint a b$ and differentiable on the open interval $\openint a b$.
Let:
:$\forall x \in \openint a b: \map {g'} x \ne 0$
where $g'$ denotes the derivative of $g$ {{WRT|Differentiation}} $x$.
Let:
:$\map f a = \map g a = 0$
Then:
:$\displaystyle \lim_{x \mathop \to a^+} \frac {\map f x} {\map g x} = \lim_{x \mathop \to a^+} \frac {\map {f'} x} {\map {g'} x}$
provided that the second limit exists.

91ad73cf-5852-4918-b865-48222132b348.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Then the trivial subgroup $\struct {\set e, \circ}$ is indeed a subgroup of $\struct {G, \circ}$.

6751e1a1-cb55-4a47-8e79-541c97406e4e.text:
Let $\C$ be the set of all complex numbers.
Let $d: \C \times \C \to \R$ be the function defined as:
:$\map d {z_1, z_2} = \size {z_1 - z_2}$
where $\size z$ is the modulus of $z$.
Then $d$ is a metric on $\C$ and so $\struct {\C, d}$ is a metric space.

47176e21-c4ca-41fb-8a60-9939c5530de7.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \times}$ be a unique factorization domain.
Let $p$ be an irreducible element of $D$.
Let $a, b \in D$ such that:
:$p \divides a \times b$
where $\divides$ means '''is a divisor of'''.
Then $p \divides a$ or $p \divides b$.
Let $p$ be an irreducible element of $D$.
Let $n \in D$ such that:
:$\ds n = \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^r a_i$
where $a_i \in D$ for all $i: 1 \le i \le r$.
Then if $p$ divides $n$, it follows that $p$ divides $a_i$ for some $i$.
That is:
:$p \divides a_1 a_2 \ldots a_n \implies p \divides a_1 \lor p \divides a_2 \lor \cdots \lor p \divides a_n$

9821872b-f912-4463-85d2-bde763a70035.text:
Let $U$ be a subset of $\R^3$ which is compact and has a piecewise smooth boundary $\partial U$.
Let $\mathbf V: \R^3 \to \R^3$ be a smooth vector field defined on a neighborhood of $U$.
Then:
:$\ds \iiint \limits_U \paren {\nabla \cdot \mathbf V} \rd v = \iint \limits_{\partial U} \mathbf V \cdot \mathbf n \rd S$
where $\mathbf n$ is the unit normal to $\partial U$, directed outwards.
Consider a closed surface $S$ within a body of fluid which at an arbitrary point $P$ is in motion with velocity $\mathbf V$.
The total rate of flow of fluid passing through $S$ can be found in $2$ different ways:
:$(1): \quad$ By calculating $\mathbf V \cdot \rd \mathbf S$, which is the product of a small element of $S$ and the component of velocity which is perpendicular to it, and then adding all these contributions
:$(2): \quad$ By investigating the divergence of an element of volume, which is the excess of the sources of fluid over its sinks per unit volume and integrating $\operatorname {div} \mathbf V \rd v$ throughout the volume enclosed by $S$.
These $2$ results are physically equivalent, because the excess fluid leaving $S$ over that entering must be because of the fluid injected into $B$ by the aggregate of sources and sinks.
The '''Gauss-Ostrogradsky Theorem''' is also known as:
:the '''Gauss-Ostrogradsky Theorem'''
:'''Gauss-Ostrogradsky Theorem'''
:'''Gauss-Ostrogradsky Theorem''' or '''Gauss-Ostrogradsky Theorem'''
:'''Gauss-Ostrogradsky Theorem'''
:the '''Gauss-Ostrogradsky Theorem'''.
The Gauss-Ostrogradsky Theorem was first discovered by {{AuthorRef|Joseph Louis Lagrange}} in $1762$.
It was the later independently rediscovered by {{AuthorRef|Carl Friedrich Gauss}} in $1813$ during the course of his investigations into electromagnetism.
{{AuthorRef|Mikhail Vasilyevich Ostrogradsky}}, who also gave the first proof of the general theorem, rediscovered it in $1826$.
It was also rediscovered by {{AuthorRef|George Green}} in $1828$, {{AuthorRef|Siméon-Denis Poisson}} in $1824$ and {{AuthorRef|Pierre Frédéric Sarrus}} in $1828$.

7f336856-c7b8-4d4f-8c03-db53b7ef1c12.text:
Let $\left({X, \circ}\right)$ be a $B$-algebra.
Then the right regular representation of $\left({X, \circ}\right)$ with respect to $0$ is a bijection.

895324b4-815b-455c-8de8-627c1906e129.text:
Let $a \in \R_{\ne 0}$.
Then:
:$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x^2 \paren {\sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} }^3} = -\frac {a x^2 + 2 b x + c} {c^2 x \sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} } + \frac {b^2 - 2 a c} {2 c^2} \int \frac {\d x} {\paren {\sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} }^3} - \frac {3 b} {2 c^2} \int \frac {\d x} {x \sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} }$

6287fec7-a7d6-446f-bc2e-3ceca58e2818.text:
Let $g$ and $h$ be elements of a group $G$ whose identity element is $e$.
Then:
:$g h = g \implies h = e$

890f5cc6-282a-4f5d-8549-a3d74da695ae.text:
Let $\sequence {d_n}$ be the sequence defined as:
:$d_n = \map \ln {n!} - \paren {n + \dfrac 1 2} \ln n + n$
Then the sequence:
:$\sequence {d_n - \dfrac 1 {12 n} }$
is increasing.

731986d6-d30b-4b54-8c7b-16cacdbc3b21.text:
Let $x, y, n$ be integers.
Let:
:$x \not \equiv \pm y \pmod n$
and:
:$x^2 \equiv y^2 \pmod n$
where $a \equiv b \pmod n$ denotes that $a$ is congruent to $b$ modulo $n$.
Then:
:$1 < \gcd \set {x - y, n} < n$
and:
:$1 < \gcd \set {x + y, n} < n$
where $\gcd \set {a, b}$ is the GCD of $a$ and $b$.

8c8db993-209d-4d2e-8cf4-2c2a6da57467.text:
Let $X$ be a topological space.
Let $U\subset X$ be an open subset.
Let $V\subset U$ be a subset.
Then $V$ is open in $U$ {{iff}} $V$ is open in $X$.

96d6a816-a10f-4526-b1f8-46cfb2443acc.text:
The indeterminate Diophantine equation:
:$16x^2 + 32x + 20 = y^2 + y$
has exactly $4$ solutions:
:$\tuple {0, 4}, \tuple {-2, 4}, \tuple {0, -5}, \tuple {-2, -5}$

b9bdbe1f-5f40-4ff7-af8d-c19e7a5928d2.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a quasigroup.
Then $\struct {S, \circ}$ is not necessarily a $B$-algebra.

f987da88-5948-4298-bb79-569bf71b50c4.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book = X|prop = 22|body = The square on a medial straight line, if applied to a rational straight line, produces as breadth a straight line rational and incommensurable in length with that to which it is applied.}}

5722ddc2-a12b-423d-bcc4-41a4dfebb3ea.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a semigroup with a right identity $e_R$.
Let $x \in S$ such that $\exists x_R: x \circ x_R = e_R$, i.e. $x$ has a right inverse with respect to the right identity.
Then:
:$\paren {x_R \circ x} \circ \paren {x_R \circ x} = x_R \circ x$
That is, $x_R \circ x$ is idempotent.

8dbde44e-f925-4262-83b5-cc9eea32971b.text:
Let $m, n, k \in \N$ where $\N$ is the set of natural numbers.
Let $<$ be the relation defined on $\N$ such that:
:$m < n \iff m \in n$
where $\N$ is defined as the minimal infinite successor set $\omega$.
Then:
:$k < m, m < n \implies k < n$
That is: $<$ is a transitive relation.

7e83bc79-3740-43ff-861b-78e64c3ce76e.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $a \sim b $ denote the relation:
:$a \sim b \iff \exists S \subseteq T: S$ is connected between the two points  $a$ and $b$
where $a, b \in X$.
Then $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.

b0eb9e82-6d57-4066-b1df-06192f09b772.text:
Let $T = \struct {\CC, \tau_d}$ be the Cantor space.
Then $T$ is non-meager in itself.

5d925360-c5e1-4867-80f3-2f0f2531e6b0.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq, \tau}$ be a generalized ordered space by Definition 1:
$\struct {S, \preceq, \tau}$ is a '''generalized ordered space''' {{iff}}:
:$(1): \quad \struct {S, \tau}$ is a Hausdorff space
:$(2): \quad$ there exists a basis for $\struct {S, \tau}$ whose elements are convex in $S$.
Then $\struct {S, \preceq, \tau}$ is a generalized ordered space by Definition 3:
$\struct {S, \preceq, \tau}$ is a '''generalized ordered space''' {{iff}}:
:$(1): \quad \struct {S, \tau}$ is a Hausdorff space
:$(2): \quad$ there exists a sub-basis for $\struct {S, \tau}$ each of whose elements is an upper set or lower set in $S$.

464f0782-1d7f-446d-89fd-741229fef852.text:
Let $\struct {\Q, \tau_d}$ be the rational number space under the Euclidean topology $\tau_d$.
Then $\struct {\Q, \tau_d}$ is not weakly $\sigma$-locally compact.

799c639b-50e3-4636-aa50-f99be2e04a57.text:
Consider a circle of radius $a$ rolling without slipping along the x-axis of a cartesian plane.
Consider the point $P$ on the circumference of this circle which is at the origin when its center is on the y-axis.
Consider the cycloid traced out by the point $P$.
Let $\tuple {x, y}$ be the coordinates of $P$ as it travels over the plane.
Then the locus of $P$ is concave.

aedf5457-a275-4d3a-bf9c-dc36b367b9ff.text:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \dfrac {\map \Phi n} {n^2} = \dfrac 3 {\pi^2}$
where:
:$\map \Phi n = \ds \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n \map \phi k$
:$\map \phi k$ is the Euler $\phi$ function of $k$.
Numerically, this evaluates to:
:$\dfrac 3 {\pi^2} \approx 0 \cdotp 30396 35509 \ldots$
{{OEIS|A104141}}

48b4da75-6e3f-4533-89e5-dce593bf74da.text: There exists an inverse completion of the natural numbers under addition.

be5c3fe0-421a-467e-8c3d-3aba0a3a2056.text:
Let $A$ be a class.
Let $\prec$ be a relation on $A$.
Furthermore, let $\map {\prec^{-1} } a$ be a small class for each $a \in A$.
Let $S$ be a small class that is a subset of the class $A$.
Let $G$ be a mapping such that:
:$\map G x = A \cap \paren {\map {\prec^{-1} } x}$
Let $F$ be defined using the Principle of Recursive Definition:
:$\map F 0 = S$
:$\map F {n^+} = \map F n \cup \map G {\map F n}$
Let $\ds T = \bigcup_{n \mathop \in \omega} \map F n$.
Then:
:$(1): \quad T$ is a set and satisfies:
::::$\forall x \in A: \forall y \in T: \paren {x \prec y \implies x \in T}$
::::In other words, $T$ is $\prec$-transitive.
:$(2): \quad S \subseteq T$
:$(3): \quad$ If $R$ is $\prec$-transitive and $S \subseteq R$, then $T \subseteq R$.
That is, given any set $S$, there is an explicit construction for its relational closure.

b9dd74ff-8aba-4497-af9d-09b22f0ef98a.text:
Let $\C$ be the complex plane.
Let $E$ be an ellipse in $\C$ whose major axis is $d \in \R_{>0}$ and whose foci are at $\alpha, \beta \in \C$.
Then $C$ may be written as:
:$\cmod {z - \alpha} + \cmod {z - \beta} = d$
where $\cmod {\, \cdot \,}$ denotes complex modulus.

a24ffd82-e945-4596-b196-ee0c15fb4e98.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $x \in S$ be an open point.
Then $T$ is a non-meager space.

954d83b5-93b0-4d0b-8b7e-682d7aeb4ad2.text: Every infinite bounded space in a real Euclidean space has at least one limit point.

af2e4612-d07e-4a9b-9a48-b982c90fd92a.text:
Let $\map {\R^3} {x, y, z}$ denote the real Cartesian space of $3$ dimensions.
Let $\mathbf V$ be a vector field on $\R^3$:
Then the gradient of the divergence of $\mathbf V$ is a conservative vector field.

65bed981-509f-4761-a8c8-2bf19a8dfbea.text:
Let $G$ and $H$ be groups which are solvable.
Then their (external) direct product $G \times H$ is also solvable.

1b03b029-65a1-4fec-93fd-7de3a5561800.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {p \sin a x + q \cos a x} = \frac 1 {a \sqrt {p^2 + q^2} } \ln \tan \size {\frac {a x + \arctan \dfrac q p} 2} + C$

5bcb60e5-9e90-40c2-b40f-cfee540af9dd.text: :$\ds \int x \sin^2 a x \rd x = \frac {x^2} 4 - \frac {x \sin 2 a x} {4 a} - \frac {\cos 2 a x} {8 a^2} + C$

56036dfe-e021-4418-bf37-741033876be8.text:
Let $a$ and $b$ be real numbers.
Let $i$ be the imaginary unit.
Then:
:$\sin \paren {a + b i} = \sin a \cosh b + i \cos a \sinh b$
where:
:$\sin$ denotes the sine function (real and complex)
:$\cos$ denotes the real cosine function
:$\sinh$ denotes the hyperbolic sine function
:$\cosh$ denotes the hyperbolic cosine function.

3f27cb18-6806-4e65-b529-604e9410428a.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Then the trivial subgroup $\struct {\set e, \circ}$ of $G$ is a normal subgroup in $G$.

03fe4bca-8c6f-4040-83ce-55d5cfaf6c8a.text:
Let $S$ be the Archimedean spiral defined by the equation:
:$r = a \theta$
Let $\theta = \theta_1$ and $\theta = \theta_2$ be the two rays from the pole at angles $\theta_1$ and $\theta_b$ to the polar axis respectively.
Let $R$ be the figure enclosed by:
:$\theta_1$ and $\theta_2$
:the $n$th turn of $S$ and the $n+1$th turn of $S$
The area $\AA$ of $R$ is given by:
:$\AA = a^2 \pi \paren {\theta_2 - \theta_1} \paren {\theta_2 + \theta_1 + 2 \pi \paren {2 n + 1} }$
{{Proofread|My algebra may have failed me}}

ac628722-a341-4ad6-bca2-e14e10a14309.text:
Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a topological space.
Let $\left \langle {x_n} \right \rangle$ be a sequence in $S$.
Let $\alpha$ be a limit point of $\left \langle {x_n} \right \rangle$.
Then $\alpha$ is an adherent point of $\left\{ {x_n: n \in \N}\right\}$.

03963eb8-78a7-43a7-aa86-f84961e41b65.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \preceq, \tau}$ be a linearly ordered space.
Then $S$ is a connected space {{iff}} it is a linear continuum.

4d66f056-ba22-4b15-a997-d496297c8ae6.text:
Let $\struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \neg}$ be a Boolean algebra, defined as in Definition 1.
Then:
:$\forall a, b, c \in S: \paren {a \wedge b} \wedge c = a \wedge \paren {b \wedge c}$
:$\forall a, b, c \in S: \paren {a \vee b} \vee c = a \vee \paren {b \vee c}$
That is, both $\vee$ and $\wedge$ are associative operations.

2ea8450a-982b-4505-8eb2-ae830c5d2e34.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a strictly positive integer.
Let $\dbinom n k$ be the binomial coefficient of $n$ over $k$ for a positive integer $k \in \Z_{\ge 0}$.
Let $S_n = \sequence {x_k}$ be the sequence defined as:
:$x_k = \dbinom n k$
Then $S_n$ is strictly increasing exactly where $0 \le k < \dfrac n 2$.

933b8d6e-7793-4bdd-a61e-26a9b5357380.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $M$ be countably compact.
Then $M$ is compact.

26746f83-70c3-4c12-b123-01b044aa7a68.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $H \subseteq S$ be a clopen set of $T$.
Let $\relcomp S H$ denote the complement of $H$ relative to $S$.
Then $\relcomp S H$ is also a clopen set of $T$.

30d1f150-3117-4d3a-80ae-459c6d46d134.text:
Let $K$ denote the circle group.
Let $\phi: K \to K$ be the homomorphism defined as:
:$\forall z \in K: \map \phi z = z^n$
for some $n \in \Z_{>0}$.
Then $\phi$ can be decomposed into the form:
:$\phi = \alpha \beta \gamma$
in the following way:
:$\alpha: K \to K$ is defined as:
::$\forall z \in K: \map \alpha z = z$
:that is, $\alpha$ is the identity mapping
:$\beta: S \to K$ is defined as:
::$\forall z \in S: \map \phi z = z^n$
:where $S$ denotes the set defined as:
::$S := \set {z \in \C: z = e^{2 \pi i x}, 0 \le x < \dfrac 1 n}$
:$\gamma: K \to S$ is defined as:
::$\forall z \in K: \map \gamma z = z \bmod \dfrac 1 n$
:where $\bmod$ denotes the modulo operation.

aa14550f-686b-4ace-9cda-ea147cfd248d.text:
Let $\struct{S, \vee_1, \wedge_1, \preceq_1}$ and $\struct{T, \vee_2, \wedge_2, \preceq_2}$ be complete lattices.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping such that
:$\forall x \in S: \map f x = \sup \leftset {\map f w: w \in S \land w \preceq_1 x \land w}$ is compact$\rightset{}$
Then
:$\forall x \in S: \map f x = \sup \set{ \map f w: w \in S \land w \ll x}$

a327e79b-bb34-471a-bf4a-81be96e3afd9.text:
{{TFAE|def = Limit Point of Set|view = limit point}}
That is, let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $H \subseteq S$.
Let $H^{\complement}$ denote the relative complement of $H$ in $S$.
Then the following conditions are equivalent for any point $x \in S$:
:$(1): \quad$ Every open neighborhood $U$ of $x$ satisfies $H \cap \paren {U \setminus \set x} \ne \O$.
:$(2): \quad x$ belongs to the closure of $H$ but is not an isolated point of $H$.
:$(3): \quad x$ is an adherent point of $H$ but is not an isolated point of $H$.
:$(4): \quad H^{\complement} \cup \set x$ is ''not'' a neighborhood of $x$.

96573593-3082-4b03-aea0-d26b276e8a0f.text:
Let $S$ be a non-empty subset of $\R$.
Let the distance $\map d {\xi, S} = 0$ for some $\xi \in \R$.
If $S$ is bounded above, then there exists a sequence $\sequence {x_n}$ in $S$ such that:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n = \sup S$

c8d307dc-9637-4a0f-a39b-0e575be080a5.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space which is totally disconnected.
Then $T$ is a $T_1$ (Fréchet) space.

2eaeb4de-0ff2-421d-b4ea-4a3450d2d1b8.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let the only clopen sets of $T$ be $S$ and $\O$.
Then there are no two non-empty separated sets of $T$ whose union is $S$.

3b48ee9e-f02e-4c2f-88f0-422ea2e2ed13.text:
Let $\triangle ABC$ be a triangle whose sides $a, b, c$ are such that $a$ is opposite $A$, $b$ is opposite $B$ and $c$ is opposite $C$.
Then:
:$c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2 a b \cos C$

e2edb6b3-732a-4c89-a248-46ccc8e59faa.text:
Let $n \Z$ be the set of integer multiples of $n$.
Let $p \in \Z: p \ge 0$ be a positive integer.
Let $S \subseteq n \Z$  be defined as:
:$S := \set {x \in n \Z: x > p}$
that is, the set of integer multiples of $n$ greater than $p$.
Then the algebraic structure $\struct {S, \times}$ is closed under multiplication.

12edd1cc-20da-45af-ad7b-09ab3322f757.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a particular point space.
Then $T$ is weakly locally compact.

f3cf75b1-43bf-46e1-b413-0e755dbd4bfe.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be an uncountable Fort space.
Let $U \subseteq S$ be a countably infinite subset of $S$.
Then $p$ is the only limit point of $U$.

a4026138-d723-4e0a-a368-b6108e4a244c.text:
Let $k$ be a field.
Let $\map {\operatorname O} {n, k}$ be the $n$th orthogonal group on $k$.
Let $\GL {n, k}$ be the $n$th general linear group on $k$.
Then $\map {\operatorname O} {n, k}$ is a subgroup of $\GL {n, k}$.

2542e5fc-5444-4e1f-a71d-e7137b891041.text:
Let $\map P x$ be a polynomial in $x$.
Let $a$ be a constant.
Then $x - a$ is a divisor of $\map P x$ {{iff}} $a$ is a root of $P$.

f8db2655-1793-40d9-860c-e5b88e0d19fa.text:
